Pediatric Epilepsy Gates

Formula

Longdan Decoction (from "Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold")

This is for treating infants who have just been born, with excessive blood and qi, experiencing alternating chills and fevers, sudden spasms in their limbs, high fever, and severe vomiting. If the infant is able to breastfeed but is unable to digest, suffering from excessive heat that transforms into steaming and can't be relieved, along with symptoms of ghostly influences and all types of epilepsy, this formula is fully applicable. All children under ten years old can take this. The Longdan Decoction for infants is the primary formula for newborns. For those who grow according to the sun and moon cycles, follow accordingly as an example. If it is necessary to know about ghostly influences and qi, you can add ginseng and angelica, adjusting the amount of Longdan accordingly: for a baby one hundred days old, add three golds; for two hundred days, six golds; for one year old, half a tael; the rest of the herbs are measured in the same way.

Ingredients: Longdan, Diao Teng Pi (Vine bark), Chai Hu (Bupleurum), Huang Qin (Scutellaria), Jie Geng (Platycodon), Shao Yao (Peony), Fu Ling (Poria), Gan Cao (Licorice), each six golds; two scarabs; one tael of Da Huang (Rhubarb).

Preparation: Chop the ten ingredients and boil them with one liter of water, reducing it to five cups as the dosage. The method of administration is as follows: for infants born to seven days old, divide one cup into three doses; for those born between eight and fifteen days, divide one and a half cups into three doses; for those born between sixteen and twenty days, divide two cups into three doses; for those born between twenty and thirty days, divide three cups into three doses; for those born between thirty and forty days, use all five cups divided into three doses. Administer until results are seen and do not continue further.[191p]
Da Huang Decoction: Treats childhood wind seizures, abdominal pain from accumulation, and upward reversal in twenty-five seizures. Ingredients: 3 "zhus" each of rhubarb, ginseng, asarum, ginger, angelica, and licorice. Combine and grind the six ingredients, boil with one liter of water until reduced to four portions. Take a dose the size of a jujube, three times daily.

Fresh White Sheep Decoction: Treats childhood wind seizures with internal illness. Ingredients: 2 "zhus" of fresh white sheep, 2 cicadas, 4 "zhus" of rhubarb, 3 "zhus" each of licorice, thing-snake vine bark, and asarum, 4 pieces of cow bile the size of a large soybean, and one inch of snake skin. Combine and grind the eight ingredients, boil with 2.5 liters of water until reduced to 1.2 liters. Divide into five doses, three times daily. If the medication runs out and seizures continue, you may add 1 "zhus" each of rhubarb and thing-snake vine, soak the herbs in water for half a month, then boil again.[192p]
Mugwort Tiger Soup
Used to treat children's fright and repel evil spirits. This soup is used for bathing.
1 pound of mugwort, 1 tiger skull.
Boil these in 3 dou of water to make the soup for bathing, which must be prepared at the time of use.

Yin Yu Balls
Used to treat children who have minor wind-related seizures that persist into adulthood, or who may have episodes triggered by changes in the weather or strong food and drink. Symptoms include tightness in the veins, irregular walking, and difficulty speaking; taking this will prevent further episodes.
Yin yu leaves, lead calx, Qin jiao, drilled bamboo skin (roasted), gypsum, du hang, and fang kui each 1 tael; fragrant calamus and huang qin each 1.5 taels; half a tael of lichen; 10 dung beetles; 3 taels of licorice.
Mix these twelve ingredients into a powder, form into honey pills the size of small beans: children under 3 years take 5 pills; children over 3 take 7 pills; children over 5 take 10 pills; those over 10 may take up to 15 pills.

Calming Heart Balls
Used to treat children's fright, seizures, and various illnesses, calming the heart.
10 grains of silver flakes, 20 grains of mercury, 6 grains of true cow bile, 4 fen each of purple quartz, pearl, fang kui, and iron essence; 3 fen of fu shen and fu ling; 2 fen each of yuan zhi, fang ji, bai lian, xiong huang, ren shen, and shao yao; 6 fen of da huang.
Mix these sixteen ingredients by first combining the mercury and silver flakes into a paste, then adding the other herbs to form pills. For a 2-year-old, use 2 pills; adjust the dosage according to the child's size. Note: This recipe does not include cow bile as one of the ingredients.[193p]
Dan Shen Mo Gao: Treats children's febrile seizures.
Dan Shen and Lei Wan, each half a tael; pig oil, two taels.
Cook the above ingredients together, seven times up and seven times down, then filter out the excess. Apply to the child’s body three times a day.

Shuang Jin San (from Zhi Zhi Fang): Treats children with sky-hanging convulsions. If prolonged and unrelenting, with visible white of the eyes, and arching of the back, unable to make sounds.
One centipede, head and feet removed, roasted in fat and split open with a bamboo knife, marking the left and right.
One penny of musk, divided and marked left and right.
Grind the above into a powder, wrapping each side. For the left side, blow into the left nostril; for the right, blow into the right nostril, each a little, but not too much. If the eyes do not return to normal, blow a bit more, stopping only when the eyes have improved.

Shen Xue Dan (from Ling Yuan Fang): Treats acute convulsions, sky-hanging heat syndrome, and similar symptoms.
Four taels of purple snake skin, calcined; one tael of pig excrement, small pieces calcined well; one tael of iron powder; half a tael of cinnabar; one penny of musk.
Grind into a powder, form into pills the size of lotus seeds with glutinous rice paste, and dry in a lacquer tray. Ensure each pill has a small hole, hence the name Shen Xue. Take one pill with mint liquor, and it will act immediately. For gruel, dissolve in cold water instead.[194p]
Mortality Powder
From "Tang's Infants' Treasure Formula"

For treating urgent and chronic convulsions in children, phlegm and saliva obstructing the throat, where life is at stake, this drug descends the phlegm and is a sacred remedy for convulsions due to phlegm.
1 tael of genuine limestone, 0.5 taels of nitre.

Grind them together into a powder. Take half a qian or one qian per dose. For acute phlegm heat related to convulsions, use mint and schizonepeta soup, mixed with raw honey to take. For chronic convulsions due to spleen deficiency, use cardamom soup mixed with cooked honey to take. Although limestone and nitre effectively resolve phlegm, they are not suitable if caused by weak spleen and stomach.

Wang Keng-Tang says: This medicine has great power to control phlegm and saliva. Regardless of acute or chronic convulsions, with phlegm swelling and blocking the throat, creating a sound like tides, termed "tide saliva," where no medicine can pass, and life is at stake, first use this medicine to enter the throat, and phlegm will immediately descend, functioning perfectly, seizing the essence of nature.

He also states: For acute convulsions with phlegm obstructing upwards, and a body temperature like fire, use fresh mint juice mixed with honey to take warm. After a long while, the medicine will wrap the phlegm which will then descend and be expelled like thick mucus, this is the effect of the medicine; then take other heat-dispelling and convulsion-stopping drugs.

For chronic convulsions also with phlegm and saliva rising, blocking the throat so that food and medicine cannot enter, doctors are at a loss, waiting for the condition to pass, just use this medicine, grinding white pills from Qingzhou into a powder, boil them into a thin paste, and mix with cooked honey to take, which will cause the saliva to descend into the stomach; subsequently, take medicines like flower snake, chuanwu, whole scorpion, centipede, etc.[195p]

For treating children’s convulsions.

Xieqing Pill treats excess heat in the liver channel and urgent convulsions. Qianghuo and Yinbi both treat the same. If there is constipation, thirst for cold drinks, and normal appetite, it suggests a tangible illness; this should be treated with laxatives. Daohong San treats excess heat in the small intestine, with symptoms of dark, scanty urination. It purges the small intestine.

The ingredients include raw Rehmannia for the heart and small intestine, Mu Tong to clear heat from the small intestine, and roasted Licorice in equal portions, used raw to drain heart fire.

Prepare this as a powder; take one qian (about 3 grams) with cool bamboo leaves and water to decoct. One variation adds Huangqin, Chishao, Qianghuo, and Dengxin for decoction. Another variation omits Licorice and uses Huangqin instead.

Xue Ji stated that according to the Xiaxin Decoction and Daohong San, these are prescriptions for clearing heart and small intestine excess fire. The heart is the mother of the spleen, and the spleen is the child of the heart. However, if the heart is ill, the spleen is likely to be weak, so practitioners should be cautious. It is advisable to protect the spleen's earth.[202p]
Shengxi San treats the heart's empty heat.
Digu Pi, Chi Shao, Chai Hu, and Gan Ge, each one and two taels; Gan Cao, five qian. Grind these into a powder. Take one to two qian each time, decocted in water. Xi Jiao, two qian, is for wind-heat seizure, calming the liver and clearing heart heat. Danxi said: Xi Jiao is used post-pox to disperse residual toxins. However, if there is no toxin but the blood is empty, or if it has mistakenly been used when there is already dryness and heat, calamities will follow. Xue Ji said: The previous prescription states it treats the heart's empty heat, yet many of the medicines used mainly belong to the categories of draining the heart and liver. The term "empty heat" may likely be a transcription error. If the heart's disease originates from blood deficiency heat, use Mi Zhi An Shen Wan. If the spleen is deficient, seizing the heart's energy and causing heat, use Mi Zhi Bu Pi Tang. If the liver fails to nourish the heart fire, leading to empty heat, use Di Huang Wan.

Mi Zhi An Shen Wan treats heart blood deficiency leading to nighttime agitation and fright, or reactions from sudden scares.
Ren Shen replenishes the five organs and stops palpitations.
Ban Xia decocted strengthens the spleen and stomach.
Suan Zao Ren, stir-fried, calms the heart and mind.
Fu Shen, one qian, opens the heart and enriches the will.
Wu Wei Zi, five grains, ground.
Dang Gui, washed in wine.
Ju Hong, and Chi Shao, both stir-fried, each seven fen.

Xie Huang San treats excess heat in the spleen and stomach.

Ingredients:

  • 7.5 qian of Huoxiang leaves (enters the hand and foot Taiyin channels) to enhance appetite and stop vomiting
  • 5 qian of gypsum to clear stomach fire
  • 1 liang of Sanjizhi (Cape Jasmine fruit)
  • 2 liang of Fangfeng

These are slightly stir-fried with honey wine and ground into a powder. The dosage is 1 to 2 qian, decocted in water. Xue Ji stated: If symptoms include thirst for cold drinks, lying down with eyes closed, hot hands and feet, or jaundice, this indicates excess heat in the stomach channel, and Xie Huang San should be used. If there is thirst for soup, lying down with exposed eyes, and cold hands and feet, this indicates deficiency heat in the stomach channel, and Yi Gong San should be used. If the face is green, with a writhing belly and little appetite for dairy, this indicates liver overacting on the spleen; use Mi Zhi Bu Pi Tang. If the face is red with anxiety, body heat, and somnolence, this indicates heart overacting on the spleen; use Mi Zhi An Shen Wan. If there is a pale face with wheezing and fatigue, indicating lung overacting on the spleen, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang. If there are black lips and diarrhea with cold fingers and toes, indicating kidney overacting on the spleen, use Yi Huang San. After illness, if fluids are insufficient, leading to dry mouth and thirst, use Qi Wei Bai Zhu San. If a nursing mother consumes rich and heavy foods, leading to emotional excess fire, the cause must be identified and treated in the mother.

Gua Lou Tang treats chronic fright.[204p]
Ingredients:

  • 2 qian of melon dung root
  • 1 qian of white sweetwormwood

These should be lightly roasted over a slow fire until yellow and then ground into a powder. Each dose is 2-3 fen, taken with a decoction of mint and musk. Xue Ji explains: According to Xu Yongcheng, Qian’s treatment for gradual fright uses melon soup, fearing that there may be transcription errors. This is because fright is primarily due to the wind element, associated with the Yang of wood; acute conditions are easy to treat, while chronic conditions are difficult. Moreover, children’s internal organs are not fully developed, and when they experience gradual fright, it is not a result of post-illness or vomit and diarrhea leading to spleen and stomach deficiency. Thus, be cautious with such harsh remedies.

Wang Keng Tang adds: The melon soup on the right is a method by Qian for treating gradual fright, suitable for those with a strong pulse. This condition is caused by damp phlegm accumulating in the diaphragm, preventing wind and fire from resolving, leading to a cold body; hence the use of melon soup to eliminate damp phlegm allows wind and fire to manifest, warming and halting spasms. If the pulse is weak, it is inappropriate to use this; instead, one should supplement the spleen and apply warming formulas like Warming Fright Pill or similar remedies.

Warming Fright Pill: Treats symptoms of gradual fright. Also known as Pink Powder Pill.

Ingredients:

  • 4 liang of dried southern star (Nux vomica) powder, mixed with ox bile and air-dried for 100 days.

The mixture should be made into pills the size of a chicken head; each dose is one pill, or half a pill for smaller children, taken with sugar water. However, the herbs included are primarily spicy and disperse Yang Qi to eliminate phlegm, and the practitioner should assess accordingly.[205p]

Zhang Shi Wen Pi San treats spleen and stomach depletion, abdominal and flank distension, poor appetite for dairy and food, and fatigue.

Qingxin Pills: Treats shock, heat, and restlessness.

Juzhi Decoction: Treats the condition of wind and dampness attacking the body, causing pain and discomfort, making it difficult to turn or shift position; with no vomiting or thirst, hard stools, and freely passing urine, as well as symptoms of wind causing dizziness and heaviness in the head.

Ingredients:

  • 4 taels of White Atractylodes (Bai Zhu)
  • 2 taels of roasted Licorice (Gan Cao)
  • 1.5 taels of processed Aconite (Fu Zi), peeled and with the seed removed

Method: Grind the above into a fine powder, then add Aconite. For each dose, take 3 qian, along with 5 slices of ginger and 1 jujube, and decoct in water for consumption.

Xue Ji states: "In my humble opinion, Aconite warms the center and restores yang; it is the premier medicine for the spleen's slow function. If the vital energy is not depleted, its efficacy is guaranteed. Use pieces weighing around 1.5 to 2.4 qian, regular and flat with a shape resembling a lotus flower; otherwise, they resemble poisonous black Aconite."

Preparation method: Cut off the pointed ends and soak in child's urine for a specified period—7 days in autumn and winter, and 5 days in spring and summer, changing the urine daily. After soaking, cut into four pieces, wrap them in several layers of damp paper, and gently simmer for half a day. After removal, cut open; if there are no white specks, it is prepared correctly. If needed urgently, process until cracks form, then immediately soak in child’s urine for an extended period, slice once fully soaked, and if the color is white, lightly roast again. For severe depletion of energy, urgent use is effective as well.[208p]

Baolong Pills treat wind-heat epidemics, body heat, and drowsiness, as well as cough caused by phlegm and wind-heat obstruction. Danxi stated: The Baolong Pills are for the heart, lungs, and liver. "Bao" means to protect; "Long" refers to the liver. Xue Ji noted: The main functions of this pill are to resolve phlegm, expel evil, and clear heat, especially effective for conditions arising from excess heat in the liver and heart. The Wan family said: Strong and healthy children should use it. However, within it contains medicinal substances like male red gold stone that cannot be consumed. For instance, musk consumes true vitality and can draw in the wind evil, much like oil cannot be expelled once it enters the skin. Therefore, everyone forbids it and does not use it lightly. Wang Kengtang said: For the medicine mentioned, for infants of a hundred days, each pill is divided into three or four doses; for five-year-olds, one or two pills; for adults, three to five pills. It also treats white discharge in young girls; for summer heat, chew a small amount of salt with one or two pills and swallow with freshly drawn water. Boiling snow water in the twelfth month, combined with licorice and the medicine, is especially good. One method involves soaking southern star root in rice water or fresh water for three days until it is translucent, then boiling it softly for three to five times, taking it out, cutting off the skin while soft, only taking the white soft part, thinly slicing it, drying it out, and roasting it until yellow. Take eight taels of this powder, with two and a half taels of licorice smashed, use two bowls of water to soak overnight, then slowly boil until half a bowl remains, remove the dregs, and gradually pour the southern star powder into it while slowly grinding, ensuring the licorice water is fully absorbed before adding the remaining medicine.[221p]

Ren Shen, amber, white poria, yuan zhi prepared with ginger, stir-fried meat, cinnabar, tian ma, finely ground shi chang pu, chuan xiong, nan xing, qing dai, each 1 qian; musk, 1 spoon. Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, take 1-2 pills with jinyin mint decoction. One formulation has huai shan and gan cao, but no amber or qing dai.

Hu jing wan treats the evil qi of epilepsy entering the heart.

Hu jing, finely ground; yuan zhi soaked in ginger juice, heart removed; rhino horn shavings; da huang wrapped in wet paper and steamed; shi chang pu; mai men dong, all of equal parts; three scarab beetles, feet and wings removed and stir-fried. Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, take 1-2 pills with bamboo leaf decoction or jinyin mint decoction.

Qing shen decoction treats epilepsy.

Rhino horn shavings; yuan zhi roasted with ginger juice; white lichen skin; shi chang pu; ren shen; gan cao, stir-fried, each 1.5 qian. Grind the above into a powder, take 5-7 fen with mai men dong decoction.

Mi tuo seng powder treats heart epilepsy without speech and other cases of shock and loss of voice. Mi tuo seng, grind finely, take 1 spoon with rice vinegar decoction; adults take 1 qian with hot wine.

Scorpion and tiger powder treats epilepsy.[226p]
A brown scorpion is ground finely, mixed with a small amount of realgar and musk, and prepared with peppermint tea to make a dose. This is effective for several years. The reason is that epilepsy is caused by the stagnation of heart blood, and the scorpion helps control the blood. After this, continue with Er Chen Tang. If scorpions are unavailable, use the blood of a male wild boar instead. Adding daizhi stone powder is particularly wonderful.

Daizhi Stone Powder treats both yin and yang epilepsy. The daizhi stone is calcined, rinsed with vinegar, ground into powder, and then water-floated and dried. This becomes the powder, and each dose is taken with half a qian, decocted with gold and silver, mixed with gold foil and silver foil, taken in two doses. If there are red spots on the shins, that indicates the evil qi is releasing, and it can be treated; if there are no red spots, it is difficult to treat.

Huafeng Dan cools wind, dispels phlegm, reduces heat, and calms convulsions. It consists of two qian of cattle gall, Nánxīng, Qianghuo, Duhuo, Fangfeng, Tianma, Ginseng, Chuanxiong, Jingjie, and one qian each of powdered grass, with a whole scorpion. Grind the ingredients into powder, make honey pills the size of a soapberry, and take one qian with peppermint tea. If whole scorpion is unavailable, substitute with licorice and Xixin. If adding, include cinnabar and musk.

Fushen Tang treats deficiency and cold of the gallbladder qi, headaches, dizziness, anxiety, and fear, and those who cannot be alone or may have fright-induced epilepsy. The ingredients are each one or two liang of Fushen, fried jujube seed, fried Astragalus, fried Baiziren, fried white peony, and fried Schisandra; and five fen each of cassia heart, self-prepared cooked Rehmannia, ginseng, and fried licorice. Each dose is two to three qian and boiled with ginger water.[227p]
Sour Jujube Seed Pill treats stern heat and fright caused by excessive gallbladder energy, or uneasy sleep, anxiety, and palpitations. Ingredients include: fried Sour Jujube Seed, Poria, Polygala, fried Biota Seed, Fangfeng, fried Bitter Orange Peel, and powdered Fresh Rehmannia, each half a tael; 2.5 qian of fragrant bamboo reed. Nourishing the Heart Decoction treats deficiency of heart blood and dispels fright and epilepsy. It may present as anxiety, palpitations, night sweats with insomnia, fever, and irritability. Wonderful Aroma Powder treats insufficient heart energy, fright and epilepsy, or mental confusion, irritability with little sleep, and symptoms of night sweats. Great Black Dragon Pill
Effective for treating sudden and chronic convulsions in children.

Pharmaceutical Recipes for Pediatric Convulsions
Phlegm-Relief Pill[229p]
Niudan Nixing: one qian each of Cow Gall, Zhi Ke with kernel removed, and Chen Pi with white parts removed; five qian of Da Huang; two qian of Qian Niu Tou powder; mix into a fine powder, boil with soap pod water, and take with lampwick decoction.

An Shen Wan: two qian each of Huang Lian with roots and hairs removed, Shi Chang Pu, Yuan Zhi with heart removed, Dang Gui body, Mai Men Dong with heart removed, and Shan Zhi Ren fried; eight qian of Fu Shen; mix into powder, combine with millet paste, use pork heart blood to form into pills, coated with cinnabar, and take with lampwick decoction.

Shen Gui Dan: three qian each of Xiong Huang, Sang Ji Sheng, Tian Zhu Huang, and Diaoteng Gou; two qian each of Quan Xie with legs removed, Cow Gall, Nixing, Wu Tong Lei, and Jiang Can fried; one qian each of Zhen Zhu, Niu Huang, and Amber; a little Bing Pian; use the above for powder, mix with millet flour paste for cakes, coated with gold leaf, taken with mint, lampwick, and bamboo leaf decoction.

Dao Chi San: Niu Huang, Mu Tong, Gan Cao tips, Mai Men Dong with heart removed, Shan Zhi Ren, and seven bamboo leaves; boil in water and take. A medicine to drain heart fire. To disperse, add Fang Feng and Mint.

Wu Se Wan: two qian each of Huang Qin and Huang Lian; three qian of Da Huang; without color, called San Huang Wan; with color, named Wu Se Wan. Mix into a fine powder, divide into five parts, moisten with water to form pills. One part with Qingtai for coating, called Qing Wan; one part with Cinnabar for coating, called Hong Wan; one part with Xiong Huang for coating, called Huang Wan; one part with burned Zao Jiao ash for coating, called Hei Wan.[230p]
Ding Chuan Decoction
Aged tangerine peel, processed south star, gardenia seeds, soft gypsum, almond paste, mint leaves, red poria. Boil these in water and add bamboo juice.

Qingzhou White Pills
For treating child convulsions.
Processed pinellia, chuanwu, and white fuzi, each five taels; south star three taels. Grind these into a fine powder, place in a silk bag, and soak in well water until saturated. Place in a ceramic container, sun-dry during the day and dew under the night, change water daily, making sure to stir several times, continuing until it looks like jade flakes and then grind it finer. Grind an additional qi ming stone, one qian, and mix it finely with five fen of nitre; then, place both powders in a copper pot and heat until red-hot until the nitre is fully consumed, allow to cool, and mix with the above medicines. Form into pills using glutinous rice and take with mint in honey, which will help expel phlegm.

Tiao Yuan Decoction
The Inner Canon states: "Excess heat within should be countered with sweet to drain and with sour to restrain." This is what it refers to.
One qian of Huangqi, five fen each of ginseng and white peony, two and a half fen of roasted licorice. Boil these in water and consume.

Huangqi Decoction
For treating chronic convulsions and greenish diarrhea. This condition arises from liver wood attacking spleen earth; first solidify the earth, then drain the wood. This is the method of divine treatment.
Two qians of Huangqi, one qian of ginseng, five fen of roasted licorice.[231p]
Prepare a decoction with one mouthful of the medicine and one large cup of water, simmer until reduced to half a cup, strain, and consume regularly. Adding white peony root is especially beneficial. These three ingredients are all sweet and warm, capable of replenishing vital energy. Sweetness can clear heat. The Inner Canon states: when heat is excessive within, it should be mitigated with sweetness and contained with sourness. White peony root is sour and cool, which can also clear heat; its sour flavor can drain the liver while greatly nourishing the lungs, thereby enhancing both metal and earth energies. When fire is deficient, how can wind and wood overcome the earth? Thus, expel the邪 of wind. Formulas like Yao Huang San, Li Zhong Wan, and Yang Shen Wan are all excellent remedies for conditions of excessive cold dampness in the spleen and stomach. If heat dynamic is trapped within the spleen and stomach due to insufficient effort and one takes hot medicines like ba dou, it can lead to a weak stomach and chronic shock syndrome, which can be harmful. Chronic shock is always due to a prolonged weakening of the spleen and stomach. Qian's method using Qiang Huo ointment to treat chronic shock has proven effective. For those with spleen deficiency, fire pathogens take advantage of their earth's position, which is why this condition is called “virtual邪.” When fire is strong, it can bolster wood, and when wood is abundant, it can attack the earth. Therefore, in heart conditions, one should sweetly and warmly nourish the source of earth, while in the spleen, drain heat with cool sweetness and fortify metal with sour cold, leading to a strong metal and weak fire in the spleen, thus alleviating the wind and wood. Reducing food intake and increasing medicinal consumption will lead to self-recovery; the aforementioned medicines can aid in this.[232p]
Yi Huang San: Treats stomach wind-heat.
Ingredients: 2 qian of Astragalus, 1 qian each of dried tangerine peel and ginseng, 7 fen of peony root, 5 fen each of raw and cooked licorice, a pinch of Coptis. Grind these into a fine powder. For each dose, take 2 qian with 1 cup of water, decoct until reduced to 5 parts, and take before meals. One variation adds white poria.

Bu Yang Tang: For a small child, 2 years old, with a cold syndrome in early winter. Symptoms include a bluish vein on the forehead, a bluish-black forehead, a prominent bluish vein at the back of the head, a white slippery tongue, wheezing and coughing, slightly bluish stools, cold tips of the ears, constant tearing from the eyes, significant discomfort in the chest, frequent disturbance in sleep, but without spasm indicates cold.
Ingredients: 5 fen each of Wu Zhu Yu, raw Rehmannia, and earthworm; 1 fen each of goldthread, tangerine peel, kudzu root, forsythia, scorpion tail, and roasted licorice; 2 fen each of Angelica, Astragalus, and Bupleurum; 3 fen each of Angelica and Ephedra.
Grind these together into a single dose, add 1.5 large cups of water, decoct until reduced to 6 parts, strain, and take warm after the milk feed. After taking the medicine, bring joy and laughter, improving spirit and harmonizing the qi, resulting in robust appetite.[233p]
Amber Dragon Ball

This remedy is for children experiencing fright, seasonal wind and cold, excessive phlegm and heat, leading to restlessness and agitation, as well as coughing and difficulty breathing, and when rashes are about to erupt. It is also suitable for their treatment.

Ingredients include:

  • Genuine amber: 1.5 taels
  • Turmeric: 1.5 taels
  • Finely powdered sandalwood: 1.5 taels
  • Ginseng (peeled): 1.5 taels
  • White poria (peeled): 1.5 taels
  • Fresh licorice: 3 taels (cut to remove joints)
  • Bitter orange peel (roasted): 1 tael
  • Bitter orange (soaked in water, roasted until slightly yellow): 1 tael
  • Chinese yam (peeled, cut into small pieces, stir-fried over low heat until thoroughly heated): 1 pound
  • Noxious star (shredded): 1 tael (fermented with sulfur and cow bile over the summer)
  • Cinnabar: 5 taels (first use a magnet to remove iron filings, then grind in a mortar to remove floating impurities; clarify in a clean container and drain excess water, following this process to refine it until pure, then dry for use)

Combine the final powdered medicine (1 tael) with 100 sheets of gold leaf, grind together very finely in a mortar, blend with the previous mixture, then form into pills the size of green peas using fresh well water, and air-dry. Each dose should be taken with mint decoction.

Amber Dragon Ball contains nourishing ingredients that everyone appreciates. However, the two ingredients, bitter orange peel and bitter orange, can disperse stagnant energy. For those without stagnant energy, they may weaken the vital energy in the chest. In cases of chronic fright or weakened vital energy, these two ingredients should be reduced; they can be replaced with 2 taels each of angelica and chuanxiong. Ensure that the amber and turmeric are genuine.[234p]
Wang Kengtang said: The first twelve ingredients, excluding vermilion and gold leaf which are not ground together, and among the remaining ten, sandalwood is the only one not subjected to heat. Nine of the ingredients are either sun-dried or roasted, ground into a powder, and mixed evenly. Use one tael of vermilion and one tael of gold leaf. Take one tael of fresh well water, slightly pound it in a mortar, and roll it into balls the size of a chicken egg, then dry in the shade. In sunny weather, avoid excessive exposure to sunlight as it may cause cracking. It is advisable to leave them in a windy place to dry naturally. The preparation method also uses scallion broth, to be taken at any time, or mint broth. If phlegm causes severe coughing, take it with light ginger broth. If smallpox appears unexpectedly, take it with warm clean broth. For palpitations and unease, take it with lamp grass broth. In hot weather, if there is fatigue or confusion, take it with water from cooked Ophiopogon. For infants within a hundred days, take three doses of each pill. For those over two years old, limit to one or two pills.[235p]
When preparing the medicinal formula, if one ingredient is missing and it does not follow the established standards, it will surely be ineffective. Always use a ceramic bottle to combine with musk, to prevent the scent from dissipating. Mix in one tael of pearl powder, called "Golden Pearl Powder." Pearls can calm the heart and soothe the liver, particularly effective for expelling phlegm. The method of preparation is the same as before. Moreover, the meaning of "embracing the dragon" is to protect, with the dragon representing the liver. The liver corresponds to the eastern azure dragon of wood; wood generates fire, which symbolizes the nurturing parents. The liver is the mother, and the heart is the child; if the mother is stable, so shall the child be peaceful. The heart stores the spirit, and the liver stores the soul; if the spirit and soul are settled, where can anxiety arise? Thus, it is said that "Embracing Dragon Pill" treats various disturbances in children, such as seasonal colds from wind and cold, warm epidemic heat causing restlessness, phlegm cough with breathlessness, and prevention of emerging sores and rashes, all suitable for administration. Its medicinal nature is warm and balanced, not harsh or drying. Regular use disperses wind, transforms phlegm, calms the heart, relieves heat, harmonizes the spleen and stomach, and nourishes the spirit.[236p]
Baolong Pill: The word "hold" refers to nurturing. The dragon represents pure Yang energy; it corresponds to thunder and is associated with the wood of the east, symbolizing the energy of lesser Yang. When spring arrives, it marks the beginning of the emergence of all things. The character "Yi" represents the liver and wood, with the liver governing wind and embodying the image of a newborn child, which is pure Yang without Yin. The liver is characterized by excess, and the energy of lesser Yang is strong. The liver governs wind; when children are ill, they may experience heat, and heat can give rise to wind. A skilled physician considers this, creating this formula to balance the liver wood and prevent convulsions; hence, the name "hold the dragon." This medicine is essential for children to nourish their Yin and support them, ensuring balance. Furthermore, the azure dragon corresponds to the liver wood, and as children's livers often have excess while their spleens are generally deficient, this medicine curbs the liver and strengthens the spleen, thus named "hold the dragon." It treats conditions of strong heat, drowsiness with coarse breath, or coughs caused by phlegm and convulsions.

Ingredients:

  • Tianzhu Yellow: 1 qian
  • Cinnabar (Chenshi): 1 qian
  • Niu Huang (Cattle Bile): 2 fen
  • Musk: 0.5 fen
  • Pearl
  • Amber
  • Sandalwood
  • Zhi Ke (Bitter Orange Peel): 3 fen
  • Zhi Shi (Bitter Orange): 3 fen
  • Niu Dan Xing (Cattle Bile Star): 5 qian

In the twelfth month, take one cattle bile, remove the skin and navel from the southern star herb, grind it into powder, and place it inside the bile to dry in the shade for future use. Combine all to make a powder, mix with yam paste to form pills the size of yellow beans, and coat with gold foil. Prescription for Treating Shock and Epilepsy
For treating children with excessive liver fire characterized by frequent eye movements, phlegm rising, potential severe heat leading to convulsions, red complexion, strong pulse, and no damage to spleen and stomach, it is advisable to drain liver fire.
Ingredients:

  • 6 grams of Angelica
  • 6 grams of Bupleurum
  • 6 grams of tangerine peel
  • 6 grams of stir-fried bitter orange
  • 6 grams of Gastrodia
  • 8 grams of white Poria
  • 8 grams of Chuanxiong
  • 8 grams of stir-fried white peony
  • 4 grams of licorice
  • 4 grams of stir-fried Coptis
  • 3 grams of mint
    Take 2 taels of the mixture, boiled with ginger water.
    Xu Ji states: If the symptoms arise from wind-heat in the liver channel, the above prescription is appropriate. If they arise from blood dryness in the liver channel, the Six-Ingredient Pill should be used. If the liver wood impairs the spleen earth, the Four Gentlemen Decoction with the addition of Cimicifuga and Bupleurum is indicated. If lung metal damages liver wood, use the Xie Bai Powder. If kidney water cannot nourish liver wood, the Six-Ingredient Pill is advised. Should the patient experience palpitations and insomnia after recovery, or exhibit convulsions and teeth grinding during sleep, Gui Pi Decoction supplemented with Poria and Schisandra should be applied. The excess indicates a strong pathogenic factor; the deficiency indicates a weakness in true qi.[243p]
    For any illness characterized by excess, one should consider it as deficiency. The classics say: "Where evil gathers, the vital energy must be weak."

Furthermore, to treat children with deficiencies in the spleen and stomach, where the Earth is defeated and the Wood dominates, observe if the eyes are slightly moving, the limbs are slightly twitching, or if there are alternating fevers. This indicates injury to the spleen and stomach, with diminished appetite, and possibly diarrhea or vomiting, pale complexion, weak pulse; thus, it is necessary to tonify the spleen and stomach.

The prescription includes:

  • 1.3 grams of Atractylodes
  • Honey-fried Astragalus
  • 5 grams of Chuan Xiong
  • Wine-washed Angelica
  • 5 grams of dried Tangerine Peel
  • 5 grams of Ginseng
  • 5 grams of roasted Nutmeg
  • 5 grams of Massa Fermentata
  • 7 grams of dried Kudzu Root
  • 1 gram of White Peony, stir-fried in wine
  • 4 grams of Coptis
  • 4 grams of Licorice
  • 7 grams of Pinellia
  • 7 grams of White Poria

These are to be decocted in ginger water for consumption. Xue Ji states: In my humble opinion, if the condition arises from spleen and stomach weakness, it should be supplemented with the Five Flavor Decoction. If there is cold deficiency, add Wood Fragrance, or further add roasted Ginger to warm it. If it is due to the descent of spleen qi, use the Middle-Established Energy-Boosting Decoction. For thirst, use the Seven Flavor Atractylodes Powder. If it is due to spleen and stomach weakness with cold water dominating the Earth, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction, adding Wood Fragrance and roasted Ginger to warm it. If it arises from spleen and stomach weakness with Liver Wood oppressing the Earth, use the Middle-Established Energy-Boosting Decoction plus Poria, Peony, and Pinellia to adjust.[244p]
If the liver wood is excessive, leading to restriction of the spleen earth, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with roasted gardenia. If due to injury from fish and meat, use Six Gentlemen Decoction, adding hawthorn and cardamom to dispel it. If caused by injury from cold leading to abdominal pain or clear diarrhea, Six Gentlemen Decoction should be used with cardamom, costus, and roasted ginger to warm it. If caused by an injury from pungent heat, resulting in stagnant vomiting of sour fluids or loose stools, use Six Gentlemen Decoction with Huang Lian, Wu Zhu Yu, and costus to harmonize it. If accumulation leads to persistent diarrhea, use Four Gentlemen Decoction with nutmeg, cheesy fruit, costus, and ginger to nourish the spleen and kidneys. If diarrhea stops but appetite diminishes, use Baizhu Powder to strengthen the spleen and stomach.

Additionally, to treat children with heart and blood deficiency, causing insomnia and fright, focus on clearing the heart, calming the spirit, and resolving phlegm. Ingredients include: one qian each of ginseng, pinellia, and fried sour jujube seeds; seven fen each of angelica wine-washed, citrus peel, and red peony; five grains of five-flavored fruit; three fen of roasted licorice. Prepare with water, adding a little ginger juice and bamboo juice. A half-fen of ox gall can enhance the effectiveness.[245p]
If experiencing a warm heart with excessive heat in the heart, add five parts of raw Rehmannia and gardenia fruit, seven parts of Ophiopogon, and bamboo leaves. If the condition of food stagnation due to fright occurs, it is necessary to first resolve the food stagnation and then address the fright. Add white atractylodes and malt to the fright remedy to regulate the spleen and stomach. When fright disperses qi, it is essential to gather and replenish the qi; when fright causes phlegm aggregation, it is necessary to resolve the phlegm. Xue Ji stated: In cases with insufficient heart blood and heart spirit agitation, this formula should be used. If excessive wood and fire disturb the heart spirit, use the Dao Chi San. If wood and fire combine with wind-heat causing illness, use Chai Hu Zhi Zi San. If the liver and heart are weak, with wood and fire unresolved leading to illness, use the Liu Wei Wan. If phlegm arises from stagnated spleen and stomach due to food, causing agitation, use the Si Jun Zi Tang to strengthen the spleen, along with Shen Qu, Ban Xia, and malt to transform phlegm, and add gardenia and peony to clear heat. If food stagnation leads to abdominal bloating, vomiting, or diarrhea, use the Liu Jun Zi Tang to strengthen the spleen, adding hou po and shen qu to aid digestion. If there's phlegm causing fright, continue using the original formula for treatment. If symptoms of the liver channel are present, add vine hook and replace red peony with white peony in the formula.[246p]
Anshen Zhenjing Pill is a remedy for calming the spirit, nourishing the blood after shock, and preventing future disturbances. The ingredients include:

  • Tianzhu Huang
  • Ren Shen
  • Fu Shen
  • Nan Xing prepared with ginger, each five qian
  • Fried Suan Zao Ren
  • Mai Men Dong
  • Dang Gui washed with wine
  • Sheng Di Huang washed with wine
  • Fried Chi Shao Yao, each three qian
  • Bo He
  • Mu Tong
  • Huang Lian fried with ginger juice
  • Fried Shan Zhi
  • Chen Sha
  • Niu Huang, ground separately
  • Long Gu, calcined, each two qian
  • QIng Dai, one qian, ground separately.

This mixture is ground into a powder and made into pills the size of soybeans, to be taken with light ginger tea, three to five pills each time.

Xue Ji states: In my humble opinion, this formula fundamentally aims at treatment and prevention. However, it contains many bitter, cold, and acrid ingredients which may be harmful if used lightly after illness, as they could damage the stomach's energy and lead to other ailments. If there are symptoms arising from food stagnation, the main focus should be on elimination. If there are symptoms due to damage to the spleen and stomach, the emphasis should be on strengthening the middle energy. Generally speaking, if the vital energy has not yet recovered after illness, or if it has been further harmed by purging remedies, the focus should be on promoting and replenishing the yang energy, allowing symptoms to self-resolve, as targeting the illness directly may lead to errors.[247p]
Di Huang Wan

Wang Kentang said: It treats children's liver channel deficiency and internal heat, blood dryness, or conditions caused by wind and dampness, resulting in scrofula or tuberculosis, twitching of limbs, eye spasms, and phlegm rising. It also addresses kidney deficiency symptoms like brain heat, body emaciation, cold hands and feet, alternation of cold and heat, diarrhea, abdominal distension, bad breath, dry thirst, gum sores, dark nails, and facial pallor. This may also include sores on the body and ears, ear discharge, fever, spontaneous sweating, night sweats, blood in stools, and loss of voice, among other symptoms, which cannot all be described.

Ingredients:

  • Prepared Rehmannia: 4 qian
  • Cornelian Cherry: 4 qian
  • Dried Chinese Yam: 4 qian
  • Alisma: 3 qian
  • Peony Root: 3 qian
  • White Poria (peeled): 3 qian

Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, hollow inside, and take with warm water, thirty pills. Wang Kentang states that Bawei Di Huang Wan is the Six Flavor Rehmannia Pill with the addition of 1 liang each of Aconite and Cinnamon. It treats deficiency of the fire of the life gate from congenital constitution, which cannot generate earth, leading to spleen deficiency and cold. Symptoms include lack of appetite, poor digestion, abdominal pain, and frequent urination at night. The classics say: "Nourishing the original fire to dispel the shadows of yin," referring to this. If a nursing mother has weak fire in her life gate, and the child drinks her milk leading to the above symptoms, both mother and child should take this.

Furthermore, the augmented or reduced Bawei Wan, which consists of Di Huang Wan plus 1 liang of Cinnamon and 4 liang of Schisandra, treats congenital kidney yin deficiency, or prolonged illness from vomiting or diarrhea leading to fluid depletion, dry mouth and thirst, or sores on the mouth or tongue, warm feet, or rising phlegm and qi, or cold extremities, among other symptoms.[248p]
Sneeze Dispersal
For treating sudden fright and gradual fright, causing confusion and unconsciousness.
Take half a qian of Pinellia and half a qian of soap pod.

Open Sneeze Like a Sage Powder

Grind the ingredients to a powder. For the left eye flipping and left hand trembling, blow the left powder into the left nostril. For the right eye flipping and right hand trembling, blow the right powder into the right nostril. For both eyes and both hands, combine the actions.

Wind Elimination Decoction

Pearl Pill
For treating sudden convulsions in children, with copious drooling and high fever with phlegm obstruction.

Hu Po San

Indication: Treats acute and chronic convulsions in children, drooling, stupor, eye rolling, abdominal pain from shock, mild suppression of measles, restless crying during sleep—immediate effect upon ingestion. For shock and seizures, continuous use eliminates the root cause of the illness.

  • Ingredients:
    • Cinnabar (Chen Sha) - 1.5 qian
    • Amber (Hu Po), Bovine gallstone (Niu Huang), Gastrodia (Tian Ma), Fried silkworm (Jiang Can), Scorpion (Quan Xie) - 1 qian each
    • White Atractylodes (Bai Fu Zi), Frankincense (Ru Xiang), Cicada slough (Chan Tui) - 1 qian each
    • Musk (She) - 0.5 qian
    • Calcined red ochre (Dai Zhe Shi) - 1 qian (processed with vinegar seven times)
    • One character of brain (Pian Nao), one character of gallstone (Dan Xing)

Preparation: Grind to a powder. For three-year-olds, administer 1 qian, mixed with peppermint tea. For chronic shocks, add 1 fen of Aconite (Fu Zi).[251p]
Dissipating Qi: For children after a slow fright, use this to adjust them. Ingredients: each one qian of Mu Xiang, Xiang Fu, Ren Shen, Ju Pi, Huo Xiang, and Zhi Cao. Prepare by decocting with ginger and jujubes.

Cinnamon Twig Decoction: Treats Taiyang Wind syndrome, with yang floating and yin weak; yang floating means heat is self-releasing, yin weak means sweat is self-producing; characterized by aversion to cold, slight fever, and nasal congestion with dry vomiting. Ingredients: one and a half tael of peeled Gui Zhi, one and a half tael of Sheng Jiang, and one tael of Sheng Gan Cao. Grind the ingredients, and for each dose, take three qian with two jujubes and one cup of water, decoct until eight parts remain. Shortly thereafter, sip a bowl of congee to assist the medicinal effect. Keep warm and allow for slight sweating over time; slight sweating all over the body is optimal. Gui Zhi is effective in response throughout the year for people from the northwest. In the Jianghuai region, it should only be used in winter and spring. For symptoms of Gui Zhi from spring before summer solstice, half a tael each of Zhi Mu and Shi Gao can be added, or one fen of Sheng Ma can be included. If the patient has a history of deficiency and cold, use the ancient formula.

Kudzu Decoction: Treats Taiyang disease with neck stiffness, aversion to wind, no sweat, and no aversion to cold, presenting with rigidity. Ingredients: four tael of Ge Gen, three qian of Ma Huang, one tael of Gui, and two tael each of Sheng Gan Cao and Shao Yao. Grind the ingredients, and for each dose, take five qian with one and a half cups of water, five slices of Sheng Jiang, and two jujubes; decoct to one cup, and induce slight sweating.[252p]

Grind nitre and sulfur into a fine powder, lightly roast with a willow stick while continuously stirring, allowing the yin energy to meld in, taking care not to overheat.

One tael each of transparent sulfur and primordial subtle stone; two taels each of five-spice resin, green peel, and aged peel; grind the resin and peels into a fine powder, then mix with the powdered primordial stone and previous powders, combining well with good vinegar to form pills the size of peas. Tian Nansheng Pill
One jin of Tian Nansheng, each piece weighing about 1 liang. Rinse in warm water and scrape off the outer and inner skin, soak in wine overnight, then steam with mulberry wood, continuously adding water until the pot is full and steam overflows. Sprinkle with wine regularly to keep the herbs moist; do this for seven cycles. Afterward, take out and cut a large piece with a bronze knife. Chew a bit; if it does not numb the tongue, it is done. If not, continue steaming until ready. Then, cut finely and dry.
Ingredients: Each 1 liang of ground musk, ground cloves, and ground cinnabar (water-floated separately); two halves of dragon brain. Grind all these into a powder, combine with honey and wine to make pills, coated with cinnabar, to be taken with ginger soup, about one bean-sized.[255p]
Lingzhi Pill

Jinye Dan
Treats chronic vomiting and diarrhea, spleen and stomach deficiency, cold extremities, spiritual lethargy, excessive coldness with watery eyes, and cold breath from the mouth and nose, wanting to become prone to chronic fright.

Bò Hé Sǎn

One variant includes bupleurum, rhizome of ligusticum, platycodon, and poria, excluding scorpion, silkworm, muskroot, and white atractylodes.

Yǎng Shēng Bì Yòng Shé Huáng Wán
One piece of snake gall, calcined and re-steeped, two qian each of pyrite, red lead, and realgar, and four qian of iron powder, ground very fine. Form into pills using honey, and for children over five years old, swallow with a decoction of gold and silver; for younger children, use smaller pills like millet size.

Sǎn Fēng Sǎn - Treats wind epilepsy, first use this.
One qian of bovine gall, one qian each of notopterygium, ligusticum, saposhnikovia, gastrodia, ginseng, schizonepeta, and chuanxiong. Grind into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, and take two pills with a decoction of mint and perilla.

Rì Yìng Dān - Treats chronic epilepsy.[261p]
Black tin, sulfur, mercury, and iron powder, each half a tael; thirty sheets of gold and silver foil. Mix the mercury, iron powder, and gold and silver foil together. First, melt the black tin in a crucible, then add sulfur, stirring continuously until the sulfur fumes wane. Afterward, add the remaining ingredients and stir over heat. After a short while, pour it out on the ground overnight to release the toxic fumes. Grind it fine, forming pills the size of a millet grain, coat them with cinnabar. Take three pills after meals with ginseng soup.

Whole scorpion five-itch pills are used to treat children's five ailments.

One red centipede, remove the head and feet, soak in alcohol and roast; half an ounce of Nanchang star, one character of musk; one whole scorpion; wind protection; cinnabar; distant will; ginger-prepared; white atractylodes; aloe; and Yanhusuo, each one coin; thirty sheets of gold and silver foil. Grind into a powder, add musk, form into pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill mixed with sweet flag and perilla soup.

Star cinnabar powder is used to calm convulsions and relieve phlegm.

One tael of Nanchang wrapped in damp paper, roasted; one coin of cinnabar. Grind into a powder, use pig heart's blood to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill mixed with wind protection soup.

Tooth-opening powder:

One coin each of xixin, Nanchang star, and (stone salt) nitre; half a coin of musk; seven scorpion tails. Grind into a powder, use a small amount with ume fruit flesh to rub and clean teeth. Also use xixin, soapberry, and schizonepeta, blow into the nose, used for treating various wind syndromes and convulsions.[262p]
Qinglong Pill: Cures shock accumulated with heat.
Ingredients:

  • Qingtai
  • Fuling
  • Aloe vera
  • South star (pounded), each one qian
  • Qingfen
  • Musk
  • Bashuang, each one character
  • Whole scorpion (roasted), three qian

First, grind the Ba dou until it is like mud, then add all the other ingredients and grind them very finely. Form into pills the size of a wutong seed, coat with vermilion. Take one pill with mint tea.

Treasure Pill: Cures various seizures, sudden shock, heat in the heart leading to insomnia, agitation, wind phlegm convulsions, as well as feverish delirium, heat-induced vomiting, etc.

Ingredients:

  • Half a liang of benzoin powder (strained with wine to remove sand)
  • One liang of raw rhinoceros horn flakes
  • One liang of raw tortoiseshell flakes
  • One liang of true amber ground superfine then dispersed in water
  • One liang of finely ground realgar
  • Fifty sheets of gold leaf, half for coating
  • Fifty sheets of silver leaf
  • Finely ground fragment of powder
  • One qian of musk, ground finely
  • Half a liang of cow bile, ground

Combine the raw rhinoceros and tortoiseshell flakes to make a fine powder, mix with all other medications until uniform. Slowly simmer the benzoin paste in a double boiler, mix to form a paste. If it becomes dry, add a bit of heated honey. Store in a ceramic container, roll into pills the size of an apricot seed. For a two-year-old, give two pills with ginseng tea. Adjust quantity for adults based on necessity.

Also, it treats adults who suddenly cannot speak, suffer from toxic exposure, or heat-damp wind. For postpartum blood fainting, or if the fetus does not descend, use one cup of a child’s urine with three to five drops of natural ginger juice, warm gently, and take five pills for immediate effect.[263p]
Mystical Life-Taking Pill
Take the worm from the summer mugwort's stem in July,
Add to it realgar and musk to form pills, and include a small amount of brain matter.

Wind-Dispersing Red Powder
Treats children’s initial fright.
Use equal parts of raw Rehmannia, Muxiang (wood fragrance), Fangfeng (siler), and raw Licorice. Grind finely and take three qian each time, brew with a cup of water and a small amount of bamboo leaves. If there’s heat, add Scutellaria (Huangqin), red Peony root (Chishao), and Qianghuo.

Cicada Slough and Vine Drink
Treats abdominal pain and fear-induced crying.
Use two qian each of Vine (Diao Teng), Tianma (Gastrodia), Poria, Chuanxiong, and white Peony root; add one qian each of raw Licorice and Cicada slough. Grind finely and brew with lightsweet heart. One recipe adds Muxiang, Ophiopogon (Maimendong), Fangfeng, and Qianghuo.

Cooling Heat Drink
Use 2.5 qian each of Gypsum, Scutellaria, raw Licorice, red Peony root, and Kudzu root; add half a liang each of Ephedra and Bupleurum. Grind finely and for a three-year-old, take two qian each time with a small cup of water, a little ginger, and three inches of scallion white with a pinch of fermented soybean.

Seven Treasures Heart-Cleansing Powder
Treats children’s anxiety, heat-induced sores, and also convulsions.
Use equal parts of raw Rehmannia, Willoweed, Fangfeng, raw Licorice, Scutellaria, Qianghuo, and red Peony root; grind into a fine powder, reduce the amount of realgar by half, add Angelica root for effectiveness. Take one qian with a drink of light sweet heart and mint soup before meals on an empty stomach.[264p]
Anshen Pill
Ginseng, Poria, Ophiopogon, and Chinese yam, each 6 grams; dragon brain and dragon tooth, each 3 grams; cold water stone, raw licorice, and cinnabar, each 2.5 grams; two pieces of gold foil. Grind the above into a powder, combine with honey to form pills the size of lotus seeds. Take one pill each time, mixed with lampwick decoction.

Diaoteng Paste
Treats extreme abdominal pain in children, causing dry crying afterwards, referred to as "the hook inside the intestines." Frankincense, myrrh, and wood incense, all ground separately, and turmeric, each 3 grams; three seeds of wood bitter (remove oil). Grind the above into a powder, form honey pills the size of lotus seeds, and take half a pill ground in Diaoteng decoction, mixed with honey. First use this medicine to settle the pain, then take Weixiang Powder.

Weixiang Powder
Five grams of gentian, two grams of asafetida. First, dissolve the asafetida in warm wine and soak the gentian for one night, then dry and grind into a powder. Mix with perilla seed drink to take.

Diaoteng Decoction
Treats children’s night cries caused by cold internal organs. When yin is strong at night, it becomes cold and restless, leading to agitation, and excess cold causes pain, hence the night crying doesn’t cease. Diaoteng Decoction is the primary treatment. Each ingredient: Diaoteng hook, poria, white poria, Chuanxiong, angelica, wood incense, raw licorice, and white peony root, each 3 grams. Grind the above into a powder, take 3 grams each time, brewed with ginger and jujube. If there’s agitation from internal heat causing loud crying, there must be evidence of flushed face, white tongue, and reddish, turbid urine. In this case, remove wood incense from Diaoteng Decoction and add 3 grams of ground cinnabar. Take 3 grams each time, mixing with mutong decoction, or it can be taken as a powder. For treating startled crying, add cicada slough, windbreak herb, and gastrodia.[265p]
Baoming Pill - Treats children's internal fright from fetal shocks, tight and hard abdomen, restless sleep, frequent night crying, and remedies for sudden fright and chronic wind ailments, where the eyes look upward, hands and feet convulse, and the person becomes unresponsive. This is prescribed for cold syndromes.

Ingredients:

  • Ten pieces of gold leaf

Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung nut, with forty pills made from every two taels of mixture, regularly take to calm the heart, settle the spirit, and dissolve phlegm. It alleviates all forms of fright and wind syndromes; the decoction can be substituted as needed.

One formula adds two qian of ginseng and Bai Fu Ling. Another formula adds two qian of amber. For heat syndromes, add Niu Huang (Bovine bile), Pian Nao (Ground brain), and borax.

Xiao Xu Ming Decoction: Treats stroke with loss of consciousness, drooling, stiffness, loss of voice, cold extremities.
Ingredients: Ephedra, ginseng, 黄芩 (Huang Qin), chuanxiong, white peony root, apricot kernel, twining passions vine, cinnamon, and raw licorice, each 250 grams; wind protector 37.5 grams; processed aconite 12.5 grams. Excluding aconite and apricot kernel, all are to be coarsely powdered. For each dose, take 90 grams, with three slices of ginger and one date, boiled together. If there is heat, exclude aconite and reduce cinnamon by half. It is said: all sudden rigidity belongs to wind. Therefore, this formula is collected and should not be used without wind syndrome.

Ren Shen Bai Du Powder: Treats colds, epidemics, wind dampness with symptoms like dizziness, pain in the limbs, increased chills and heat, tight neck, eye pain, common wind-induced dizziness and fatigue, phlegm and cold-related cough, nasal obstruction, and heavy voice.
Ingredients: Bupleurum, notopterygium, chuanxiong, stir-fried bitter orange peel, qianghuo, duhuo, poria, platycodon, ginseng each 390 grams; licorice 15 grams. Xiao Chai Hu Decoction treats febrile diseases with symptoms such as fever, aversion to wind, neck stiffness and urgency, fullness and pain in the chest and sides, vomiting and reverse Qi, thirst, alternation of cold and heat, yellowing of the body and face, difficulty in urination, constipation, or unresolved issues after menstruation, or persistent tidal fever without relief. It also addresses issues like pain and fever recurring after recovery, irregular menstruation, and fever resembling malaria.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng: 9 grams
  • Honey-fried Licorice: 9 grams
  • Huang Qin (Scutellaria baicalensis): 9 grams
  • Chai Hu (Bupleurum): 24 grams
  • Ban Xia (Pinellia ternata): 7.5 grams (prepared by soaking and drying seven times)

Preparation: Grind the above into a fine powder. Each dose is 6 grams, mixed with one cup of water, three slices of fresh ginger, and one date. Boil, strain, and take warm without regard for time.

Wang Kengtang states: Adding Mountain Zhi and Peony Root to Xiao Chai Hu Decoction results in the modified formula, known as Jia Wei Xiao Chai Hu. It treats wind-heat in the liver and gallbladder channels, alternation of cold and heat, afternoon fevers, tidal heat, lack of desire for food, bitter mouth and anger, deafness, cough, or pain in the sides and fullness in the chest, difficulty in urination, diarrhea with sour and bitter vomiting, or spasms in the limbs and twitching of the lips and eyes, all of which are also indications for its use.[268p]

Da Chaihu Decoction
Treats exogenous cold with symptoms persisting over ten days, with evil Qi stagnated internally, alternating chills and fever, constipation, abdominal fullness and pain, delirium, hardness in the heart area, poor appetite; or lack of bowel movement for five to six days with stabbing pain around the navel, and irritability at times; also for symptoms resembling malaria post-sweating, evening fevers, when pulse is strong due to excess in organs.
Ingredients:
Each 24 grams of Chai Hu (without the root), and Huang Qin and Chi Shao Yao; 4.5 grams of Ban Xia (washed and roasted); 1.5 grams of Zhi Shi (without the seeds and toasted).
Grind these, boil with ginger and jujube, make adjustments as needed. For more laxative effect, add 9 grams of Chuan Da Huang.

Shen Su Decoction (from "Zheng Zhi Zhun Sheng")
Relieves convulsive shock, heat phlegm convulsions, cough with reversed Qi, and disharmony in spleen and stomach.
Ingredients:
Each 22.5 grams of Ren Shen (without the root), Zi Su (with stem), Qian Hu (without root), Gan Ge, Ban Xia, and Chi Fu Ling; 15 grams of Zhi Ke, Chen Pi, and Jie Geng (chopped and roasted); 10 grams of Gan Cao.

Ren Shen Qiang Huo Powder treats sudden onset of fright, disperses wind pathogens, and clears wind-heat. It consists of Qiang Huo, Du Huo, Chai Hu, Chuan Xiong, Ren Shen, honey-fried Gan Cao, and Bai Fu Ling, each one liang; Qian Hu without the stalk, Jie Geng, Di Gu Pi, and Tian Ma soaked in alcohol and roasted, each half liang; one liang of Zhi Ke, fried with bran. The ingredients should be ground together, and for each dose, take one qian, with half a bowl of water, one slice of ginger, one leaf of mint, and half a jujube, boiled and consumed. It can also be taken when rashes or pox have not yet appeared. According to the "Zhi Zhi Fang," for each dose, mix with a decoction of Zi Su and mint. For urgent cases with spasms, remove the Jie (麻黄) and boil in soup. Alternatively, the Xingsheng Powder can be added with Jing Jie and Fang Feng to avoid immediate use of Nao and She Xiang. For stiff body due to stroke, add Ma Huang, Gan Ge, and Yi Yi Ren. For treating fright and fever, add Chan Tui.

Ding Chu San - For treating children's sudden convulsions.

One large centipede, soaked in wine; fried white kusso; qianghuo; ephedra; stir-fried silkworms (zhijiangcan); calcined dalmint of daizheshi (red earth) for seven times; nansheng; scorpion’s tail; and two qian each of Huang Jiang (turmeric) from Sichuan, one qian of cinnabar. Whole Scorpion Powder: Treats both sudden and gradual onset of fright and convulsions, remarkably effective. Methods for acute and chronic conditions are included for better preparation.
Preparation: 2-4 whole scorpions, wrapped in fresh mint leaves and dried over a gentle fire; 0.5 liang of roasted silkworm, silk removed and roasted similarly, or dried mint leaves moistened with wine; 1 liang each of Nux vomica powder and ginger slices, mixed with 2 liang of fresh mint to form a paste; 3 qian of roasted white peony, 0.5 liang each of Fangfeng (with roots removed), Tianma, licorice (roasted), vermilion (water-floated), and Chuanxiong. Xie's Deadly Pill: Treats sudden shock leading to unconsciousness, with fixed eyes, clenched jaws, and pale or dark lips. Ingredients: 4 qian each of Noxious Star and Half Summer, powdered and mixed with ginger juice to make a cake, then dried; 2 qian of white pearl; 1 qian of purified oil-free castor bean; 4 qian of cinnabar; 10 pieces each of gold and silver foil; 0.5 qian each of white lead powder and musk. Bi Jin Pill: Treats childhood wind heat toxin and sudden loss of voice or shock. In the previous Deadly Pill, reduce the amount of gold and silver foil, and add 3 qian of true safflower, formed into pills as described above.

True Pearl Tianma Pill treats excessive phlegm heat causing seizures and can effectively relieve abdominal pain and discomfort. Directly Pointing Tianma Pill: Benefits against fright and facilitates phlegm, settles cramps, and calms the stomach and mouth, can be used broadly. Grind into a powder, make into small pills, and for each pill take with mint and fresh ginger-infused soup. Bai Jie San
This formula resolves hundreds of ailments, especially suitable for dispelling wind-heat and excessive yin conditions.
Ingredients: 2 liang of dried kudzu root, 2 liang each of bulbus acteae and red peony root, 1 liang of yellow qin herb, 7.5 qian of processed ephedra, 2.5 qian of cinnamon bark, and 1.5 qian of licorice.
Preparation: Grind the ingredients. For each dose, take 2 qian, add 1 cup of water, 2 slices of ginger, 1 green onion, and simmer down to 7 parts. Take warm at any time. If wind-heat is severe, add mint during simmering.

Mu Tong San
This formula addresses upper heat and closed lower orifices, resulting in irritability and anger, as well as dysuria and various skin conditions.
Ingredients: 0.5 liang each of peeled houttuynia and old root removed from earth flat plant, 3 qian each of rhubarb, licorice, and peeled red poria, 2.5 qian each of candu, talcum powder, gardenia seed, plantain seed, and yellow qin herb.
Preparation: Grind and pulverize the ingredients. For each dose, take 2 qian, add 1 cup of water and 3 stems of lamp wick, simmer down to 7 parts. Take warm at any time. Can also add mint while simmering.

San Jie San
This formula treats upper jiao heat and wind invasion, characterized by flushed face, red eyes, irritability, thirst, sudden crying, distress, oral sores, and phlegm cough.
Ingredients: 5 qian each of red peony and yellow qin herb, 15 whole scorpions (remove poisonous tip), 6 qian of powdered grass, 2 qian each of poria, bitter orange (without kernel), and stir-fried wheat bran, 2.5 qian each of saposhnikovia, gastrodia, rhubarb, curcuma, and white silkworm, as well as 2.5 qian of ginseng.
Preparation: Grind and roast into a powder. For each dose, take 0.5 to 1 qian and mix with mint tea or lamp wick tea at any time.[283p]

Banxia Pill
Effectively treats phlegm conditions. Particularly useful if phlegm and drooling arise after a fright or cramping, this medicine is very effective.

  • Raw Banxia: 2 taels
  • Red Poria: 1 tael
  • Zhi Ke (dried bitter orange): 1 tael
  • Wind-prepared Niter: 2.5 qian

The first three ingredients should be ground into powder, mixed with niter using a mortar, then made into pills the size of a mung bean using naturally extracted ginger juice boiled with glutinous rice flour. "Kuānqì Drink" is used to unblock and benefit the joints, alleviate chest congestion and phlegm retention, expel water, and enhance the consumption of nourishing food. It can also treat the accumulation of qi leading to convulsions, sudden or chronic fright, qi counterflow, and mental fatigue.

For its preparation, soak bitter orange peel (zhǐkē) and dry ginger, lightly roasted until slightly yellow; take equal amounts (one liang each) of the bitter orange fruit and ginseng, and half a liang each of roasted licorice. Grind these into a powder and take half to one qian with pure water at any time. For convulsions from fright, mix with ginger juice and scallion soup. If extremely heated, add in the "Kuān Rè Drink" and mint honey tea, or use ophiopogon soup.

"Wǔ Hé Soup" is aimed at dispelling accumulated heat in the internal organs and harmonizing the nutritive and defensive qi. To prepare, wash equal parts (half a liang each) of angelica root, red poria, roasted licorice, rhubarb, and soaked bitter orange peel, and lightly roasted until slightly yellow (each seven and a half qian). Grind the mixture, and take two qian with one cup of water, decocting to seven parts, taken warm at any time.

"Fúshén Soup" treats insufficient heart qi, causing anxiety and frequent crying, as well as helping underweight infants with much fright. It is suitable for both mother and child to take together. Use one liang of poria, half a liang each of ginseng and angelica (washed to remove tail), and two qian of roasted licorice. Grind the mixture, and take two qian with one cup of water, decocting to seven parts, taken warm at any time. If there is slight heat and restlessness, add ophiopogon and decoct together without the heart.[285p]
Zhenjing Pill
This is for both acute and chronic shock, wind-phlegm obstruction, spasms in the hands and feet, facial distortions, irritability and anger, and clouded spirit. Regular use calms the mind and settles shock, dispelling wind and easing qi.

Qingzhou White Pill: Treats childhood convulsions.

Ingredients:

  • Fresh Ban Xia (Pinellia): 7 liang
  • Fresh Nan Xing (Arisaema): 3 liang
  • Fresh Bai Fu Zi (Aconite): 2 liang
  • Fresh Chuan Wu (Aconite): 0.5 liang, skin and navel removed

Preparation: Grind the above ingredients into a powder, put into a silk bag, and immerse in well water. If not released, massage by hand; if there’s residue, grind again, then place in the silk bag for proper soaking. In a magnetic basin, sun-dry by day and expose to dew by night. Discard old water by morning and mix with well water, continuing to sun-dry until the next morning. Repeat this process: five days in spring, three days in summer, seven days in autumn, and ten days in winter. After water is removed, dry and grind to a fine powder like jade, mix with glutinous rice flour to prepare porridge, form pills the size of mung beans, and take three to five pills with mint tea at any time.[288p]

Ba Xian San: For those with a strong wind condition.

Nourishing Milk Recipe:
Ingredients:

  • Ginseng
  • Mu Xiang
  • Huo Xiang
  • Chen Xiang
  • Orange peel
  • Shenqu
  • Malt, all in equal parts.

Directions: Use half the amount of cloves. Grind the ingredients and take four qian per dose, with one bowl of water, ten slices of ginger, ten leaves of perilla, and three dates. Boil down to half a bowl. After the wet nurse eats, she must remove all the milk before taking it. Immediately lie on her back for a moment to let the medicine enter the milk channels, then let the baby suck a few times but do not let it become overly full; this is the correct method.

If vomiting persists for a day, it is urgent to dispel wind by taking Ba Xian San. Two days later, it is advisable to follow with Xiang Pi San. If none of the previous medicines work and there is danger, one must check the Tai Chong pulse to see if it is not completely closed and then should moxibustion on the Baihui point. The point is located at the midpoint between the hairline at the front and the tips of both ears.[290p]
The text states that it only mentions the top of the head with spiral hair, but does not explain the existence of double tops or irregular spirals. Many mediocre physicians, adhering to old texts, often mislead people. After moxibustion, one should control saliva using a powder made from Qingzhou white pills; after simmering it to a thin paste, mix in refined honey and a lethal powder, which will eventually help salivation. Finely grind spirit sand and mix it with rice drink to apply in the mouth, gradually observing the retreat of symptoms. If there's a strong wind, take Eight Immortals Powder; if feeling drowsy, use Wake the Spleen Powder. Regularly reducing mother’s milk and having the mother take fermented milk medicine, this form of regulation leads to recovery for everyone. However, if there is a deficiency in constitution or if the five elements are imbalanced, even skilled practitioners may not overpower destiny. If the saliva has already left the diaphragm and is stuck in the throat like a saw, medications cannot enter and cannot be controlled; alternative methods must be used to stimulate its release, alongside inducing sneezing through the nose, and then taking the lethal powder to avoid recurrence.[291p]
Phlegm-Lifting Formula
Seven pieces each of Chuanwu and Baifuxin, peeled and used fresh; seven scorpions; a small amount of stone green. Grind them into a powder, mix them uniformly. Use a chicken feather to dab the medicine and insert it into the throat, gradually withdrawing it while frequently using a cloth to wipe. This is a treatment method by the Tang family for chronic fright. First, use Duoming Powder and Ba Wanzi to control phlegm, wait for the phlegm to descend once, then use Baxian to awaken the spleen again, allowing the wet nurse to use the milk fermentation method. For critical cases, one should apply moxibustion to Baihui and the phlegm-lifting method, but for Duoming, use lunstone. For those with deficient qi, it's challenging to use; must be combined with Dongyuan's Yihuang Powder. Chen said: For treating chronic fright wind, first use Xiongxie Powder to manually expel cold phlegm and cold salivation, so that one won't be delirious; then take Youzhu Ointment; afterward, take Yizhen Decoction to warm and strengthen the original qi; occasionally take the previous Pusa Powder to relieve excess above and deficiency below.[292p]
Xuanguo San treats children’s brain and marrow affected by wind, releasing pressure from the skull, and alleviating tightness in the skin, flesh, tendons, and meridians. Symptoms include bluish veins along the cranial sutures, pale complexion, occasional abdominal gas sounds, intermittent greenish-white frothy stools, or vomiting of phlegm and saliva, leading to potential chronic convulsions, with cold feet and shins.

Ingredients:

  • Chuanxiong and Bibo each 1 tael
  • Banxia soaked in wine overnight, then rinsed and roasted
  • Xixin each 2 qian
  • Scorpion tail, detoxified, 1 qian

Grind the above into a fine powder. Use a copper coin's worth for a child, mixed with some boiling water to warm it, or use mint soup, and administer on an empty stomach. If phlegm fills the chest and throat, with the eyeballs cross-eyed, administer quickly. If the eyes are fixed and unresponsive, recovery is difficult. If phlegm and gas are obstructing and ingestion of medicine is impossible, use a finger to probe into the child's throat and soft palate to remove the phlegm, allowing for slight relief. Next, use the Bushi Yizhen Decoction, or select Oil Pearl Ointment. This formula has saved many lives throughout the ages.

Oil Pearl Ointment treats reversed gas and vomiting due to wind-phlegm causing convulsions.

Ingredients:

  • Stone pavilion fat and sulfur selected to be wax-like
  • Talcum powder each 0.5 tael
