　　玉液丸　治风壅，化痰利膈，清头目烦热，除咳嗽。　　寒水石煅水飞，二两　半夏制，一两　枯矾五钱　共为末，米糊丸如粟米大，姜汤下。感风寒咳嗽，桑白皮汤下；咳血，茅根汤下；常咳，茶汤下；咳而吐，煨姜汤下。
　　参苓白朮散 【万氏《幼科发挥》，下同】　　人参　白朮　白茯苓　山药各一两五钱　扁豆去壳，姜汁浸炒　甘草　桔梗　薏苡仁　莲肉各一两　为细末，枣汤送下。
　　辰砂膏　下小儿痰甚妙，治惊热惊积。　　辰砂研水飞，三钱　硼砂　马牙硝各钱半　元明粉二钱　全蝎去毒　珍珠研，各一钱　麝香一字　　右，另为末和匀，好油单纸包起，自然成膏，每用一粒许，月内调涂乳头令吮。狂躁恶叫。生地黄自然汁调下；诸惊，薄荷汤调下；胎惊，猪乳汁和枣汤下；潮热，生甘草汤下。
　　当归茱萸汤　治内钓。
　　当归　吴茱萸泡焙干　小茴香炒　甘草　木香　　右，水煎服。[240p]

Jade Liquid Pill: Treats wind obstruction, transforms phlegm and benefits the diaphragm, clears heat and restlessness from the head and eyes, alleviates coughing. Ingredients include: 2.5 taels of calcined cold water stone, 1 tael of prepared pinellia, 0.5 tael of dried alum, all ground into a powder. Form into pills the size of millet grains, take with ginger decoction. For cough caused by wind-cold, take with mulberry bark decoction; for coughing blood, take with reed root decoction; for persistent cough, take with tea decoction; for coughing with phlegm, take with simmered ginger decoction.

Ginseng and Poria Powder (from Wan's "Pediatric Elucidation"): 1.5 taels each of ginseng, white atractylodes, white poria, and Chinese yam; 1 tael of shelled cowpea, soaked and stir-fried in ginger juice; 1 tael each of licorice, balloon flower root, coix seed, and lotus flesh. Make into fine powder and take with jujube decoction.

Cinnabar Paste: Excellent for treating severe phlegm in children, as well as convulsions due to heat and accumulation. Grind 3 qian of cinnabar with water, 0.5 qian each of borax and horse's tooth nitrate, 2 qian of yimen powder, 1 qian each of detoxified scorpion and ground pearl, and a drop of musk. Mix well into powder, wrap in oil paper to make a paste. Use a small amount for breast feeding to encourage sucking. For mania and excessive crying, mix with fresh prepared rehmannia juice; for various convulsions, mix with mint decoction; for fetal convulsions, mix with pig’s milk and jujube decoction; for tidal heat, mix with fresh licorice decoction.

Angelica and Evodia Decoction: Treats internal conditions related to fishing down (a metaphor for internal issues). Ingredients are: angelica, dried evodia soaked and roasted, stir-fried fennel, licorice, and aromatic wood. Boil with water and take.[240p]

　　五福丸 【《本草纲目》】 　治小儿急惊。　　生蚯蚓一条，研烂，入五福化毒丹一丸，同研　以薄荷汤少许化下。《普济方》云：梁国材言，洋州进士李彦直家专货此药，一服千金，以糊十口。梁传其方，亲试屡验，不可不笔于册以救婴儿。
　　千金小惊丸　治小儿惊，大小便秘，钓气。　　金皂角水洗煮　黄连　牙硝　木香　胆草　藿香各五分　全蝎六个，去毒末之，面糊丸，用雄黄、朱砂、麝香、金箔为衣。镇惊，薄荷灯心汤下；大便秘，枳壳、大黄、(石卜)硝，煎汤化服；钓气，钓藤汤下。量儿大小用。
　　千金保命丹　治小儿一切痰喘，急慢惊风，撮口脐风，但能开口灌下，无不活者。　　牛黄　冰片　琥珀另研，各一钱　甘草二分　黄连姜汁炒　全蝎　姜蚕各三分　朱砂　明天麻面裹煨　胆星各四分　共为细末，磁罐蜡封，勿令出气，每五七厘，薄荷灯心金银煎汤，不拘时温服。[241p]

Wufu Pill [from "Bencao Gangmu"]
For treating acute fright in children. A live earthworm, crushed into paste, mixed with one Wufu Detox Pill and ground together, dissolved in a small amount of mint tea and administered. According to "Pujifang," Liang Guocai said that Li Yanzhi from Yangzhou specialized in this medicine, costing a thousand gold for a single dose, sufficient to treat ten children. This formula was passed down by Liang and personally tested multiple times, making it essential to record in books for the salvation of infants.

Qianjin Xiaojing Pill
For treating children's fright, constipation, and excessive gas. Wash and boil golden soap pod, Coptis chinensis, and prepare five fen each of myrrh, wood fragrance, gentian, and patchouli, along with six whole scorpions, removing their poison. Form into pills with realgar, vermilion, musk, and gold leaf as the coating. For calming fright: administer with mint and light heart decoction; for constipation: use bitter orange, rhubarb, and (stone salt), decoct and take; for gas: use vine tea. Adjust dosage according to the child's size.

Qianjin Baoming Pill
For treating all phlegm and wheezing in children, sudden or chronic convulsions, and umbilical wind—anything that can be administered orally is effective. Include one qian each of buffalo horn, borneol, and amber, two fen of licorice, stir-fried ginger juice of Coptis, and three fen each of whole scorpion and ginger silkworm; four fen each of vermilion and bright gastrodia covered and roasted. Grind into fine powder, seal in a magnetic jar with wax to prevent exposure. Administer five to seven qian, in mint light heart decoction, at any time, warm.[241p]

　　乳黄散　治小儿天钓，壮热翻眼，手足搐掣，皆因痰滞经络，头目反仰，名曰天钓。由乳母过食热物蕴毒，兼挟风邪所致。但解利风热，则应手而愈。　　滴乳一钱，另研　天竺黄一钱半　雌黄另研　腊茶　枯矾各一钱　炙甘草　荆芥穗炒　菉豆一百粒，半生半炒　赤脚蜈蚣一条，酒浸炙　细末之，每服半钱，煎人参薄荷汤调下。
　　全蝎散　治小儿天钓潮热。
　　钓藤　人参各半分　全蝎　天麻各一分　犀　甘草炙，各半分　末之，每服一钱半，水半锺，煎五分，温服。
　　久癎方 【《医贯》方】 　治小儿积癎。　　陈皮　黄连　白朮各五分　半夏　胆星　黄芩　枣仁　远志去心，各六分　白茯苓　麦冬各八分　甘草　枳实　柴胡　薄荷　干葛　元参各三分　　右，水二锺煎，加姜汁三匙，不拘时服。其南星制法：腊月八日取牛胆一个，将南星打碎，即以胆汁拌匀，复入胆内，扎口悬风处阴干。用水二锺煎，加姜汁三匙，不拘时服。[242p]

Milk Yellow Powder - Treats children's "Heavenly Catch" characterized by high fever, rolling eyes, and convulsions in limbs, all due to phlegm obstructing the meridians. The head tilts backward, termed "Heavenly Catch." This is caused by the wet nurse consuming too many hot foods accumulating toxins while being accompanied by wind evil. However, relieving the wind-heat will result in immediate recovery.

Ingredients:

  • 1 qian of milk
  • 1.5 qian of 天竺黄 (Tian Zhu Huang)
  • other prepared 黄 (Yellow)
  • 1 qian each of dried tea and dried alum
  • 1 qian of fried licorice
  • fried sage
  • 100 pieces of mixed beans (half raw, half fried)
  • a foot-long centipede, marinated in alcohol, roasted, and ground into fine powder.

Take half a qian each time, decoct in ginseng and peppermint soup.

Whole Scorpion Powder - Treats children's "Heavenly Catch" with tidal heat.

Ingredients:

  • 0.5 parts of fishing vine and ginseng
  • 1 part each of whole scorpion and tianma
  • 0.5 parts each of rhino and roasted licorice.

Grind into powder, take 1.5 qian with half a sheng of water, boil for 5 minutes, and consume warm.

Chronic Phlegm Formula (from "Medical Compendium") - Treats children's accumulation of phlegm.

Ingredients:

  • 0.5 parts each of dried tangerine peel, coptis, and white atractylodes
  • 0.6 parts each of pinellia, gall bladder, and scutellaria
  • 0.6 parts each of jujube seed and zhu-yuan (dandelion) without heart
  • 0.8 parts each of white poria and ophiopogon
  • 0.3 parts each of licorice, bitter orange, bupleurum, peppermint, dried kudzu, and prunella.

Decoct with 2 sheng of water, adding 3 spoonfuls of ginger juice, and can be consumed at any time.

Preparation Method for South Star: On the 8th day of the lunar month, take one ox gall, smash the South Star, mix with the gall juice, reinsert into the gall, seal, and dry in a shady place. Use 2 sheng of water to decoct, adding 3 spoonfuls of ginger juice, and can be consumed at any time.[242p]

　　拟定治惊癎诸方 【《明医杂着》，下同】 　治小儿肝经火旺，目睛频动，痰气上升，或壮热惊搐，面色红，脉有力，脾胃无伤，宜泻肝火。　　当归　柴胡　橘红　枳壳炒　天麻各六分　白茯苓　川芎　白芍药炒，各八分　甘草　黄连酒炒，各四分　薄荷三分　　右，每服二钱，姜水煎服。薛己曰：愚按前证，若肝经风热而自病，宜用本方。若肝经血燥而自病，宜用六味丸。若肝木克脾土，宜用四君子汤加升麻、柴胡。若肺金克肝木，宜用泻白散。若肾水不能生肝木，宜用六味丸。若愈后惊悸不寐，或寐中发搐咬牙，宜用归脾汤加茯苓、五味。盖有余者，邪气实也；不足者，真气虚也。[243p]

Prescription for Treating Shock and Epilepsy
For treating children with excessive liver fire characterized by frequent eye movements, phlegm rising, potential severe heat leading to convulsions, red complexion, strong pulse, and no damage to spleen and stomach, it is advisable to drain liver fire.
Ingredients:

  • 6 grams of Angelica
  • 6 grams of Bupleurum
  • 6 grams of tangerine peel
  • 6 grams of stir-fried bitter orange
  • 6 grams of Gastrodia
  • 8 grams of white Poria
  • 8 grams of Chuanxiong
  • 8 grams of stir-fried white peony
  • 4 grams of licorice
  • 4 grams of stir-fried Coptis
  • 3 grams of mint
    Take 2 taels of the mixture, boiled with ginger water.
    Xu Ji states: If the symptoms arise from wind-heat in the liver channel, the above prescription is appropriate. If they arise from blood dryness in the liver channel, the Six-Ingredient Pill should be used. If the liver wood impairs the spleen earth, the Four Gentlemen Decoction with the addition of Cimicifuga and Bupleurum is indicated. If lung metal damages liver wood, use the Xie Bai Powder. If kidney water cannot nourish liver wood, the Six-Ingredient Pill is advised. Should the patient experience palpitations and insomnia after recovery, or exhibit convulsions and teeth grinding during sleep, Gui Pi Decoction supplemented with Poria and Schisandra should be applied. The excess indicates a strong pathogenic factor; the deficiency indicates a weakness in true qi.[243p]

凡病有余，当认为不足。经云：邪之所凑，其气必虚。　　又　治小儿脾经不足，土败木侮，目睛微动，四肢微搐，或潮热往来，脾胃有伤，饮食少进，或泄泻呕吐，面色黄脉无力，宜补脾胃。　　白朮一钱三分　黄芪蜜炙　川芎　当归酒洗　陈皮　人参　肉蔻煨　神曲　干葛各五分　白芍一钱，酒炒　黄连　甘草炙，各四分　半夏　白茯苓各七分　　右，姜水煎服。薛己曰：愚按前证若因脾胃虚弱，用五味异功散补之；虚寒者加木香，或再加炮姜温之。若因脾气下陷，用补中益气汤举之；作渴者，用七味白朮散主之。若因脾胃虚弱，寒水侮土，用六君子加木香、炮姜温之。若因脾胃虚弱，肝木侮土，用补中益气汤加苓、芍、半夏调之。[244p]

For any illness characterized by excess, one should consider it as deficiency. The classics say: "Where evil gathers, the vital energy must be weak."

Furthermore, to treat children with deficiencies in the spleen and stomach, where the Earth is defeated and the Wood dominates, observe if the eyes are slightly moving, the limbs are slightly twitching, or if there are alternating fevers. This indicates injury to the spleen and stomach, with diminished appetite, and possibly diarrhea or vomiting, pale complexion, weak pulse; thus, it is necessary to tonify the spleen and stomach.

The prescription includes:

  • 1.3 grams of Atractylodes
  • Honey-fried Astragalus
  • 5 grams of Chuan Xiong
  • Wine-washed Angelica
  • 5 grams of dried Tangerine Peel
  • 5 grams of Ginseng
  • 5 grams of roasted Nutmeg
  • 5 grams of Massa Fermentata
  • 7 grams of dried Kudzu Root
  • 1 gram of White Peony, stir-fried in wine
  • 4 grams of Coptis
  • 4 grams of Licorice
  • 7 grams of Pinellia
  • 7 grams of White Poria

These are to be decocted in ginger water for consumption. Xue Ji states: In my humble opinion, if the condition arises from spleen and stomach weakness, it should be supplemented with the Five Flavor Decoction. If there is cold deficiency, add Wood Fragrance, or further add roasted Ginger to warm it. If it is due to the descent of spleen qi, use the Middle-Established Energy-Boosting Decoction. For thirst, use the Seven Flavor Atractylodes Powder. If it is due to spleen and stomach weakness with cold water dominating the Earth, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction, adding Wood Fragrance and roasted Ginger to warm it. If it arises from spleen and stomach weakness with Liver Wood oppressing the Earth, use the Middle-Established Energy-Boosting Decoction plus Poria, Peony, and Pinellia to adjust.[244p]

若因肝木太过，脾土受制，用小柴胡汤加炒山栀平之。若因伤鱼肉等物，用六君子汤，更加山楂、砂仁消之。若因伤生冷腹痛，或泻利清白，宜六君子汤加砂仁、木香、炮姜温之。若因伤辛热，停滞呕吐酸水，或大便清利不快，用六君子汤加黄连、吴茱萸、木香和之。若因积去而泄泻不止，用四君子汤加肉豆蔻、补骨脂、木香、煨姜以补脾肾。若泄泻止而饮食少思，宜用白朮散以补脾胃。　　又　治小儿心血虚，睡中惊动不安，或受惊吓而作，主清心安神降痰。　　人参　半夏汤泡　酸枣仁炒　茯神各一钱　当归酒洗　橘红　赤芍各七分　五味五粒，杵　炙草三分　　右，水煎，入姜汁竹沥少许。入牛黄半分尤妙。[245p]

If the liver wood is excessive, leading to restriction of the spleen earth, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with roasted gardenia. If due to injury from fish and meat, use Six Gentlemen Decoction, adding hawthorn and cardamom to dispel it. If caused by injury from cold leading to abdominal pain or clear diarrhea, Six Gentlemen Decoction should be used with cardamom, costus, and roasted ginger to warm it. If caused by an injury from pungent heat, resulting in stagnant vomiting of sour fluids or loose stools, use Six Gentlemen Decoction with Huang Lian, Wu Zhu Yu, and costus to harmonize it. If accumulation leads to persistent diarrhea, use Four Gentlemen Decoction with nutmeg, cheesy fruit, costus, and ginger to nourish the spleen and kidneys. If diarrhea stops but appetite diminishes, use Baizhu Powder to strengthen the spleen and stomach.

Additionally, to treat children with heart and blood deficiency, causing insomnia and fright, focus on clearing the heart, calming the spirit, and resolving phlegm. Ingredients include: one qian each of ginseng, pinellia, and fried sour jujube seeds; seven fen each of angelica wine-washed, citrus peel, and red peony; five grains of five-flavored fruit; three fen of roasted licorice. Prepare with water, adding a little ginger juice and bamboo juice. A half-fen of ox gall can enhance the effectiveness.[245p]

若温暖月，心经多热，加生地黄、山栀仁各五分，麦门冬七分，淡竹叶。若方饮食因惊而停滞者，须先消饮食，然后冶惊，惊药内仍加白朮、麦芽以理脾胃。盖惊则气散，宜收补其气；惊则痰聚，宜消化其痰。薛己曰：愚按前证，若心血不足，而心神惊悸者，宜用本方。若木火太过而心神不宁者，宜用导赤散。若木火翕合，风热相搏而病者，用柴胡栀子散。若肝心虚弱，木火未济而病者，用六味丸。若因脾胃食郁生痰，惊动不安者，宜用四君子汤以健脾，神曲、半夏、麦芽以化痰，山栀、芍药以清热。若因饮食停滞，肚腹膨胀，或呕吐泄泻，宜用六君子汤以健脾，用厚朴、神曲以消食。如有痰搐惊证，仍用本方调治。如见肝经之证，加钓藤钩，方内赤芍药易以白芍药。[246p]

If experiencing a warm heart with excessive heat in the heart, add five parts of raw Rehmannia and gardenia fruit, seven parts of Ophiopogon, and bamboo leaves. If the condition of food stagnation due to fright occurs, it is necessary to first resolve the food stagnation and then address the fright. Add white atractylodes and malt to the fright remedy to regulate the spleen and stomach. When fright disperses qi, it is essential to gather and replenish the qi; when fright causes phlegm aggregation, it is necessary to resolve the phlegm. Xue Ji stated: In cases with insufficient heart blood and heart spirit agitation, this formula should be used. If excessive wood and fire disturb the heart spirit, use the Dao Chi San. If wood and fire combine with wind-heat causing illness, use Chai Hu Zhi Zi San. If the liver and heart are weak, with wood and fire unresolved leading to illness, use the Liu Wei Wan. If phlegm arises from stagnated spleen and stomach due to food, causing agitation, use the Si Jun Zi Tang to strengthen the spleen, along with Shen Qu, Ban Xia, and malt to transform phlegm, and add gardenia and peony to clear heat. If food stagnation leads to abdominal bloating, vomiting, or diarrhea, use the Liu Jun Zi Tang to strengthen the spleen, adding hou po and shen qu to aid digestion. If there's phlegm causing fright, continue using the original formula for treatment. If symptoms of the liver channel are present, add vine hook and replace red peony with white peony in the formula.[246p]

　　安神镇惊丸　惊退后调理，安心神养血，和平预防之剂。　　天竺黄另研　人参　茯神　南星姜制，各五钱　酸枣仁炒　麦门冬　当归酒洗　生地黄酒洗　赤芍药炒，各三钱　薄荷　木通　黄连姜汁炒　山栀炒　辰砂　牛黄俱另研　龙骨煅，各二钱　青黛一钱，另研　　右为末，蜜丸菉豆大，淡姜汤送下，每服三五丸。薛己曰：愚按前方根本之治，防微杜渐之法也。但内多苦寒辛散分利之味，病后不宜轻用，恐复伤胃气而变生他证也。若饮食停滞而见他证，当消导为主。若脾胃损伤而见他证，当健中气。大凡病后元气未复，或因克伐之剂，元气复伤而见前证，但用升补阳气为主，诸证自愈，若专攻其病则误矣。[247p]

Anshen Zhenjing Pill is a remedy for calming the spirit, nourishing the blood after shock, and preventing future disturbances. The ingredients include:

  • Tianzhu Huang
  • Ren Shen
  • Fu Shen
  • Nan Xing prepared with ginger, each five qian
  • Fried Suan Zao Ren
  • Mai Men Dong
  • Dang Gui washed with wine
  • Sheng Di Huang washed with wine
  • Fried Chi Shao Yao, each three qian
  • Bo He
  • Mu Tong
  • Huang Lian fried with ginger juice
  • Fried Shan Zhi
  • Chen Sha
  • Niu Huang, ground separately
  • Long Gu, calcined, each two qian
  • QIng Dai, one qian, ground separately.

This mixture is ground into a powder and made into pills the size of soybeans, to be taken with light ginger tea, three to five pills each time.

Xue Ji states: In my humble opinion, this formula fundamentally aims at treatment and prevention. However, it contains many bitter, cold, and acrid ingredients which may be harmful if used lightly after illness, as they could damage the stomach's energy and lead to other ailments. If there are symptoms arising from food stagnation, the main focus should be on elimination. If there are symptoms due to damage to the spleen and stomach, the emphasis should be on strengthening the middle energy. Generally speaking, if the vital energy has not yet recovered after illness, or if it has been further harmed by purging remedies, the focus should be on promoting and replenishing the yang energy, allowing symptoms to self-resolve, as targeting the illness directly may lead to errors.[247p]

　　地黄丸 【《婴童百问》，下同】 　王肯堂曰：治小儿肝经虚热血燥，或风客淫气而患瘰疬结核，或四肢发搐，眼目抽动，痰涎上涌。又治肾疳脑热肢体消瘦，手足如冰，寒热往来，滑泄肚胀，口臭干渴，齿龈溃烂，爪黑面黧，或遍身两耳生疮，或耳内出水，或发热自汗盗汗便血诸血失音等证，其功不能尽述。　　熟地黄　山茱萸　干山药各四钱　泽泻　牡丹皮　白茯苓去皮各三钱　　右为末，炼蜜丸如桐子大，空心，温水化下三十丸。王肯堂曰：八味地黄丸，即六味地黄丸加附子、肉桂各一两。治禀赋命门火衰，不能生土，以致脾土虚寒，或饮食少思，或食而不化，脐腹疼痛，夜多漩溺等证。经云：益火之原以消阴翳，盖谓此也。或乳母命门火衰，儿饮其乳致前证者，子母并服之。又曰：加减八味丸，即地黄丸加肉桂一两、五味子四两。治禀赋肾阴不足，或吐泻久病，津液亏损，口干作渴，或口舌生疮，两足发热，或痰气上涌，或手足厥冷等证。[248p]

Di Huang Wan

Wang Kentang said: It treats children's liver channel deficiency and internal heat, blood dryness, or conditions caused by wind and dampness, resulting in scrofula or tuberculosis, twitching of limbs, eye spasms, and phlegm rising. It also addresses kidney deficiency symptoms like brain heat, body emaciation, cold hands and feet, alternation of cold and heat, diarrhea, abdominal distension, bad breath, dry thirst, gum sores, dark nails, and facial pallor. This may also include sores on the body and ears, ear discharge, fever, spontaneous sweating, night sweats, blood in stools, and loss of voice, among other symptoms, which cannot all be described.

Ingredients:

  • Prepared Rehmannia: 4 qian
  • Cornelian Cherry: 4 qian
  • Dried Chinese Yam: 4 qian
  • Alisma: 3 qian
  • Peony Root: 3 qian
  • White Poria (peeled): 3 qian

Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, hollow inside, and take with warm water, thirty pills. Wang Kentang states that Bawei Di Huang Wan is the Six Flavor Rehmannia Pill with the addition of 1 liang each of Aconite and Cinnamon. It treats deficiency of the fire of the life gate from congenital constitution, which cannot generate earth, leading to spleen deficiency and cold. Symptoms include lack of appetite, poor digestion, abdominal pain, and frequent urination at night. The classics say: "Nourishing the original fire to dispel the shadows of yin," referring to this. If a nursing mother has weak fire in her life gate, and the child drinks her milk leading to the above symptoms, both mother and child should take this.

Furthermore, the augmented or reduced Bawei Wan, which consists of Di Huang Wan plus 1 liang of Cinnamon and 4 liang of Schisandra, treats congenital kidney yin deficiency, or prolonged illness from vomiting or diarrhea leading to fluid depletion, dry mouth and thirst, or sores on the mouth or tongue, warm feet, or rising phlegm and qi, or cold extremities, among other symptoms.[248p]

　　生半夏一钱　皂角半钱
　　右为末，用一豆许，用管子吹入鼻，立醒。

　　省风汤　治惊风口噤，筋脉挛急，抽掣疼痛，风盛痰实，旋晕僵仆，头目眩，胸膈烦满，恍惚不定，神志昏愦。　　天南星生用　防风去芦，各四两　生甘草　半夏半泔浸一宿　黄芩去粗皮，各一两　　右(口父)咀，每服二钱，生姜一片，煎去滓，不拘时服。

Sneeze Dispersal
For treating sudden fright and gradual fright, causing confusion and unconsciousness.
Take half a qian of Pinellia and half a qian of soap pod.
Grind the ingredients to a powder, use about one bean-sized amount, and blow it into the nose with a tube to immediately revive.

Open Sneeze Like a Sage Powder
One red centipede, split into two pieces, soaked overnight in scallion juice and then dried. One whole scorpion, also split into two pieces, distinguished as left and right, placed in two locations. Three qian each of peony bark and white poria, peeled.
Grind the ingredients to a powder. For the left eye flipping and left hand trembling, blow the left powder into the left nostril. For the right eye flipping and right hand trembling, blow the right powder into the right nostril. For both eyes and both hands, combine the actions.

Wind Elimination Decoction
For treating convulsive wind with locked jaws, tight sinews, acute pain, excessive wind and phlegm, causing dizziness and collapse, head and eyes spinning, chest and diaphragm feeling full, disoriented, and confused.
Use fresh tian nanxing, and four liang each of Fangfeng without its rush. Fresh licorice soaked half in water for a night, and one liang each of Huangqin with the coarse skin removed.
Mouth grind the ingredients, each dose two qian with a slice of fresh ginger, boiled and strained, to be taken at any time.

Pearl Pill
For treating sudden convulsions in children, with copious drooling and high fever with phlegm obstruction.
One qian each of white typhonium, talcum powder, and light powder; half a qian of the whole scorpion; fifteen bitter beans, oil removed.
Grind to powder, form into balls the size of small beans. Give one pill for three years old, two pills in total, to be taken with scallion broth.[249p]

Seven Treasure Heart Cleansing Powder
White atractylodes, stir-fried, one and a half qian. Honey-fried licorice, angelica, schizonepeta spike, ephedra, peony, rhubarb wrapped and stewed, removed the wrap and chopped, each six qian. Prepared prepared pseudoscore, raw land each four qian. A little mint. This is the powder; take one qian each time, with one cup of water, add a slice of fresh ginger, and decoct for consumption.

Heat Releasing Powder
Zhiqiao moistened with water, along with forty-nine kernels of croton, stir-fried and remove croton. One tael each of rhubarb and (stone-tested) saltpeter, half a tael of raw licorice. This is the powder; keep it in a bottle, take one word each time, mixed with mint soup for consumption.

Gastrodia and Notopterygium Pill
Treats children's convulsions with fever, difficult breathing, excessive sleep, fright, and convulsions in hands and feet, along with mental confusion. Gastrodia, notopterygium, ginseng, realgar, yellow arsenic, musk, and honey-fried licorice each one fen. Stir-fried scorpion and silkworm each half a tael, stir-fried. One character of cow bile. This is the powder, refine with honey into pills the size of tung seeds, take one pill each time, with mint soup for consumption. One formula contains gallbladder star, without musk.

Dragon Tooth Powder
Dragon tooth, cicada slough, climbing vine, notopterygium, poria, and ginseng in equal parts. This is the powder; take half a qian each time, with mint soup for consumption.[250p]

Fangfeng Tongsheng San

  • Ingredients:
    • White Atractylodes (Bai Zhu), Chuan Jiao Su (Jing Jie Sui), Gardenia fruit (Zhi Zi) - 2.5 qian each
    • Chuanxiong (Chuan Xiong), Angelica (Dang Gui), Mint (Bo He) - 0.5 liang each
    • Rhubarb (Mian Wen Da Huang), Peony (Shao Yao), Ephedra (Ma Huang), Fangfeng (Fang Feng) - 0.5 liang each
    • Forsythia (Lian Qiao), Glauber's salt (Mang Xiao) - 0.5 liang each
    • Gypsum (Xi Wen Shi Gao), Scutellaria (Huang Qin), Platycodon (Jie Geng) - 1 liang each
    • Talcum (Hua Shi) - 6 liang
    • Raw Licorice (Sheng Gan Cao) - 2 liang

Preparation: Grind together. Each dose: 2 qian, boiled with 1 cup of water and 2 slices of ginger until reduced to 7 parts. Strain and take.

Da Lian Qiao Tang

Indication: Treats skin rashes with intense heat, urinary obstruction, various sores and carbuncles, and umbilical convulsions.

  • Ingredients:
    • Forsythia (Lian Qiao), Reed (Qu Mai), Jing Jie, Akebia (Mu Tong), Red Peony (Chi Shao Yao), Angelica (Dang Gui), Fangfeng (Fang Feng), Bupleurum (Chai Hu), Talcum (Hua Shi), Cicada slough (Chan Tui), Fried Licorice (Gan Cao) - 1 qian each
    • Gardenia seed (Shan Zhi Ren), Scutellaria (Huang Qin) - 0.5 qian each

Preparation: Grind together. Each dose: 1 qian, add Purple Root (Zi Cao) for decoction; take warm. If heat is intense, increase rhubarb.

Hu Po San

Indication: Treats acute and chronic convulsions in children, drooling, stupor, eye rolling, abdominal pain from shock, mild suppression of measles, restless crying during sleep—immediate effect upon ingestion. For shock and seizures, continuous use eliminates the root cause of the illness.

  • Ingredients:
    • Cinnabar (Chen Sha) - 1.5 qian
    • Amber (Hu Po), Bovine gallstone (Niu Huang), Gastrodia (Tian Ma), Fried silkworm (Jiang Can), Scorpion (Quan Xie) - 1 qian each
    • White Atractylodes (Bai Fu Zi), Frankincense (Ru Xiang), Cicada slough (Chan Tui) - 1 qian each
    • Musk (She) - 0.5 qian
    • Calcined red ochre (Dai Zhe Shi) - 1 qian (processed with vinegar seven times)
    • One character of brain (Pian Nao), one character of gallstone (Dan Xing)

Preparation: Grind to a powder. For three-year-olds, administer 1 qian, mixed with peppermint tea. For chronic shocks, add 1 fen of Aconite (Fu Zi).[251p]

　　调气散　小儿慢惊之后，以此调之。　　木香　香附　人参　橘皮　藿香　炙草各一钱　　右，姜枣煎服。

　　桂枝汤　治太阳中风，阳浮而阴弱；阳浮者热自发，阴弱者汗自出；啬啬恶寒，翕翕发热，鼻鸣干呕者。　　桂枝去皮　勺药　生姜各一两半　生甘草一两　　右銼，每服三钱，枣二个，水一盏，煎八分服。须臾，啜粥一盏，以助药力。温覆，令一时许，通身热微汗出为佳。桂枝，自西北二方居人，四时行之，无不应验。江淮惟冬及春可行之。自春未及夏至已前桂枝证，可加知母、石膏各半两，或加升麻一分。若病人素虚寒者，正用古方。
　　葛根汤　治太阳病项强几几，恶风无汗，不恶寒，刚痉。　　葛根四两　麻黄三钱　桂一两　生甘草　芍药各二两　　右銼，每服五钱，水一盏半，生姜五片，枣二个，煎一盏服，取微汗。[252p]

Dissipating Qi: For children after a slow fright, use this to adjust them. Ingredients: each one qian of Mu Xiang, Xiang Fu, Ren Shen, Ju Pi, Huo Xiang, and Zhi Cao. Prepare by decocting with ginger and jujubes.

Cinnamon Twig Decoction: Treats Taiyang Wind syndrome, with yang floating and yin weak; yang floating means heat is self-releasing, yin weak means sweat is self-producing; characterized by aversion to cold, slight fever, and nasal congestion with dry vomiting. Ingredients: one and a half tael of peeled Gui Zhi, one and a half tael of Sheng Jiang, and one tael of Sheng Gan Cao. Grind the ingredients, and for each dose, take three qian with two jujubes and one cup of water, decoct until eight parts remain. Shortly thereafter, sip a bowl of congee to assist the medicinal effect. Keep warm and allow for slight sweating over time; slight sweating all over the body is optimal. Gui Zhi is effective in response throughout the year for people from the northwest. In the Jianghuai region, it should only be used in winter and spring. For symptoms of Gui Zhi from spring before summer solstice, half a tael each of Zhi Mu and Shi Gao can be added, or one fen of Sheng Ma can be included. If the patient has a history of deficiency and cold, use the ancient formula.

Kudzu Decoction: Treats Taiyang disease with neck stiffness, aversion to wind, no sweat, and no aversion to cold, presenting with rigidity. Ingredients: four tael of Ge Gen, three qian of Ma Huang, one tael of Gui, and two tael each of Sheng Gan Cao and Shao Yao. Grind the ingredients, and for each dose, take five qian with one and a half cups of water, five slices of Sheng Jiang, and two jujubes; decoct to one cup, and induce slight sweating.[252p]

Chrysanthemum and Scorpion Powder treats slow reactions to fright.

Take seven whole scorpions (remove the tails), one cicada sloughed off, two and a half qian of roasted herbs, and one southern star anise (but fried). Grind these into a powder; take half a qian each time, boiled in water. Another formula includes three slices of ginger and two dates.

The Divine Treasure Perfected Pill balances yin and yang, harmonizing hot and cold, regulating vomiting and diarrhea, and clearing phlegm and saliva. Mix equal parts of sulfur, nitre, and melted juice, with five-spice resin, green peel, aged peel, and stir-fried half summer, grinding them into a powder. Form into pills the size of millet, taking three pills each time with rice drink.

The Revival Pill is formulated to balance the two energies, adjusting yin and yang, seizing the harmonious energy of heaven and earth, possessing the ability to harmonize water and fire, replenishing deficiencies and supporting the weak—its wonders are hard to fully express. Grind nitre and sulfur into a fine powder, lightly roast with a willow stick while continuously stirring, allowing the yin energy to meld in, taking care not to overheat.

One tael each of transparent sulfur and primordial subtle stone; two taels each of five-spice resin, green peel, and aged peel; grind the resin and peels into a fine powder, then mix with the powdered primordial stone and previous powders, combining well with good vinegar to form pills the size of peas. Take thirty pills each time, washed down with porridge. For severe cases, take fifty pills; for children, three pills; and for newborns, one pill. For children with chronic fright or ongoing vomiting and diarrhea, turning into a weak convulsion, it is not actually fright but the stomach energy about to collapse; in this case, administer five pills.[253p]

Wang's Xingsheng Powder: Treats children with vomiting, diarrhea, and weak spleen due to internal deficiency leading to fright. Ingredients: Ginseng, Poria, Mu Xiang (Aucklandia), Tian Ma (Gastrodia), Bai Bian Dou (Lima Bean), stir-fried Chen Pi (Dried Tangerine Peel), roasted Quan Xie (Scorpion). Grind into powder. Dosage: half a qian each time, cooked with ginger and jujube. One variation excludes Chen Pi and uses Chen Mi (Cooked Rice).

Xing Pi Powder: Treats vomiting, diarrhea, and lack of appetite due to spleen constraint and phlegm causing fright and convulsions. Ingredients: Roasted Quan Xie (Scorpion) 0.5 qian, Bai Fu Zi (Prepared Suberectal Plant) 0.5 qian, roasted Tian Ma (Gastrodia), honey-fried Licorice, Ginseng, Bai Fu Ling (White Poria), Shi Chang Pu (Acorus), Mu Xiang (Aucklandia), Shi Lian Rou (Lotus Seed) 0.5 qian each. Grind into powder. Dosage: three qian each time, with two slices of ginger, one jujube, and two small cups of water, decocted for drinking. For those with heat, exclude Mu Xiang and add Jiang Can (Silkworm) or add Nanshen (Southern Star, a herb), Ban Xia, Chen Pi, and stir-fried rice.

Da Xing Pi Powder: For those feeling confused and drowsy. Ingredients: South Star, Bai Fu Ling, Ju Hong (Tangerine Peel) 0.5 qian each, roasted Quan Xie (Scorpion), Ginseng, honey-fried Licorice, Bai Fu Zi (Prepared Suberectal Plant) 0.5 qian each, Shi Lian Zi (Lotus Seed), Mu Xiang (Aucklandia) 0.5 qian each, 200 grains of Chen Cang Mi (Cooked Rice). Grind into powder. Dosage: three qian each time, decocted with ginger and jujube. Both formulas can dispel wind and awaken the spleen. Should be used for infant feeding. When children's stomachs are weak and unable to digest milk or food, dietary moderation is essential.

Xing Xiang Powder: Treats chronic fright and convulsions, confusion, and phlegm. Ingredients: Cooked South Star 2 qian, Mu Xiang (Aucklandia), Ginseng, Ju Hong (Tangerine Peel) 1 qian each, roasted Quan Xie (Scorpion) 3 pieces, honey-fried Licorice 0.5 qian. Grind into powder. Dosage: one qian each time, mixed into strong decoction of Zi Su (Perilla), ginger, and jujube, taken with a spoon. For those with heat, add Fang Feng (Siler).[254p]

　　定命饮
　　半夏　茯苓　木香　生姜各一钱　白朮　甘草炙　天麻各五分　　右为末，每服半钱，姜枣煎汤调下。
　　四圣散　治慢惊，吹入鼻中。

　　天南星丸
　　天南星一斤，每一个重一两上下者，用温汤浸洗，刮去里外浮皮，酒浸一宿，用桑柴蒸，不住添汤，令釜满甑内气溢，更不住洒酒，常令药润，七复时满，取出用铜刀切开一个大者，嚼少许，不麻舌为熟，未即再炊，以熟为度，然后用铜刀切细焙干　麝香研　丁香　辰砂另研水飞，各一两　龙脑研，两半　　右为末，炼蜜并酒丸，朱砂为衣，姜汤下一豆许。[255p]

Decoction of Destiny
Ingredients: Banxia, Fuling, Muxiang, and Shengjiang each 1 qian; Baizhu and Gan Cao (roasted) each 5 fen; Tianma. Grind all into powder. Take 0.5 qian each dose, prepared with ginger and jujube decoction.

Sisheng Powder
Used for treating chronic fright, blown into the nose.
Ingredients: Seven whole scorpions, fourteen silkworms, 7.5 qian of Tian Nansheng, 2 qian of Chuanwu. Grind Tian Nansheng into a powder, mix with water to form cakes, wrap scorpions, silkworms, and Chuanwu, then wrap in wet paper, and simmer on low heat until reddish. Serve one piece each time, decoct in gold and silver soup, adding a little good tea to adjust.

Tian Nansheng Pill
One jin of Tian Nansheng, each piece weighing about 1 liang. Rinse in warm water and scrape off the outer and inner skin, soak in wine overnight, then steam with mulberry wood, continuously adding water until the pot is full and steam overflows. Sprinkle with wine regularly to keep the herbs moist; do this for seven cycles. Afterward, take out and cut a large piece with a bronze knife. Chew a bit; if it does not numb the tongue, it is done. If not, continue steaming until ready. Then, cut finely and dry.
Ingredients: Each 1 liang of ground musk, ground cloves, and ground cinnabar (water-floated separately); two halves of dragon brain. Grind all these into a powder, combine with honey and wine to make pills, coated with cinnabar, to be taken with ginger soup, about one bean-sized.[255p]

　　金液丹　治吐利日久，脾胃虚损，手足厥逆，精神昏睡，寒多露睛，口鼻气冷，欲成慢惊风者。　　舶上硫黄十两，先飞拣去砂石穪，研为细末，入罐内，再入赤石脂，封缝，盐泥固济，炭火煅三昼夜，取出候冷用　　右以柳木槌研为细末，每服二钱，生姜汤下。[256p]

Lingzhi Pill
Five parts of Lingzhi, one part each of roasted Bai Fuzi, Mu Xiang, and fried Zhi Jiangcan, half a qian each of roasted Quanxie (to remove poison) and damp Dannanxing wrapped in paper and cooked with fire, one qian of Zhu Sha. The above are ground into fine powder, boiled with rice vinegar, and formed into round pills about the size of sesame seeds. Take three pills with ginger tea.

Qizhen Pill
Treats stubborn phlegm and congestion.
Half a qian of Xi Xin, Chuan Lingzhi, one and a half qian of Zhi Jiangcan, one qian of Bai Fuzi, half a qian of Zhu Sha, and four roasted Quanxie. The above are ground into powder; make round pills about the size of sesame seeds with a paste of Dannanxing, and take five pills each time with ginger tea.

Si Junzi Decoction
Treats deficiency of the Defensive Qi and weakened organs.
Equal parts of Ren Shen (remove the skin), Fu Ling (remove the skin), Sheng Gan Cao, and Bai Zhu.

Chuan Wu San
Dispels wind and revives Yang.
One qian of raw Chuan Wu, and half a part each of Quanxie and Mu Xiang. The above are ground into powder; take three words with three slices of ginger, boil to obtain half, and then drop into the mouth. If there is vomiting, add cloves.

Jinye Dan
Treats chronic vomiting and diarrhea, spleen and stomach deficiency, cold extremities, spiritual lethargy, excessive coldness with watery eyes, and cold breath from the mouth and nose, wanting to become prone to chronic fright.
Ten taels of sulfur from the ship, first select and remove sand and rocks, grind into fine powder, place in a jar, add red stone fat, seal and stabilize with salt mud, and calcine with charcoal fire for three days and nights. Take out, wait for it to cool, and use. The above is ground into fine powder with a willow wood pestle; take two qian with raw ginger tea.[256p]

Sheng Fu Si Jun Zi Decoction helps to revive yang in the stomach. It is the original Si Jun Zi Decoction, adding one-fourth of powdered Fuzi for cold extremities. Take half a penny each time, decoct in water, and swallow with a spoon.

Scorpion and Fuzi Powder treats chronic spleen wind, revives yang energy, and clears phlegm. Use one whole scorpion, two qian of processed Fuzi, one qian each of processed Nansheng, Bai Fuzi, and Mu Xiang. Grind this into a powder. Every dose is half a penny, to be taken with three slices of ginger boiled in water.

White Silkworm Pill is prescribed for chronic spleen conditions with lingering yang. It can also stop wind. The ingredients are: two qian of Danxing, one qian each of fried Silkworm, Wulingzhi, dried Earthworm, and roasted Scorpion. Grind into a powder and use half a penny at a time, making pills the size of sesame seeds, to be taken with ginger soup.

Seven Treasures Wonderful Sand Pill is effective for phlegm and wind. For chronic fright and chronic spleen, cinnabar is the main ingredient, with Mu Xiang assisting. Use a specific type of ancient coin with moon segments on both sides, small and dark in color. Place one in an iron spoon, heat in charcoal until yellow and white particles emerge. Once cooled, pour into a bowl. This is one dose, taken with Namu Xiang Decoction, and ginseng soup is particularly effective.[257p]

Fangfeng Pill: Treats wind-heat phlegm accumulation and constipation.
Ingredients: Qiang Huo, Fang Feng, Zhi Shi, Chuan Xiong, Da Huang wrapped in wet paper and baked, and stir-fried Gan Cao, all at one and a half qian each. Grind together, take three characters worth per dose, decoct with ginger and jujube. An alternate recipe may add Chi Shao Yao.

Zhi Ke Powder: Treats abdominal distension and wheezing in children with malnutrition.
Ingredients: One liang of Zhi Ke, fried wheat bran, twenty-one grains of Ba Dou, fry until yellow and remove husks. Grind into powder, for a three-year-old child use half a qian, mixed with syrup made from sugar.

Aloe Powder: Treats convulsions due to excessive phlegm.
Ingredients: Five whole scorpions, roasted, one character of Ba Shuang, half a qian of light powder, one qian each of Aloe, Nan Xing (Arisaema), Zhu Sha (cinnabar), half a character each of Bing Pian (borneol) and She Xiang (musk), one fen of Yu Jin (curcuma zedoaria), and decanted with soap pod water, grind into powder. Take one character worth each dose and mix with decocted gold-silver mint soup.

Niu Huang Liang Ge Pill: Treats excessive heat with drooling.
Ingredients: Ya Shao, Han Shui Shi (cold water stone), phosphor gypsum, fresh Gan Cao, all at half a liang each, two and a half qian of Dan Xing, one qian of Zi Shi Ying (purple quartz), half a fen each of Niu Huang (cow urine), Pian Nao (bitter almond), and She Xiang. Grind into powder, form into pills the size of a mung bean, and take one pill each dose mixed with tangerine peel soup.

Qing Jin Dan: Releases wind and facilitates phlegm.
Ingredients: One qian each of Aloe, Ya Shao, and Qing Dai (Indigo), half a qian each of Shi Jun Zi (fruit of the quisqualis) and borax, half a qian of light powder, and fourteen scorpion tails. Grind into powder, form into pills the size of sesame seeds, and take one pill each dose mixed with mint soup.[258p]

Ban Xia Decoction
Five qian of Ban Xia, two and a half qian of Chen Pi, four qian of Bai Fu Ling, one and a half qian of Sheng Gan Cao. Grind these together. For each dose, take three qian, with three slices of ginger, and decoct for consumption.

Tian Ma Su He Xiang Pill
One fen each of Tian Ma, Fang Feng, Ren Shen, Chen Sha, Xiong Huang, She Xiang, and Zhi Gan Cao; half a liang each of Fried Quan Xie and Fried Jiang Can; a small amount of Niu Huang; one qian of Nan Xing; one cup of Su He oil. Grind these into powder, then mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill with mint decoction.

Shen Ling Bai Zhu Powder
Two qian each of Fried Bian Dou, Ren Shen, Fu Ling, and Fried Bai Zhu; two qian of Zhi Gan Cao; one qian each of Mi Ren, Suo Shan Ren, Bai Lian Rou, and Jie Geng; five fen each of Tian Ma and Huo Xiang. Grind these together. For each dose, take two qian with jujube decoction.

Zhen Xin Pill
One qian each of Zhu Sha, Long Chi, and Niu Huang; two qian each of Tie Fen, Hu Po, Ren Shen, Fu Ling, and Fang Feng; seven Fried Quan Xie. Grind these into powder, then mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill with mint decoction.

Xing Su Powder
For the treatment of various wind-related speech disorders.
Slightly roast and grind Tian Nan Xing; take one qian per dose. Use four slices of ginger and five leaves of Zi Su, decoct to take half, then add a small amount of male pig's gall bladder and take warm. For those who cannot speak, bowel movements need to be facilitated. For slow wind affecting speech, use only Nan Xing, with Ren Shen and Shi Chang Pu as assistants.[260p]

　　日应丹　治颠癎连年不瘥。[261p]

Wǔ Xiān Wán - Treats food epilepsy.
Prepared with half a tael of powdered cinnabar, two and a half qian of mercury, one tael of realgar, and one tael of pearl, finely ground into a powder. Form into pills the size of millet using honey. Take two pills with a decoction of gold and silver.

Bò Hé Sǎn
Half a tael of mint leaves, one and a half qian each of rhizome of notopterygium, scorpion, raw licorice, ephedra, fried silkworm without silk, muskroot, and white atractylodes. Grind into a powder and take with mint decoction. If there is extreme heat and wind, add a bit of bamboo juice to take. One variant includes bupleurum, rhizome of ligusticum, platycodon, and poria, excluding scorpion, silkworm, muskroot, and white atractylodes.

Yǎng Shēng Bì Yòng Shé Huáng Wán
One piece of snake gall, calcined and re-steeped, two qian each of pyrite, red lead, and realgar, and four qian of iron powder, ground very fine. Form into pills using honey, and for children over five years old, swallow with a decoction of gold and silver; for younger children, use smaller pills like millet size.

Sǎn Fēng Sǎn - Treats wind epilepsy, first use this.
One qian of bovine gall, one qian each of notopterygium, ligusticum, saposhnikovia, gastrodia, ginseng, schizonepeta, and chuanxiong. Grind into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung seed, and take two pills with a decoction of mint and perilla.

Rì Yìng Dān - Treats chronic epilepsy.[261p]

　　黑锡　硫黄　水银　铁粉研，各半两　金银箔三十片　　右水银、铁粉、金银箔夹和一处，先将黑锡于铫内熔开，次入硫黄，不住手就铫内碎搅，候硫黄烟气欲息，次入余药，就火上同搅，少顷时倾出地上一宿，出火毒，再研细，粳米饭丸麻子大，朱砂为衣，每服三丸，食后，人参汤下。
　　全蝎五癎丸　治小儿五癎。
　　赤蜈蚣一条，去头足酒浸炙　南星炮，二钱半　麝香一字　全蝎　防风　朱砂　远志姜制　白附　芦荟　延胡索各一钱　金银箔三十片　　右为末，入麝，糕糊丸桐子大，每服一丸，菖蒲紫苏汤调下。
　　星朱散　定癎利痰。
　　南星湿纸裹炮香熟，一两　朱砂一钱　　右为末，带性猪心血为丸，桐子大，每服一丸，防风汤调下。
　　开牙散
　　细辛　天南星　(石卜)硝各一钱　麝香五分　蝎梢七个　　右为末，以少许用乌梅肉揉和擦牙，兼用细辛、皂角、荆芥末，吹入鼻中，治诸风搐搦惊癎用此。[262p]

Black tin, sulfur, mercury, and iron powder, each half a tael; thirty sheets of gold and silver foil. Mix the mercury, iron powder, and gold and silver foil together. First, melt the black tin in a crucible, then add sulfur, stirring continuously until the sulfur fumes wane. Afterward, add the remaining ingredients and stir over heat. After a short while, pour it out on the ground overnight to release the toxic fumes. Grind it fine, forming pills the size of a millet grain, coat them with cinnabar. Take three pills after meals with ginseng soup.

Whole scorpion five-itch pills are used to treat children's five ailments.

One red centipede, remove the head and feet, soak in alcohol and roast; half an ounce of Nanchang star, one character of musk; one whole scorpion; wind protection; cinnabar; distant will; ginger-prepared; white atractylodes; aloe; and Yanhusuo, each one coin; thirty sheets of gold and silver foil. Grind into a powder, add musk, form into pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill mixed with sweet flag and perilla soup.

Star cinnabar powder is used to calm convulsions and relieve phlegm.

One tael of Nanchang wrapped in damp paper, roasted; one coin of cinnabar. Grind into a powder, use pig heart's blood to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take one pill mixed with wind protection soup.

Tooth-opening powder:

One coin each of xixin, Nanchang star, and (stone salt) nitre; half a coin of musk; seven scorpion tails. Grind into a powder, use a small amount with ume fruit flesh to rub and clean teeth. Also use xixin, soapberry, and schizonepeta, blow into the nose, used for treating various wind syndromes and convulsions.[262p]

　　青龙丸　治惊积有热。

　　至宝丹　治诸癎急惊，心热卒中客忤，不得眠睡，烦躁，风涎搐搦，及伤寒狂语，伏热呕吐，并宜治之。　　安息香两半末，以酒滤去沙，取一两，慢火熬成膏　生犀角屑　生玳瑁屑　真琥珀研细水飞　雄黄研细水飞，各一两　金箔五十片，半为衣　银箔五十片　片脑研　麝香各一钱，研细　牛黄半两，研　　右，生犀、玳瑁屑捣罗为细末，研入诸药令匀，将安息香膏以重汤煮化，和捣为剂，如干即入少熟蜜，盛磁器内，旋丸如桐子大，二岁儿服二丸，人参汤化下，大小以意加减。又治大人卒中不语，中恶气。中诸物毒，中热暗风，产后血晕，死胎不下，并用童子小便一合，生姜自然汁三五滴，同温过，化下五丸，立效。[263p]

Qinglong Pill: Cures shock accumulated with heat.
Ingredients:

  • Qingtai
  • Fuling
  • Aloe vera
  • South star (pounded), each one qian
  • Qingfen
  • Musk
  • Bashuang, each one character

First, grind the Ba dou until it is like mud, then add all the other ingredients and grind them very finely. Form into pills the size of a wutong seed, coat with vermilion. Take one pill with mint tea.

Treasure Pill: Cures various seizures, sudden shock, heat in the heart leading to insomnia, agitation, wind phlegm convulsions, as well as feverish delirium, heat-induced vomiting, etc.

Ingredients:

  • Half a liang of benzoin powder (strained with wine to remove sand)
  • One liang of raw rhinoceros horn flakes
  • One liang of raw tortoiseshell flakes
  • One liang of true amber ground superfine then dispersed in water
  • One liang of finely ground realgar
  • Fifty sheets of gold leaf, half for coating
  • Fifty sheets of silver leaf
  • Finely ground fragment of powder
  • One qian of musk, ground finely
  • Half a liang of cow bile, ground

Combine the raw rhinoceros and tortoiseshell flakes to make a fine powder, mix with all other medications until uniform. Slowly simmer the benzoin paste in a double boiler, mix to form a paste. If it becomes dry, add a bit of heated honey. Store in a ceramic container, roll into pills the size of an apricot seed. For a two-year-old, give two pills with ginseng tea. Adjust quantity for adults based on necessity.

Also, it treats adults who suddenly cannot speak, suffer from toxic exposure, or heat-damp wind. For postpartum blood fainting, or if the fetus does not descend, use one cup of a child’s urine with three to five drops of natural ginger juice, warm gently, and take five pills for immediate effect.[263p]

Mystical Life-Taking Pill
Take the worm from the summer mugwort's stem in July,
Add to it realgar and musk to form pills, and include a small amount of brain matter.

Wind-Dispersing Red Powder
Treats children’s initial fright.
Use equal parts of raw Rehmannia, Muxiang (wood fragrance), Fangfeng (siler), and raw Licorice. Grind finely and take three qian each time, brew with a cup of water and a small amount of bamboo leaves. If there’s heat, add Scutellaria (Huangqin), red Peony root (Chishao), and Qianghuo.

Cicada Slough and Vine Drink
Treats abdominal pain and fear-induced crying.
Use two qian each of Vine (Diao Teng), Tianma (Gastrodia), Poria, Chuanxiong, and white Peony root; add one qian each of raw Licorice and Cicada slough. Grind finely and brew with lightsweet heart. One recipe adds Muxiang, Ophiopogon (Maimendong), Fangfeng, and Qianghuo.

Cooling Heat Drink
Use 2.5 qian each of Gypsum, Scutellaria, raw Licorice, red Peony root, and Kudzu root; add half a liang each of Ephedra and Bupleurum. Grind finely and for a three-year-old, take two qian each time with a small cup of water, a little ginger, and three inches of scallion white with a pinch of fermented soybean.

Seven Treasures Heart-Cleansing Powder
Treats children’s anxiety, heat-induced sores, and also convulsions.
Use equal parts of raw Rehmannia, Willoweed, Fangfeng, raw Licorice, Scutellaria, Qianghuo, and red Peony root; grind into a fine powder, reduce the amount of realgar by half, add Angelica root for effectiveness. Take one qian with a drink of light sweet heart and mint soup before meals on an empty stomach.[264p]

Anshen Pill
Ginseng, Poria, Ophiopogon, and Chinese yam, each 6 grams; dragon brain and dragon tooth, each 3 grams; cold water stone, raw licorice, and cinnabar, each 2.5 grams; two pieces of gold foil. Grind the above into a powder, combine with honey to form pills the size of lotus seeds. Take one pill each time, mixed with lampwick decoction.

Diaoteng Paste
Treats extreme abdominal pain in children, causing dry crying afterwards, referred to as "the hook inside the intestines." Frankincense, myrrh, and wood incense, all ground separately, and turmeric, each 3 grams; three seeds of wood bitter (remove oil). Grind the above into a powder, form honey pills the size of lotus seeds, and take half a pill ground in Diaoteng decoction, mixed with honey. First use this medicine to settle the pain, then take Weixiang Powder.

Weixiang Powder
Five grams of gentian, two grams of asafetida. First, dissolve the asafetida in warm wine and soak the gentian for one night, then dry and grind into a powder. Mix with perilla seed drink to take.

Diaoteng Decoction
Treats children’s night cries caused by cold internal organs. When yin is strong at night, it becomes cold and restless, leading to agitation, and excess cold causes pain, hence the night crying doesn’t cease. Diaoteng Decoction is the primary treatment. Each ingredient: Diaoteng hook, poria, white poria, Chuanxiong, angelica, wood incense, raw licorice, and white peony root, each 3 grams. Grind the above into a powder, take 3 grams each time, brewed with ginger and jujube. If there’s agitation from internal heat causing loud crying, there must be evidence of flushed face, white tongue, and reddish, turbid urine. In this case, remove wood incense from Diaoteng Decoction and add 3 grams of ground cinnabar. Take 3 grams each time, mixing with mutong decoction, or it can be taken as a powder. For treating startled crying, add cicada slough, windbreak herb, and gastrodia.[265p]

Baoming Pill - Treats children's internal fright from fetal shocks, tight and hard abdomen, restless sleep, frequent night crying, and remedies for sudden fright and chronic wind ailments, where the eyes look upward, hands and feet convulse, and the person becomes unresponsive. This is prescribed for cold syndromes.

Ingredients:

  • Fourteen whole scorpions, detoxified
  • Fang Feng (Saposhnikovia)
  • Stir-fried silkworms with silk removed
  • Two qian of Tian Ma (Gastrodia)
  • Two qian of South Star (Zanthoxylum)
  • Bai Fu Zi (Typhonium)
  • Five fen of musk
  • Ten pieces of gold leaf
  • One qian each of Cicada slough and Cinnabar

Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a tung nut, with forty pills made from every two taels of mixture, regularly take to calm the heart, settle the spirit, and dissolve phlegm. It alleviates all forms of fright and wind syndromes; the decoction can be substituted as needed.

One formula adds two qian of ginseng and Bai Fu Ling. Another formula adds two qian of amber. For heat syndromes, add Niu Huang (Bovine bile), Pian Nao (Ground brain), and borax.

Xiao Xu Ming Decoction: Treats stroke with loss of consciousness, drooling, stiffness, loss of voice, cold extremities.
Ingredients: Ephedra, ginseng, 黄芩 (Huang Qin), chuanxiong, white peony root, apricot kernel, twining passions vine, cinnamon, and raw licorice, each 250 grams; wind protector 37.5 grams; processed aconite 12.5 grams. Excluding aconite and apricot kernel, all are to be coarsely powdered. For each dose, take 90 grams, with three slices of ginger and one date, boiled together. If there is heat, exclude aconite and reduce cinnamon by half. It is said: all sudden rigidity belongs to wind. Therefore, this formula is collected and should not be used without wind syndrome.

Gui Zhi Jia Ge Gen Decoction: Treats headaches with stiffness in neck and back, sweating, and aversion to wind.
Ingredients: Cinnamon twig, peony, raw licorice each 180 grams; kudzu root 390 grams. Coarsely grind, and for each dose, take 90 grams, with ginger and dates boiled together.

Ren Shen Bai Du Powder: Treats colds, epidemics, wind dampness with symptoms like dizziness, pain in the limbs, increased chills and heat, tight neck, eye pain, common wind-induced dizziness and fatigue, phlegm and cold-related cough, nasal obstruction, and heavy voice.
Ingredients: Bupleurum, notopterygium, chuanxiong, stir-fried bitter orange peel, qianghuo, duhuo, poria, platycodon, ginseng each 390 grams; licorice 15 grams. Grind coarsely, take 60 grams each dose with ginger and peppermint boiled. For one recipe, add earth bone bark and gastrodia. Alternatively, finely grind and add cicada slough and wind protector. For treating fever from fright, ginseng, dried kudzu, and Huang Qin may be added. If there is no sweating, add ephedra.[267p]

　　小柴胡汤　治伤寒温热病，身热恶风，颈项强急，胸胁满痛，呕吐哕逆，烦渴，寒热往来，身面皆黄，小便不利，大便秘濇，或过经不解，或潮热不除，及瘥后劳复发热，疼痛烦热，经血适来适断，寒热如疟。　　人参　甘草炙　黄芩各三钱　柴胡八钱　半夏汤泡七次焙干，二钱半　　右銼散，每服二钱，水一盏，生姜三片，枣一枚，煎去滓温服，不拘时。王肯堂曰：小柴胡汤加山栀牡丹皮，名加味小柴胡，治肝胆经风热瘰疬，寒热往来，日晡发热，潮热身热，不欲饮食，或怒火口苦，耳聋咳嗽，或胁痛胸满，小便不利，或泄泻吐酸苦水，或肢体搐动，唇目抽札，并宜用之。[268p]

Xiao Chai Hu Decoction treats febrile diseases with symptoms such as fever, aversion to wind, neck stiffness and urgency, fullness and pain in the chest and sides, vomiting and reverse Qi, thirst, alternation of cold and heat, yellowing of the body and face, difficulty in urination, constipation, or unresolved issues after menstruation, or persistent tidal fever without relief. It also addresses issues like pain and fever recurring after recovery, irregular menstruation, and fever resembling malaria.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng: 9 grams
  • Honey-fried Licorice: 9 grams
  • Huang Qin (Scutellaria baicalensis): 9 grams
  • Chai Hu (Bupleurum): 24 grams
  • Ban Xia (Pinellia ternata): 7.5 grams (prepared by soaking and drying seven times)

Preparation: Grind the above into a fine powder. Each dose is 6 grams, mixed with one cup of water, three slices of fresh ginger, and one date. Boil, strain, and take warm without regard for time.

Wang Kengtang states: Adding Mountain Zhi and Peony Root to Xiao Chai Hu Decoction results in the modified formula, known as Jia Wei Xiao Chai Hu. It treats wind-heat in the liver and gallbladder channels, alternation of cold and heat, afternoon fevers, tidal heat, lack of desire for food, bitter mouth and anger, deafness, cough, or pain in the sides and fullness in the chest, difficulty in urination, diarrhea with sour and bitter vomiting, or spasms in the limbs and twitching of the lips and eyes, all of which are also indications for its use.[268p]

Da Chengqi Decoction
Treats severe abdominal fullness, internal excess, clenched mouth and teeth, intense heat with thirst, and constipation.
Ingredients:
Each 15 grams of Da Huang and Mang Xiao; 30 grams of Hou Po and Zhi Shi.
Grind the ingredients, take 9 grams each time, add 3 slices of ginger, boil in 1 cup of water until reduced to half a cup, and take warm.

Da Chaihu Decoction
Treats exogenous cold with symptoms persisting over ten days, with evil Qi stagnated internally, alternating chills and fever, constipation, abdominal fullness and pain, delirium, hardness in the heart area, poor appetite; or lack of bowel movement for five to six days with stabbing pain around the navel, and irritability at times; also for symptoms resembling malaria post-sweating, evening fevers, when pulse is strong due to excess in organs.
Ingredients:
Each 24 grams of Chai Hu (without the root), and Huang Qin and Chi Shao Yao; 4.5 grams of Ban Xia (washed and roasted); 1.5 grams of Zhi Shi (without the seeds and toasted).
Grind these, boil with ginger and jujube, make adjustments as needed. For more laxative effect, add 9 grams of Chuan Da Huang.

For Pediatric Shock and Convulsions
Shen Su Decoction (from "Zheng Zhi Zhun Sheng")
Relieves convulsive shock, heat phlegm convulsions, cough with reversed Qi, and disharmony in spleen and stomach.
Ingredients:
Each 22.5 grams of Ren Shen (without the root), Zi Su (with stem), Qian Hu (without root), Gan Ge, Ban Xia, and Chi Fu Ling; 15 grams of Zhi Ke, Chen Pi, and Jie Geng (chopped and roasted); 10 grams of Gan Cao.
Grind these; take 6 grams each time, with 1 cup of water, 2 slices of ginger, simmer till reduced to 70%, and take warm at any time. From "Ling Fang," substitute Ren Shen with Chuan Xiong.[269p]

　　人参羌活散　治初作急惊，散风邪，除风热。　　羌活　独活　柴胡　川芎　人参　甘草炙　白茯苓各一两　前胡去芦　桔梗　地骨皮　天麻酒浸焙，各半两　枳壳一两，麸炒　　右(口父)咀，每服一钱，水半盏，姜一片，薄荷一叶、枣半个，煎服。疹痘未发亦可服。《直指方》每服三字末，紫苏薄荷汤调。搐掣紧急者，去节麻黄煎汤调。或惺惺散加荆芥、防风亦可，免得遽施脑、麝。或中风体硬，加麻黄、干葛、薏苡仁。加蝉蜕治惊热。

Ren Shen Qiang Huo Powder treats sudden onset of fright, disperses wind pathogens, and clears wind-heat. It consists of Qiang Huo, Du Huo, Chai Hu, Chuan Xiong, Ren Shen, honey-fried Gan Cao, and Bai Fu Ling, each one liang; Qian Hu without the stalk, Jie Geng, Di Gu Pi, and Tian Ma soaked in alcohol and roasted, each half liang; one liang of Zhi Ke, fried with bran. The ingredients should be ground together, and for each dose, take one qian, with half a bowl of water, one slice of ginger, one leaf of mint, and half a jujube, boiled and consumed. It can also be taken when rashes or pox have not yet appeared. According to the "Zhi Zhi Fang," for each dose, mix with a decoction of Zi Su and mint. For urgent cases with spasms, remove the Jie (麻黄) and boil in soup. Alternatively, the Xingsheng Powder can be added with Jing Jie and Fang Feng to avoid immediate use of Nao and She Xiang. For stiff body due to stroke, add Ma Huang, Gan Ge, and Yi Yi Ren. For treating fright and fever, add Chan Tui.

Xingsheng Powder clears wind-heat and is effective against febrile conditions caused by cold pathogens, as well as for rashes and fevers. It consists of equal parts Bai Fu Ling, Xi Xin, Jie Geng, Hua Fen, Ren Shen, honey-fried Gan Cao, and Bai Zhu. This is ground into a powder, and for each dose, take one qian, with half a bowl of water, one slice of ginger, and three leaves of mint, boiled together. For the Tang family, reduce the Xi Xin by half.[270p]

Du Huo Decoction treats fetal fright and disperses wind pathogens.

Ingredients:

  • Qiang Huo and Du Huo, each 1 part
  • Betel nut, Tian Ma, Ma Huang (removing joints), and sweetened licorice, each 0.5 parts.

Grind these together. Take half a coin worth, decoct in water. Add powdered Tian Nan Xing and honey for a topical application at the temple.

Mu Tong Powder treats heat in the liver and heart of children, alleviating fright. It clears liver wind, reduces heart fire, and relieves heat.

Ingredients:

  • Qiang Huo and Shan Zhi, each 2 qian
  • Prepared Da Huang, Mu Tong, Chi Fu Ling, and sweetened licorice, each 1 qian.

Grind into a fine powder. Take 2 qian, add a small amount of Zi Su, decoct in 1 cup of water until reduced by two parts, and can be taken at any time.

Ji Feng Dan expels wind and alleviates fright.

  • Tian Zhu Huang finely ground, Fang Feng, and Diaoteng, each 1 liang
  • Bai Jiang Can, Gan Quan Xie, and Bai Fu Zi, each 0.5 liang.

Grind into a fine powder, mix with honey to form small pills, each the size of a sorghum grain. Take 1 to 2 pills, mixed with musk and Jing Jie Decoction for consumption.

  • Fang Feng, Mai Dong, and sweetened licorice in the middle
  • Shan Zhi Zi and Bo He Ye below.

Ren Zhai Xi Jiao Decoction treats heart shock from excess heat.

Mr. Mao’s Deadly Powder: For treating wind affecting the navel, if a guest suddenly dies with a contorted mouth, wooden tongue, throat paralysis, mumps, wind obstructing phlegm, follow with evidence and regulation.

Use 2 grams each of copper green and cinnabar, 0.5 grams of greasy powder, musk ground separately, and 14 scorpion tails without needles. Grind into a powder; take 0.5 grams each time, washed down with peppermint wax tea.

San Yin Formula: For treating yang convulsions due to heat, with a red face, fever, and spasms, staring directly with tense jaws. Use 2 grams each of aloe, white cancer-fighting herb, and fresh licorice; 1 gram each of yellow huanglian and cinnabar; 0.5 grams each of greasy powder and musk; 7 scorpion tails, 7 fried silkworms; 7 pieces of gold leaf; 1 roasted red centipede. Grind into a powder; for children over 2 years, take 0.5 grams, washed down with gold leaf and peppermint soup.

Sleeping Red Powder: For treating children’s acute or chronic convulsions, with spasms of hands and feet, wide eyes, and confused spirit. Use 0.5 grams each of ox gallstone, borax, powdered brain, true pearl, and mercury sand; 1 gram each of indigo, fried scorpion tail, and dried star anise; 0.5 grams each of half summer ginger prepared overnight; and 1 gram of snake-flavored stone ground with one piece of gold and silver leaf. Use musk, one character, and a snake’s tail and neck of 7 inches, soaked in wine overnight, then remove skin and bones and roast, using 1 gram. Grind into a powder; for children over 3 years, take 1 character, washed down with peppermint soup. Note: This is for treating wind-heat phlegm and unblocking the channels and smoothing muscles and bones; it should not be lightly used unless there is no wind evil descending.[272p]

Ding Chu San - For treating children's sudden convulsions.

One large centipede, soaked in wine; fried white kusso; qianghuo; ephedra; stir-fried silkworms (zhijiangcan); calcined dalmint of daizheshi (red earth) for seven times; nansheng; scorpion’s tail; and two qian each of Huang Jiang (turmeric) from Sichuan, one qian of cinnabar. Grind these into a powder. For each dose, take one character (the amount of powder equal to one character), decoct it with a broth of jingjie and zisu. If the convulsions do not stop, add black snake meat.

Shun Chu San - For resolving convulsions that are not smooth for males on the right side and females on the left.

Half a liang of zhi cracked (bitter orange), diaoteng without hooks, jingjie, qianghuo, fangfeng without the reed, and licorice. Grind well. For each dose, take two qian, mix with one cup of water, slice ginger into two pieces, decoct until seven parts remain, and drink warm at any time, or simmer with mint.

Luo's Zhen Gan Wan - For treating children’s acute convulsions accompanied by upward gaze, twitching, confusion, and unresponsiveness; involving wind-heat in the liver channel. This formula resolves the transformation of the green.

Finely grind together tianzhuhuang, shengdihuang, danggui, zhuye, caolongdan, chuanchong, and dahuang (steamed) with qianghuo and fangfeng, each at two and a half qian. This creates a fine powder. Refine into pills the size of a chicken head. For each dose, take two pills, dissolving them in sweetened water. First take this, then take Tianma San.[273p]

Dingming Dan: For treating urgent cases of fright and phlegm-heat.

Shu Feng San: Treats fright and phlegm-heat when all four symptoms are prominent.

Ingredients:

  • Betel nut
  • Chenpi (dried tangerine peel), both without white, each 2 qian
  • Qianqiu (Knotweed)
  • Dahuang (Rhubarb), both pre-cooked, each 3 qian

Grind the above into powder, and take half a qian mixed with honey. Add Yanshan (Shi Bu) salt one qian. The "Baoying Fang" states that Dahuang, black Qianqiu, and white Qianqiu, each should be half raw and half cooked, using 2 qian of betel nut, ground into fine powder and mixed with honey soup. If phlegm is abundant, add light powder.

Jie Feng Dan: Treats when the four symptoms have developed but the eight indications are not yet complete.

Ingredients:

  • Jiao Chan (Silkworm), fried
  • Bai Fuzhi, precooked
  • Nanzhang, Tianma, each 2.5 qian
  • Zhusha 1 qian
  • Shexiang, one character
  • Red-footed centipede, one piece, prepared with wine

Grind the above into powder, form into pills the size of walnuts, and take three pills with a decoction of Jin Yin and Bohe. One recipe includes Fang Feng (Siler).

Ding Ju San: Treats sudden fright when all four symptoms and eight indications occur simultaneously.[274p]

Niu Huang Qing Xin Wan treats the four signs and eight conditions, dispelling wind phlegm and relieving fever. Heavenly southern star, banxia, white attached, and Sichuan wū each one liang, all washed; Sichuan yujin half a liang.

These five ingredients are to be coarsely powdered. Using two or three pieces of yellow ox bile from the twelfth month, extract the juice, mix it with the medicine, place it in the bile, and hang it in the wind for a month; then dry and add horse tooth salt, cinnabar, realgar, and borax, each one qian. A little brain and musk. If there's one liang of bile medicine, then salt and four ingredients are each one qian.

Make small pills as large as sesame seeds, take ten pills for one year old, and double it for two years old.

Taibai Powder: For urgent fright with excessive saliva.

Fangfeng Pill: Treats fright, phlegm-heat with symptoms of confusion and panic.
Ingredients: 1 liang each of Tianma, Fangfeng, Ginseng, and Chuanxiong; 2.5 qian each of whole scorpion, licorice, silkworm, vermilion, realgar, cow bile, and Nux vomica. Whole Scorpion Powder: Treats both sudden and gradual onset of fright and convulsions, remarkably effective. Methods for acute and chronic conditions are included for better preparation.
Preparation: 2-4 whole scorpions, wrapped in fresh mint leaves and dried over a gentle fire; 0.5 liang of roasted silkworm, silk removed and roasted similarly, or dried mint leaves moistened with wine; 1 liang each of Nux vomica powder and ginger slices, mixed with 2 liang of fresh mint to form a paste; 3 qian of roasted white peony, 0.5 liang each of Fangfeng (with roots removed), Tianma, licorice (roasted), vermilion (water-floated), and Chuanxiong. Grind and mix these.
Dosage: For one-year-olds, take a small amount; for two-year-olds, half a qian, adjusted according to age with mint tea. For convulsions with fever, use Huofu powder; for gradual onset with diarrhea, use ginger tea; for sudden convulsions, boil Huofu powder with rhubarb tea. If sudden fright, do not use Nux vomica, but add 1 liang of rhubarb. For gradual fright, omit rhubarb and use processed Nux vomica instead.[276p]

Fire Palace Powder: For symptoms of a flushed face, clenched teeth, heat, dry lips and mouth, and red, painful urination, it treats all forms of虚 (deficiencies) and邪热 (evil heat). Prepare by grinding, with a dose of 2 qian (a traditional unit of weight), boiled in water and taken warm at any time.

Tang's Gold Star Pill: Treats acute fright, intense heat phlegm blockage, and constipation. Ingredients: 2.5 qian each of Yujin (Curcuma) and Xiong Huang (realgar), 0.5 qian of greasy powder, and 7 pieces of Ba Dou (croton seed), ground after frost has formed. Form into pills the size of millet, to be taken with mint decoction, 2 pills for children under one year.

Little Black Dragon Pill: For treating mild acute fright in children.

Ingredients: 1 ounce of calcined Qinglongshi (blue stone), 1 qian of Qingdai (indigo), 1.5 qian of Aloe, and 1 ounce of Danxing (gallstone). Grind into a very fine powder, form into pills the size of a chicken's head, each to be taken with ginger honey and mint decoction. Both the Little and Big Black Dragon Pills use Qinglongshi and Danxing as the main ingredients to treat phlegm; they are suitable for those with excessive phlegm.[277p]

Xie's Deadly Pill: Treats sudden shock leading to unconsciousness, with fixed eyes, clenched jaws, and pale or dark lips. Yan Shan Qing Jin Pill: Treats convulsions from phlegm heat and symptoms of excess. Five Blessings Detox Pill treats frightful heat, cooling the heart and diaphragm.

Bai Jie San
This formula resolves hundreds of ailments, especially suitable for dispelling wind-heat and excessive yin conditions.
Ingredients: 2 liang of dried kudzu root, 2 liang each of bulbus acteae and red peony root, 1 liang of yellow qin herb, 7.5 qian of processed ephedra, 2.5 qian of cinnamon bark, and 1.5 qian of licorice.
Preparation: Grind the ingredients. For each dose, take 2 qian, add 1 cup of water, 2 slices of ginger, 1 green onion, and simmer down to 7 parts. Take warm at any time. If wind-heat is severe, add mint during simmering.

Mu Tong San
This formula addresses upper heat and closed lower orifices, resulting in irritability and anger, as well as dysuria and various skin conditions.
Ingredients: 0.5 liang each of peeled houttuynia and old root removed from earth flat plant, 3 qian each of rhubarb, licorice, and peeled red poria, 2.5 qian each of candu, talcum powder, gardenia seed, plantain seed, and yellow qin herb.
Preparation: Grind and pulverize the ingredients. For each dose, take 2 qian, add 1 cup of water and 3 stems of lamp wick, simmer down to 7 parts. Take warm at any time. Can also add mint while simmering.

San Jie San
This formula treats upper jiao heat and wind invasion, characterized by flushed face, red eyes, irritability, thirst, sudden crying, distress, oral sores, and phlegm cough.
Ingredients: 5 qian each of red peony and yellow qin herb, 15 whole scorpions (remove poisonous tip), 6 qian of powdered grass, 2 qian each of poria, bitter orange (without kernel), and stir-fried wheat bran, 2.5 qian each of saposhnikovia, gastrodia, rhubarb, curcuma, and white silkworm, as well as 2.5 qian of ginseng.
Preparation: Grind and roast into a powder. For each dose, take 0.5 to 1 qian and mix with mint tea or lamp wick tea at any time.[283p]

Burdock Soup
Indicated for symptoms of wind-cold causing fever and irritability, nasal congestion, wheezing, cough with frightful crying, and various sores that are red or purple, including erysipelas and sore throat.

  • Rhubarb: 1.5 taels

  • Licorice: 1 tael and 1.5 qian

Fangfeng Decoction
Used for residual heat after an acute fright, with symptoms not yet resolved, causing twitching of the hands and feet and anxiety in the heart; also for wind pathogens entering the liver channel, with the eyes blinking excessively when looking at others.

  • Chuanxiong (Szechuan lovage): 0.5 tael
  • Rhubarb: 0.5 tael

  • Licorice: 0.5 tael

  • Mentha (Peppermint) leaves: 2.5 qian

The above ingredients should be ground into powder, and for each dose, take 1 qian mixed with warm soup, adjusted to taste at any time.

Banxia Pill
Effectively treats phlegm conditions. Particularly useful if phlegm and drooling arise after a fright or cramping, this medicine is very effective.

  • Raw Banxia: 2 taels
  • Red Poria: 1 tael
  • Zhi Ke (dried bitter orange): 1 tael
  • Wind-prepared Niter: 2.5 qian

The first three ingredients should be ground into powder, mixed with niter using a mortar, then made into pills the size of a mung bean using naturally extracted ginger juice boiled with glutinous rice flour. For each dose, take 30 to 50 pills, followed by a mild ginger soup before bed. For children, cook the pills to the size of a grain of millet.[284p]

　　宽气饮　主通利关节，除胸膈痞结，消痰逐水，进美饮食；及治蓄气而成搐，传变急慢惊风，气逆不和，精神昏倦。　　枳壳水浸去穰，麸炒微黄　枳实制同上，各一两　人参　甘草炙，各半两　　右銼焙为末，每服半钱至一钱，净汤无时调服。惊风发搐，姜汁葱头汤同调。热极者，入宽热饮，薄荷蜜汤调下，或麦门冬汤。

"Kuānqì Drink" is used to unblock and benefit the joints, alleviate chest congestion and phlegm retention, expel water, and enhance the consumption of nourishing food. It can also treat the accumulation of qi leading to convulsions, sudden or chronic fright, qi counterflow, and mental fatigue.

For its preparation, soak bitter orange peel (zhǐkē) and dry ginger, lightly roasted until slightly yellow; take equal amounts (one liang each) of the bitter orange fruit and ginseng, and half a liang each of roasted licorice. Grind these into a powder and take half to one qian with pure water at any time. For convulsions from fright, mix with ginger juice and scallion soup. If extremely heated, add in the "Kuān Rè Drink" and mint honey tea, or use ophiopogon soup.

"Wǔ Hé Soup" is aimed at dispelling accumulated heat in the internal organs and harmonizing the nutritive and defensive qi. To prepare, wash equal parts (half a liang each) of angelica root, red poria, roasted licorice, rhubarb, and soaked bitter orange peel, and lightly roasted until slightly yellow (each seven and a half qian). Grind the mixture, and take two qian with one cup of water, decocting to seven parts, taken warm at any time.

"Fúshén Soup" treats insufficient heart qi, causing anxiety and frequent crying, as well as helping underweight infants with much fright. It is suitable for both mother and child to take together. Use one liang of poria, half a liang each of ginseng and angelica (washed to remove tail), and two qian of roasted licorice. Grind the mixture, and take two qian with one cup of water, decocting to seven parts, taken warm at any time. If there is slight heat and restlessness, add ophiopogon and decoct together without the heart.[285p]

　　镇惊丸　主急慢二惊，风痰上壅，手足抽掣，口眼喎斜，烦躁生嗔，精神昏闷。常服宁心镇惊，疏风顺气。　　人参三钱　粉草半生半炙　茯神　僵蚕去丝　枳壳同前制，各五钱　白附子　南星制　白茯苓　硼砂　牙硝　朱砂水飞，各二钱半　全蝎十尾，去尖毒　麝香一字　　右除牙硝、硼砂、麝香、朱砂四味，用乳钵细研，余九味焙为末，入乳钵内和匀前四味，用糯米粉水煮清糊为丸梧桐子大，就带润以银朱为衣，每服三丸至五丸或七丸。急惊用温茶清磨化服；慢惊以生姜、熟附子煎汤，研化温服，薄荷汤化下。或麦门冬汤。
　　截惊丸　治惊风搐掣，烦躁有热，两目上视，口禁牙关。　　龙胆草　防风　青黛　钓藤和钩　净黄连　牛黄　甘草　朱砂各五钱　薄荷叶二钱半　麝香半钱　　右除牛黄、麝香外，余八味銼炒为末，仍同前二味，乳钵内杵匀，炼蜜丸如芡实大，每用一丸至二丸，温汤化服，或茶清。[286p]

Zhenjing Pill
This is for both acute and chronic shock, wind-phlegm obstruction, spasms in the hands and feet, facial distortions, irritability and anger, and clouded spirit. Regular use calms the mind and settles shock, dispelling wind and easing qi.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng: 9g
  • Half raw, half charred herbal powder: 4.5g
  • Poria: 5g
  • Silkworms (silk removed): 5g
  • Bitter orange peel (prepared as before): 5g
  • White Atractylodes: 2.5g
  • Processed Hunan rhizome: 2.5g
  • White Poria: 2.5g
  • Borax: 2.5g
  • Yarrow: 2.5g
  • Cinnabar (water-fried): 2.5g
  • Total of 10 scorpions (remove sharp toxins)
  • One character of musk: 0.5g

Among these, except for yarrow, borax, musk, and cinnabar, grind finely in a mortar. The remaining nine ingredients should be baked into a powder and mixed well in the mortar with the first four ingredients. Use glutinous rice flour and water to make a clean paste for forming pills the size of a Chinese parasol fruit. Coat with red lead and take three to five pills or seven pills at a time. For acute situations, take with warm tea; for chronic issues, boil ginger and mature Aconite as a decoction, grind and take warm, or with mint decoction. Alternatively, use Ophiopogon decoction.

Jiejing Pill
This treats shock-related spasms, irritability with heat, upward gaze, and locked jaws.

Ingredients:

  • Gentian: 5g
  • Siler: 5g
  • Indigo: 5g
  • Uncaria: 5g
  • Pure Coptis: 5g
  • Cow bile: 5g
  • Licorice: 5g
  • Cinnabar: 5g
  • Mint leaves: 2.5g
  • Musk: 0.5g

Excluding cow bile and musk, the remaining eight ingredients should be ground and roasted into a powder, then mixed with the previous two. Grind in a mortar until uniform, then incorporate honey to form pills the size of gorgon fruit. Take one to two pills with warm decoction or tea.[286p]

　　朱砂膏　主五心烦热，喉痰壅盛，惊风搐搦，渴饮无时，睡中不宁，见人烦躁，口疮糜烂。　　朱砂五钱　马牙硝　硼砂　元明粉各二钱半　真麝香　金箔银箔各十五片　白附子　枳壳麸炒微黄，各三钱　川芎　粉草各四钱　人参　黄芩　薄荷叶　　右前七味，入乳钵细研，后七味銼焙为末，仍入钵中，同前药和匀，炼蜜丸芡实大，每服一丸至二丸，用麦门冬熟水，无时化服。
　　不惊丹，治因惊气而吐逆作搐，痰涎壅塞，手足掣缩，目睛斜视，常服疏风顺气，自不作惊，和脾胃，进饮食。　　枳壳去穰麸炒黄，一两　淡豆豉焙干　南星　茯神去皮根木，各半两　蝎梢五十尾，去尖毒　净芜荑二钱半，先入乳钵内，研烂极细　　右除芜荑外，余五味焙为末，再同芜荑乳钵内杵匀，酢煮糯米粉糊为丸，周岁内婴孩粟谷大，每服三十丸至五十丸，乳汁下；三岁以上者，麻仁大，每服五十丸及六十丸，温米清汤下，候一时，得吃饮食。[287p]

Zhusha Ointment is primarily for alleviating five types of heart heat, phlegm obstruction in the throat, convulsions from fright, unquenchable thirst, restlessness during sleep, irritability upon seeing people, and ulcerative oral sores.

Ingredients:

  • 5 qian of zhusha (cinnabar)
  • 2.5 qian each of Ma Ya Xie (horse tooth ash), borax, and Yuan Ming powder
  • 15 pieces each of real musk and gold leaf
  • 3 qian each of Bai Fu Zi (white zalu) and Zhi Ke (bitter orange) lightly roasted until yellow
  • 4 qian each of Chuan Xiong (Szechuan lovage) and fenugreek
  • Ginseng, Huang Qin (Scutellaria), peppermint leaves (amount not specified)

Preparation: Grind the first seven ingredients finely in a mortar. The next seven ingredients should be roasted and ground into powder. Mix all together in the mortar, form into pill-sized balls equivalent to the size of qian shi (water caltrop) using honey. Each dose is one to two pills taken with cooked water from Mai Men Dong (Ophiopogon) at any time.

Bu Jing Dan treats vomiting due to fright, phlegm accumulation, spasms in hands and feet, and squinting eyes. Regular consumption helps to dispel wind and smooth qi, preventing further fright and harmonizing the spleen and stomach to facilitate consumption.

Ingredients:

  • 1 liang of Zhi Ke (bitter orange) without husk, roasted until yellow
  • 0.5 liang each of roasted Wan Dou Shi (soybeans), Nan Xing (arisaema), and Pi Fu Shen (Poria skin with wood removed)
  • 50 scorpion tails, tips removed for toxicity
  • 2.5 qian of Jing Wu Yi (lamb's ear)

Preparation: Except for Wu Yi, roast the other five ingredients into a fine powder. Mix well with the Wu Yi in a mortar, then combine with vinegary boiled glutinous rice flour to form pills. For infants under one year old, the pills should be the size of millet grains, take 30 to 50 pills with milk. For children over three years, the pills should be the size of sesame seeds, take 50 to 60 pills with warm clear rice soup and wait an hour before consuming food and drink.[287p]

　　参朮柴苓汤　治肝经风热，脾土受克，其证善怒，睡中抽搐，徧身作痒，饮食少思。　　人参　白朮　茯苓　陈皮各一钱　柴胡　升麻各七分　山栀炒，八分　钓藤钩一钱　甘草炒，五分　每服一二钱，姜枣水煎。

Shen Zhu Chai Ling Decoction: Treats the wind-heat of the liver channel, impacted spleen, indicated by irritability, convulsions during sleep, itching all over the body, and lack of appetite.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng: 1 qian
