Spleen-Replenishing and True Benefiting Decoction: Treats chronic spleen wind.

Ingredients: Clove, Wood Fragrance, Terminalia Chebula Skin, Aged Tangerine Peel, Magnolia Bark, Grass Fruit, Nutmeg, White Peony, Ginseng, White Atractylodes, Cinnamon Twig, Pinellia Tuber, Prepared Aconite, Honey-Fried Licorice, each 2 fen; stir-fried Scorpion, 1 piece. Grind together, add 2 slices of ginger and 1 jujube, boil with water and administer. After taking, massage below the heart to enhance the drug's effect.

Nine-Dragon Saliva Controlling Powder: Treats sky fishing.

Ingredients: 1 centipede, wine-cooked; 2 qian each of Dried Tea, Realgar, Licorice; 1 qian each of Frankincense, Curcuma, Aged White Alum, Schizonepeta Spike; 100 grains of mung bean, half raw and half fried. Grind into powder, take 1/2 qian with Ginseng and Peppermint decoction.

Fishing Vine Powder: Treats the same as above.

Ingredients: Ginseng, Rhino Horn, each 5 fen; stir-fried Scorpion, Gastrodia, each 2 fen; Licorice, 1 fen; Fishing Vine, 6 fen. Grind, boil with water and take.

Burning Dan Pill: Treats maternal fright-induced convulsions.

Ingredients: Taiyin Essence Stone, Light Powder, each 1 qian; Frost Powder, Borax, each 5 fen. Grind finely, add cold food flour 1 qian, form into pills, then wrap in flour and bake until yellow, remove flour, then grind finely, moisten with water to form pills the size of rice. For children, 5 pills for 1 year old, 10 pills for 2 years old, take with warm water to mitigate adverse effects.[343p]

小儿惊癎门

　　　　单方

　　小儿慢惊虚风：用平正附子去皮脐，生研为末，以白颈蚯蚓于末内滚之，候定刮蚓上附末，丸黄米大，每服十九，米饮下。【《百一方》】
　　惊癎发热：丹参、雷丸各半两，猪膏二两同煎，七上七下，滤去滓盛之，每以摩儿身上，日三次。【《千金方》，下同】
　　小儿暴惊，啼哭绝死：蜀椒、左顾牡蛎各六铢，以酢浆水一升，煮五合，每灌一合。
　　小儿惊热：天竺黄二钱，雄黄、牵牛各一钱，研匀，面糊丸粟米大，每服三五丸，薄荷汤下。【《小儿直诀》，下同】
　　小儿慢惊发搐，带有阳证者：血甘遂末即蚤休末一钱，瓜蒌根末一钱，同于慢火上炒焦黄研匀，每服一字，煎麝香、薄荷调下。[344p]

Children's Shock and Convulsions

Single Prescription

For children with chronic shock and虚风: Use peeled and pitted Fu Zi, ground into powder. Roll it with white-necked earthworm in the powder, wait for it to settle, scrape the earthworm to get the powder, and make into pills the size of yellow millet. Take nineteen per dose, to be swallowed with rice drink.

For convulsions with fever: Use equal amounts of Dan Shen and Lei Wan, two taels of pig fat, boil together seven times up and seven times down, strain out the residue, and apply the liquid to the child's body three times a day.

For children with sudden shock, who scream and seem lifeless: Use six zhu of Shu Jiao and Zuo Gu Mu Li, mix with one liter of vinegar-water, boil down to five cups, administering one cup at a time.

For children with shock and fever: Use two qian of Tian Zhu Huang, one qian each of Xiong Huang and Qian Niu, grind together, make into pills the size of millet, taking three to five pills per dose, swallowed with mint tea.

For children with chronic shock and convulsions, accompanied by yang symptoms: One qian of blood-sweet leaf powder and one qian of Zao Xiu powder, one qian of Gua Lou root powder, stir-fry until golden brown over slow heat, and take one character's worth, boiled with musk and mint for consumption.[344p]

　　小儿惊窜，两眼看地不上者：皂角烧灰，以童尿浸刮，用火烘干研末，贴其顖即苏。 【《王氏小儿方》】
　　小儿癎疾：棘枝上雀瓮研其间虫出，取汁灌之。 【《圣惠方》，下同】
　　小儿天吊，目睛上视：用壁鱼儿干者十个，湿者五个，用乳汁和研灌之。
　　小儿天吊，惊癎客忤：取家桑东行根，研汁服。
　　小儿惊风内钓：胡椒、木鳖子仁等分为末，醋调，黑豆且末和杵，丸菉豆大，每服三四十丸，荆芥汤下。
　　小儿天吊惊风，翻眼向上：用干蝎全者一个，瓦炒好朱砂三菉豆大为末，饭丸菉豆大，外以朱砂少许，同酒化下一丸，顿愈。
　　小儿躽啼惊癎，腹满，大便青白色：用柏子仁末，温水调服一钱。
　　小儿慢脾风，因吐泄后而成：麻黄长五寸十个去节，白朮指面大二块，全蝎二个，生薄荷叶包煨为末，二岁以下一字，三岁以上半钱，薄荷汤下。[345p]

A child scared and running away, looking down without raising their eyes: burn the black locust pods to ash, soak a child's urine and scrape it, dry it with fire and grind it into powder, apply it to the forehead to recover.

For a child with epilepsy: grind the small insects found on the thorny branches of the sparrow’s nest, extract the juice and administer it.

For a child with sky-hanging sickness, looking upward: use ten dried fish and five wet ones, mix with milk and grind, then administer.

For a child with sky-hanging sickness, experiencing fright and seizures: take the roots of the mulberry tree, which grow eastward, extract the juice and administer it.

For a child with fright and internal convulsions: equal parts of pepper and the seeds of the wood-fish, grind into powder, mix with vinegar, and combine with ground black beans to form pills the size of mung beans; take three to forty pills with a decoction of schizope.

For a child with sky-hanging sickness, experiencing fright with eyes turned upward: take one whole dried scorpion, fry it well with vermilion, grind to a powder the size of three mung beans, form pills the size of mung beans, use a bit of vermilion on the outside, dissolve in wine and take one pill, immediate recovery.

For a child with crying and fright, with fullness in the abdomen and pale blue stools: take powdered biota seeds, mix with warm water and administer one qian (a weight unit).

For a child with chronic spleen wind, occurring after vomiting and diarrhea: take ten pieces of ma huang (ephedra) five inches long, remove the joints, two pieces of white atractylodes the size of a fingertip, two whole scorpions, and fresh mint leaves, package and stew to grind into powder. For children under two years, administer one character’s worth, for those three years and older half a qian, and take with mint decoction.[345p]

　　惊癎发热：干蓝、凝水石等分为末，水调敷头上。
　　小儿急慢惊风，口眼喎斜，搐搦痰盛：用天浆子房去皮生用三枚，干蝎生用七枚，朱砂一钱研匀，饭丸粟大，每服二丸，荆芥汤送下。
　　小儿风癎掣瘲戴眼，极者日数十发：莽草、雷丸各一鸡子黄大，化猪脂一斤，煎七沸，去滓，摩痛处，勿近目及阴，日凡三四次。【《外台秘要》，下同】
　　小儿癎疾：白鱼酒，用衣中白鱼七枚，竹茹一握，酒一升，煎二合，温服之。
　　小儿惊风癎疾，喉闭牙紧：鉛白霜一字，蟾酥少许为末，乌梅肉蘸药，于龈上揩之，仍吹通关药，良久便幵。【《普济方》，下同】
　　小儿癎疾：鸡子黄和乳汁搅服，不过三两枚，自定。
　　小儿急惊：远年白田螺壳烧灰，入麝香少许，水调灌之。
　　小儿癎疾：羖羊角烧灰存性，酒服少许。
　　小儿慢脾惊风：马芹子、丁香、白僵蚕等分为末，每服一钱，炙橘皮煎汤下。[346p]

  • For sudden seizures with fever: Grind dry blue and water stones into a powder, mix with water, and apply to the head.
  • For urgent and chronic convulsions in children with a crooked mouth and eyes, and excessive phlegm: Use three fresh peach seeds (skin removed) and seven dried scorpions, mix with one penny of vermilion, grind together, make into pills the size of millet, and take two pills with a decoction of schizonepeta.
  • For seizures and convulsions in children with eye twitching, especially those occurring dozens of times a day: Take one chicken egg-sized quantity each of conrady grass and thunderbolt herb, and one pound of melted pig fat, boil until seven bubbles form, strain, and apply to the painful area, avoiding the eyes and the genitals, three to four times a day.
  • For epilepsy in children: Use seven pieces of white fish and a handful of bamboo shavings with one liter of wine; boil down to two cups and take warm.
  • For seizures with a tight throat and clenched teeth in children: Take a small amount of white lead powder and toad venom, grind together, dip a piece of black plum meat in the medicine, and apply it to the gums, then blow and clear the blocked passage; after a while, it should open.
  • For epilepsy in children: Mix chicken egg yolk with milk and take no more than three to two pills as needed.
  • For sudden fright in children: Burn the shell of white field snails from many years ago to ash, mix with a little musk, and administer with water.
  • For epilepsy in children: Burn goat horn to ash, preserve its essence, and take a small amount with wine.
  • For chronic spleen-related convulsions in children: Grind equal parts of horse parsley seeds, cloves, and white silkworms, and take one penny of this mixture, with a decoction of roasted orange peels.[346p]

　　小儿惊风：用大蒜七个，先烧红地，以蒜逐个于地上磨成膏，却以僵蚕一两，去头足安蒜上，碗覆一夜，勿令泄气，只取蚕研末，每用(口畜)鼻，口内含水有效。
　　惊癎中风，壮热掣瘲，吐舌出沫：用豚卵一双切细，当归二分，以醇酒三升，煮一升分服。
　　治小儿癎利痰：天南星煨香一两，朱砂一钱为末，猪心血丸梧子大，每防风汤下一丸。
　　惊风烦热：慎火草煎水浴之。

　　小儿啼：黄芩、人参等分为末，每服一字，水饮下。
　　小儿惊癎疳痢，或夜啼：青黛量大小水研服之。歌云：孩儿杂病变成疳，不问强羸女与男。烦热毛焦鼻口燥，皮后枯槁四肢瘫。腹中时时更下痢，青黄赤白总一般。眼濇面黄鼻孔黑，谷道开张不可看。此方便是青黛散，孩儿百病服之安。【《宫气方》】
　　小儿惊热，心肺积热，夜卧多惊：鉛霜、牛黄各半分，铁粉一分研匀，每服一字，竹沥调下。【《圣济录》，下同】[347p]

The abdomen frequently experiences diarrhea, with stools measuring in blue, yellow, red, and white. Eyes are dry, face is yellow, and nostrils appear dark. To treat childhood epilepsy: Use one qian of Guansui powder, one pig heart, and collect three tassels of blood from the heart. For sudden or chronic convulsions in children, when the jaw is tightly clenched and cannot be opened: Use soapberry powder mixed with water and apply it to the gums; it will revive.

For children's convulsions with spasms and a "heavenly hook" phenomenon: Use eight fen each of Tianma, Jingjie, Fangfeng, mint, whole scorpion, and silkworms, five fen each of Zhaixing and licorice, and mix with ginger juice to form pills the size of a marble. Take one after grinding it in water.

For children who frequently have spasms, indicating lung deficiency unable to calm the liver, use warming lung herbs as the main treatment: Use ginseng, Schisandra, and cinnamon. If cinnamon is not available, one fen of Xixin can be used instead.

For children who have fainted from fright, where liver connection is affected leading to misaligned vision—seeing east when looking west and vice versa, known as "sudden vision": Use one liang of stone heather and five melon seeds ground into powder to blow into the nose, three times a day. Also, administer cow bile to calm the liver.

For chronic spleen wind: Use twenty grains of sheep dung, one hundred grains of clove, and fifty grains of pepper; mix in five fen and take with broth from old wall soil.[355p]

　　治急惊：白石膏十两，辰砂一两，共为末，量儿大小，蜜水调下。
　　小儿内钓多啼：银朱半钱，乳香、煨蒜各一钱为末，研丸黍米大，半岁五丸，薄荷汤下。
　　小儿惊热：牛黄一杏仁大，竹沥、姜汁各一合，和匀与服。 【《卫生总微》，下同】
　　小儿牛癎：白牛屎中豆，日日服之，良。
　　小儿惊风，不拘急慢：用蜣螂一枚杵烂，以水一小盏，于百沸汤中荡热，去滓饮之。 【《本草纲目》，下同】
　　小儿癎疾：青羊肝一具，薄切水洗，和五味酱食之。
　　小儿口噤牙关不开：天南星一枚，煨熟，纸裹斜包，剪一小孔，透气于穴中，牙关自开也。一用生南星用姜汁擦之，自开。
　　小儿泻后，眼上三日不乳，目黄如金，气将绝，此慢惊肝风也，宜治肝。用水飞代赭石末，每服半钱，冬瓜仁煎汤调下，愈。
　　小儿天钓惊风，发歇不定：鹳屎炒研半钱，入牛黄、麝香各半钱，炒蝎五枚为末，每服五分，新汲水服。[356p]

Treating Sudden Fright: Ten taels of white gypsum, one tael of cinnabar, ground together into powder. Measure according to the child's size and mix with honey water to administer.

For a Child Crying Excessively: Half a qian of silver vermilion, one qian each of myrrh and roasted garlic, ground into powder. Form into pills the size of millet grains; give five pills with mint tea to a child of six months.

For a Child with Fright-induced Fever: One piece of gou huo (cow bile) the size of an apricot seed, combined with one cup each of bamboo sap and ginger juice, mixed well for administration.

For Cowpox in Children: Break up white cow dung mixed with beans, and have the child take it daily; it is effective.

For Sudden Wind in Children, Regardless of Urgency: Use one dung beetle, pound it finely, mix with a small cup of water, and heat it in boiling soup. Strain and drink.

For Epilepsy in Children: One whole liver of a green goat, sliced thin and washed with water, eaten with five-spice sauce.

For a Child with Locked Jaw and Inability to Open Mouth: One piece of tian nanxing (flybane), cooked thoroughly, wrapped in paper with a small hole for airflow; place in the mouth to self-open the jaw. Alternatively, use fresh tian nanxing and rub with ginger juice for it to open.

For a Child with Diarrhea Who Hasn't Fed for Three Days, Eyes Yellow as Gold, and Breath Weak: This indicates chronic fright from liver wind and should be treated with liver remedies. Use water-fried dai zhe shi (hematoidal stone), half a qian each time, mixed with decoction of winter melon seeds for administration.

For Sudden Fright-Induced Wind with Unstable Symptoms: Fry and grind half a qian of stork droppings, adding half a qian each of cow bile and musk, alongside five fried scorpions into powder. Administer five fen with freshly drawn water.[356p]

　　小儿痓风，头及四肢皆往后，以鸭涎滴之。
　　小儿惊风，吐逆作搐，痰涎壅塞，手足掣瘲，眼睛斜视：枳壳去穰麸炒、淡豆豉等分为末，每服一字，甚者半钱，急惊薄荷自然汁下，慢惊荆芥汤下，入酒三五点，日三服。
　　小儿惊热，钓藤一两，硝石半两，甘草炙一分，为散，每服半钱，温水服。
　　惊癎发热：铁粉水调少许服之。

　　急惊涎潮壮热闷乱：铁粉一钱，朱砂一钱为末，每服一字，薄荷汤调下。
　　婴孩惊风后，喑不能言，用芜荑炒、神曲炒、麦芽炒、黄连炒各一钱为末，猪胆汁打糊，丸黍米大，每服十丸，木通汤下。黄连能去心窍恶血。
　　急慢惊风：用青蒿蠹虫捣和，朱砂、汞粉各五分，丸粟粒大，一岁一丸，乳汁服。古方不见用者，《保婴集》用治惊风，云十不失一。其诗云：一半朱砂一半雪，其功只在青蒿节。任教死去也还魂，服时须用生人血。[357p]

Childhood convulsions: the head and limbs bend backward; apply duck drool.

For child’s febrile convulsions with vomiting and cramps, phlegm obstructing, spasms in hands and feet, and squinting eyes: grind equal parts of dried bitter orange peel and light fermented soybeans into powder. Take a dose of one word amount, or half a qian for severe cases, immediately take peppermint juice; for milder cases, take it with mint decoction, adding three to five drops of wine. Take three times a day.

For childhood febrile convulsions: one liang of vine fruit, half a liang of saltpetre, and one fen of roasted licorice, mix into powder. Take half a qian with warm water.

For spasms and fever: take a small amount of iron powder mixed with water.

For severe convulsions with drooling and intense heat: mix one qian each of iron powder and vermilion into powder, take a dose of one word amount, and blend with peppermint decoction.

After a child has convulsions and becomes mute, use one qian each of fried shepherd's purse, fried medicated leaven, fried malt, and fried coptis, grind into powder. Mix with pig bile to form a paste, rolling into pills the size of millet, take ten pills with wood shaving decoction. Coptis can clear malevolent blood from the heart channels.

For acute and chronic convulsions: pound together blue-green wormwood and insect powder, add five fen each of vermilion and mercury powder, roll into pills the size of millet, one pill for each year of age, taken with breast milk. An ancient method not widely used, noted in the "Preserving Infants Collection" that claims it succeeds ten times out of ten. The poem says: "Half vermilion, half snow, its efficacy lies in the section of blue-green wormwood." Should someone die, their soul could return; while taking, one must use the blood of a living person.[357p]

　　　　针灸

　　晋　皇甫谧《甲乙经》曰：惊癎脉五，针手足太阴各五，刺足太阳者五，刺手足少阴经络傍者一，足阳明一，上踝五寸刺三针。　　小儿惊癎，本神及前顶、顖会、天柱主之。如反视，临泣主之。　　小儿惊癎，加瘈瘲脊急，强目转上插，缩筋主之。　　小儿惊癎，瘈瘲脊强，互相引，长强主之。　　小儿癎发，目上插，攒竹主之。
　　小儿癎痓，呕吐泄注，惊恐失精，瞻视不明，眵(目蔑)，瘈脉及长强主之。　　小儿惊癎不得息，颅顖主之。
　　小儿惊癎如有见者，列缺主之，并取阳明络。　　小儿癎瘈，手足扰，目昏口噤，溺黄，商丘主之。　　小儿癎瘈，遗精溺，虚则病诸癎癫，实则闭癃，小腹中热，善寐，大敦主之。　　小儿马癎，仆参及金门主之。[358p]

Acupuncture

In the "Jia Yi Jing" by Huangfu Mi from the Jin Dynasty, it states: For convulsions in children, there are five pulse points. Needle the Taiyin on hands and feet each five times, needle the foot Taiyang five times, needle the channels of the hand and foot Shaoyin once each, and for the foot Yangming, needle once within five inches above the ankle. For children's convulsions, needle the Shen and the points at the top of the head, Hui meeting point, and Tianzhu point. If there are backward gazes, needle the Linqi point.

For children with convulsions and urgent spasm of the spine, and forced upward gaze, needle where the muscles are tense. For convulsions in children where the spine is tight and symptoms interact, needle the Changqiang point.

When convulsions occur in children, if the gaze is upward, needle the Cuanzhu point. For children's convulsions presenting with vomiting, diarrhea, shock, loss of spirit, unclear vision, and eye issues, needle the points associated with the convulsive pulse and Changqiang point.

For children experiencing unyielding convulsions, needle the Hui point. If a child has visible signs of convulsions, needle the Lieque point and also target the Yangming channel. If there are convulsions accompanied by agitation in hands and feet, blurred vision, lockjaw, and yellowish urination, needle the Shangqiu point.

For convulsions involving emission of semen or urination, if weak, the illness relates to convulsions; if strong, it pertains to obstruction. If there is heat in the lower abdomen and good sleep, needle the Dadun point.

For children's malarial convulsions, needle the Pucun and Jinyuan points.[358p]

　　风从头至足，癎瘈口闭不能开，每大便腹暴满，按之不下，嚏悲喘，昆仑主之。　　唐　孙思邈《千金方》论曰：小儿新生无疾，慎不可逆针灸之。如逆针灸则忍痛，动其五脉，因喜成癎。河洛关中土地多寒，儿喜病痉，其生儿三日，多逆灸以防之。又灸颊以防噤。有噤者，舌下脉急，牙车筋急。其土地寒，皆决舌下去血、灸颊以防噤也。吴蜀地温，无此疾也。古方既传之，今人不详南北之殊，便按方而用之，是以多害于小儿也。所以田舍小儿任其自然，皆得无有夭横也。小儿惊啼，眠中四肢掣动，变蒸未解，慎不可针灸爪之，动其百脉，仍因惊成癎也。惟阴癎噤痉，可针灸爪之。凡灸癎当先下儿使虚，乃乘虚灸之，未下有实而灸者，气逼前后不通，杀人。[359p]

Wind affects the body from head to toe, causing seizures with the mouth closed tight and the abdomen distended with feces that cannot be expelled. Pressing on it does not alleviate the discomfort, leading to sadness and panting, and this is governed by Kunlun.

In "Qianjin Fang," Sun Simiao of the Tang dynasty states that a newborn child should never be subjected to reverse acupuncture. If done in reverse, the child will endure pain, disturbing the flow of the five vessels, which may lead to seizures. The land in the He and Luo regions is cold, and children are prone to convulsions; often, reverse acupuncture is used to prevent this. Additionally, moxibustion on the cheeks is used to prevent locking of the jaw. In cases of jaw locking, the pulse under the tongue is rapid, and the muscles in the teeth are tense. The cold conditions of the land lead to bleeding under the tongue and moxibustion on the cheeks to prevent jaw locking. In the warmer regions of Wu and Shu, this condition does not occur.

The ancient methods have been passed down, but modern practitioners do not pay attention to the differences between the north and south, resulting in harm to many children. Therefore, peasant children are allowed to grow naturally without dying prematurely.

When a child is shocked and cries, their limbs may twitch in sleep, and if they have not resolved the prior steam condition, do not perform acupuncture on their claws, as this could disturb the hundred vessels and lead to seizures. Only in cases of yin-type seizures and jaw locking is it acceptable to use acupuncture on the claws. In general, when moxibustion is applied for seizures, it should first be done to induce a state of deficiency in the child, and then the moxibustion is applied when the child is in a state of emptiness. If moxibustion is applied when the child is still solid, it can create a blockage in the qi both front and back, which could be fatal.[359p]

癎发平旦者在足少阳，晨朝发者在足厥阴，日中发者在足太阳，黄昏发者在足太阴，人定发者在足阳明，夜半发者在足少阴。　　右癎发时，视病所在，视其发早晚，灸其所也。　　肝癎之为病，面青，目反视，手足摇，灸足少阳、厥阴各三壮。　　心癎之为病，面赤，心下有热，短气，息微数，灸心下第二肋端宛宛中，此为巨阙也。又灸手心主及少阴各三壮。　　脾癎之为病，面黄腹大，喜痢，灸胃管三壮，侠胃管傍灸二壮，足阳明、太阴各二壮。　　肺癎之为病，面目白，口沫出，灸肺俞三壮，又灸手阳明、太阴各二壮。　　肾癎之为病，面黑，正直视不摇，如尸状，灸心下二寸二分三壮；又灸肘中动脉各二壮；又灸足少阳、少阴各三壮。　　膈癎之为病，目反四肢不举，灸风府；又灸顶上、鼻人中、下唇承浆，皆随年壮。　　肠癎之为病，不动摇，灸两承山；又灸足心、两手劳宫；又灸两耳后完骨，各随年壮；又灸脐中五十壮。　　右五脏癎证候。[360p]

Seizures occurring at dawn are associated with the footless lesser yang (Shaoyang), those occurring in the morning are associated with the footless greater yin (Jueyin), those at noon are linked to the footless greater yang (Taiyang), those at dusk with the footless greater yin (Taiyin), those during the day are connected to the footless yangming (Yangming), and those at midnight with the footless lesser yin (Shaoyin).

For the time of seizures, examine the location of the illness and the timing of the attack, then perform moxibustion accordingly.

For liver seizures, the face appears green, the eyes are turned backward, and the hands and feet shake; moxibustion should be done on the footless lesser yang and greater yin, three times each.

For heart seizures, the face appears red, there is heat below the heart, shortness of breath, and rapid weak pulses; moxibustion should be performed at the second rib's endpoint below the heart, referred to as the "Great Gate." Additionally, moxibustion should be applied to the center of the palm and on the footless lesser yin, three times each.

For spleen seizures, the face looks yellow, the abdomen is enlarged, there is a preference for diarrhea; moxibustion should be done on the stomach channel three times, alongside two moxibustions on the side of the stomach channel, and two times each on the footless yangming and greater yin.

For lung seizures, the face appears pale, there is frothy saliva; perform moxibustion on the lung back point three times, and two times each on the handless yangming and greater yin.

For kidney seizures, the face turns black, the body maintains a rigid posture, resembling a corpse; moxibustion should be applied two inches below the heart area three times, and two times each on the radial artery at the elbow and on the footless lesser yang and lesser yin.

For diaphragm seizures, the eyes roll back and the limbs cannot move; perform moxibustion at the Wind Palace (Fengfu), and also on the top of the head, between the nose and the mouth, and the lower lip, accordingly to the years of experience in practice.

For intestinal seizures, the body does not shake, perform moxibustion on both the "Chengshan" points, as well as on the soles of the feet and on the "Laogong" points in both hands, and also on the area behind the ears at the bone completion, according to the years of experience; additionally, moxibustion should be applied to the navel fifty times.

This outlines the symptoms of seizures related to the five internal organs.[360p]

　　六畜之癎，或在四肢，或在腹内，当审其候，随病所在灸之，虽少必瘥。若失其要，则为害也。　　马癎之为病，张口摇头，马鸣，欲反折，灸项风府、脐中三壮；病在腹中，烧马蹄末服之，良。　　牛癎之为病，目正直视，腹胀，灸鸠尾骨及大椎各三壮；烧牛蹄末服之，良。　　羊癎之为病，喜扬目吐舌，灸大椎上三壮。　　猪癎之为病，喜吐沫，灸完骨'完骨　原作「脊骨」，据《千金》卷五惊癎改。\两傍各一寸七壮。　　犬癎之为病，手屈拳挛，灸两手心一壮，灸足太阳一壮，灸肋户一壮。　　鸡癎之为病，摇头反折，喜惊自摇，灸足诸阳各三壮。　　右六畜癎证候。[361p]

The ailments of the six livestock may occur in their limbs or in their abdomen. One must examine the symptoms carefully and administer moxibustion to the afflicted area; even if minimal, there will certainly be healing. If the proper approach is not followed, it will cause harm.

For horse ailments, the symptoms include opening the mouth, shaking the head, neighing, and wanting to rear up. Moxibustion should be applied to the Wind Mansion at the nape of the neck and to the three points in the center of the navel. If the ailment is in the abdomen, burn the hoof powder and administer it; this is beneficial.

For cattle ailments, the symptoms include a steady gaze and abdominal swelling. Moxibustion should be performed on the tailbone and at the major spine, three times each. Burning the hoof powder and administering it is beneficial.

For sheep ailments, the symptoms include lifting the eyes and sticking out the tongue. Apply moxibustion three times above the major spine.

For swine ailments, the symptoms include excessive salivation. Moxibustion should be applied along the spine, with each side treated at one inch and seven times in total.

For dog ailments, the symptoms include flexing the paws into fists. Apply moxibustion once at the center of each paw, once at the solar plexus of the foot, and once at the rib area.

For chicken ailments, the symptoms include shaking the head and rearing back, with a tendency to tremble. Moxibustion should be applied three times at each of the foot’s Yang points.

These are the symptoms associated with the six livestock ailments.[361p]

　　小儿暴癎灸两乳头，女儿灸乳下二分。　　治小儿暴癎者，身躽正直如死人，及腹中雷鸣，灸太仓及脐中上下两傍各一寸凡六处。又灸当腹度取，皆以绳绕颈下至脐中竭，便转绳向背，顺脊下行尽绳头，灸两傍各一寸五壮。　　若面白啼声，色不变，灸足阳明、太阴。　　若目反上视，眸子动，当灸顖中。取之法，横度口尽两吻际，又横度鼻下亦尽两边，折去鼻度半，都合口为度，从额上发际上行度之，灸度头一处，正在额上未合骨中随手动者，是此最要处也。[362p]

For treating children's sudden convulsions, apply moxibustion to both nipples; for daughters, moxibustion should be applied under the breasts, about two inches below. In cases of children's sudden convulsions, if the body becomes stiff and straight like a corpse, and there are rumblings in the abdomen, apply moxibustion to the Tai Cang point and around the navel, up and down to both sides, each one inch, totaling six places. Additionally, apply moxibustion accordingly around the abdomen, using a string wrapped around the neck down to the middle of the navel, then turn the string towards the back, following the spine down until the end of the string, and apply moxibustion one and a half inches on both sides.

If the face turns pale and there are crying sounds, with no change in color, apply moxibustion to the Yangming and Taiyin points. If the eyes are rolled back and the pupils are moving, moxibustion should be applied to the fontanel. The method involves measuring horizontally from the corners of the mouth, extending to both lips, and measuring horizontally beneath the nose, also to both sides. Take half of that nose measurement, aligning it with the mouth. Measure from the hairline above the forehead downwards, applying moxibustion in one spot right on the forehead, situated in the middle of the forehead where the bones don’t meet, as this is the most critical area.[362p]

次灸当额上入发二分许，直望鼻为正；次灸其两边，当目瞳子直上入发际二分；次灸顶上回手中，次灸客主人，穴在眉后际动脉是；次灸两耳门，当耳开口则骨解开动张陷是也；次灸两耳上，卷耳取之，当卷耳上头是也，一法大人当耳上横三指，小儿各自取其指也；次灸两耳后完骨上青脉，方可以针刺令血出；次灸玉枕，项后高骨是也；次灸两风池，在项后两辕动筋外发际陷中是也；次灸风府，当项中央发际，方可与风池三处高下相等；次灸头两角，两角当回毛两边起骨是也。　　右头部凡十九处，儿生十日可灸三壮，三十日可灸五壮，五十日可灸七壮。病重者俱灸之，轻者惟灸顖中、风池、玉枕也。艾使熟，炷令平正着肉，火势乃至病所也。艾若生，炷不平正，不着肉，徒灸多炷，故无益也。[363p]

Next, moxibustion should be applied two points into the hairline above the forehead, directly in line with the nose; then, moxibustion should be applied on either side, two points directly above the pupils and into the hairline; next, moxibustion at the top of the head, and then on the rulers of the guest and host, the point is at the pulsation behind the eyebrows; next, moxibustion at the two ear gates, at the opening of the ear where the bone separates and expands; next, moxibustion on the upper parts of both ears, taking the upper edge of the ear as the point, adults align it horizontally three finger breadths above the ear, while for children, they take their own finger breadth; next, moxibustion behind both ears at the prominent bone over the blue veins, only then can acupuncture be performed to draw blood; next, moxibustion at Yuzhen, which is at the high bone behind the neck; next, moxibustion at both Fengchi points, located in the depressions on either side of the back of the neck where the tendons are; next, moxibustion at Fengfu, at the center of the back of the neck at the hairline, which should be level with the three points of Fengchi; next, moxibustion at the two angles of the head, where the bones rise at both sides along the hairline.

In total, there are nineteen points on the head; for children who are ten days old, three treatments can be applied; at thirty days, five treatments; and at fifty days, seven treatments. For severe illnesses, all points should be treated; for mild conditions, only the Baihui, Fengchi, and Yuzhen points should be treated. Use moxa that is dried, and apply the roll evenly onto the skin, allowing the heat to reach the afflicted area. If the moxa is wet, the rolls will not be evenly applied and will not contact the skin, leading to excessive burning without any benefits.[363p]

　　若腹满短气转鸣，灸肺募，在两乳上第二肋间宛宛中，悬绳取之，当瞳子是；次灸膻中；次灸胷堂；次灸脐中；次灸薛息，薛息在两乳下第一肋间宛宛中是也；次灸巨阙，大人去鸠尾下一寸，小儿去脐作六分分之，去鸠尾下一寸是也，并灸两边；次灸胃管；次灸金门，金门在谷道前，囊之后，当中央是也，从阴囊下度至大孔前，中分之。　　右腹部十二处，胸堂、巨阙、胃管，十日儿可灸三壮，一月已上可五壮。阴下缝中可三牡，或云随年壮。　　若脊强反张，灸大椎并灸诸脏俞及督脊上当中。　大椎度至穷骨中屈，更从大椎度之，灸度下头是督脊也。　　右背部十二处，十日儿可灸三壮，一月已上可灸五壮。　　若手足掣瘲惊者灸尺泽，次灸阳明，次灸少商，次灸劳官，次灸心主，次灸合谷，次灸三间三间　原作「三关」，按《千金》卷五惊癎改。，次灸少阳。　　右手部十六处，其要者阳明、少商、心主、尺泽、合谷、少阳也，壮数如上。[364p]

If there is fullness in the abdomen with shortness of breath and gurgling sounds, moxibustion should be applied to the lung region, specifically on the second rib between the two breasts. Locate this point carefully. Next, perform moxibustion on the middle of the chest, then at the navel, and subsequently at the Xuexi point, which is located in the middle between the two breasts at the first rib. Following that, apply moxibustion at the Jueque point, which is one inch below the tailbone for adults, and six-tenths below the navel for children, also one inch below the tailbone. Apply moxibustion on both sides as well. Then, moxibustion on the stomach conduit, and on the Jinmen point, which is found in front of the valley, located centrally behind the bladder. Measure from below the scrotum to the front of the perineum at the midpoint.

For the twelve points on the right abdomen—the chest area, Jueque, and the stomach conduit—apply moxibustion three times for children under ten days old and five times for those over a month. In the region above the genitals, three times may be suitable, or some say according to age.

If there is a strong curvature in the spine, moxibustion should be applied to the Dazhui point and to the associated organ points along the spine centrally. The Dazhui can be measured down to the base of the spine; from the Dazhui point, continue measuring downwards to perform moxibustion at the top of the spine.

For the twelve points on the right back, children under ten days should receive moxibustion three times, and those over a month can have it five times.

If there are spasms in the hands and feet or if there is shock, perform moxibustion on the Chi Ze point, followed by the Yangming point, then on the Shaoshang, upon the Laoguan, on the Xin Zhu point, at the Hegu point, and lastly on the three Intersections.

For the right hand, there are sixteen important points, particularly Yangming, Shaoshang, Xin Zhu, Chi Ze, Hegu, and Shaoyang, with the number of applications as mentioned above.[364p]

　　又灸伏兔，次灸三里，次灸腓肠，次灸鹿溪，次灸阳明，次灸少阳，次灸然谷。　　右足部十四处皆要，可灸，壮数如上。　　手足阳明谓人四指，凡小儿惊癎皆灸之。若风病大动，手足掣瘲者，尽灸手足十指端，又灸本节后。　　窦汉卿《疮疡全书》曰：慢惊灸法，以酱一匕，涂在百会穴，用艾叶如半粒黄豆大者，灸五壮为度。五壮之内，不拘次第。婴儿哭声如平时无异者生，其声嘶不向亮者死，累试累效。百会穴在头顶心旋毛中是穴。[365p]

Again, moxibustion is applied to the rabbit's back, then to the Sanli point, then to the calf, then to the Luci point, then to the Yangming point, then to the Shaoyang point, and then to the Rangu point.

The fourteen places on the right foot are all essential; they can be treated with moxibustion, and the intensity should be as mentioned above.

The Hand-foot Yangming refers to the four fingers; for all children experiencing fright or convulsions, moxibustion should be applied to these areas. If a severe wind condition causes spasms in the hands and feet, then moxibustion should be applied to all ten fingertips and the joints behind them.

Dou Hanjing in "Complete Book of Sores and Ulcers" states: For chronic fright, use a spoonful of soy sauce and apply it to the Baihui point, with moxibustion using mugwort leaves the size of half a yellow bean, performing moxibustion five times as a standard. Within these five times, the order does not matter.

If an infant cries in a way that is no different from usual, they will live; if their cry is hoarse and unnatural, they will die, as proven repeatedly. The Baihui point is located at the crown of the head, at the heart of where the hair spirals.[365p]

凡婴儿月内虽无惊病，依法灸之，能免一世之惊恐。泄泻灸之，亦妙。　　《幼科全书》曰：凡急惊风发时，牙关紧闭不醒者，急用艾炷灸两手中指，合而灸之即醒，而后施治法也。　　先以两手大指相合，于甲侧缝处烧一二炷；又以两手中指相合，于甲缝中心烧一二炷，即醒。若灸不知痛者，则不治。　　《古今医统》曰：小儿急惊，针小豁。惊癎啼叫灸百会，或针神门三分，灸三壮。　　小儿慢惊，灸尺泽、印堂三壮：尺泽在肘中约纹上用肘横纹筋骨罅陷中，手太阴肺脉所入为合水，肺实泻之。[366p]

For infants, even if there are no signs of fright during the month, performing moxibustion according to the method can prevent lifelong fears. Moxibustion for diarrhea is also effective. The "Complete Book of Pediatrics" states: whenever acute convulsions occur with the jaw clenched and unresponsive, immediately use moxa on the middle fingers of both hands, bringing them together to apply the heat, which will awaken the child, after which treatment can be administered. First, bring the thumbs together and burn one or two moxa sticks at the lateral edges of the nails; then, bring the middle fingers together and burn one or two moxa sticks at the center of the nail seams to awaken them. If there is no reaction to the moxibustion, do not administer treatment. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Compendium" states: for acute fright in children, needle the small point. For fright with crying, do moxibustion at the Baihui point, or needle the Shenmen point with three-tenths and do three strong moxibustions. For chronic fright in children, do moxibustion at the Shizhe and Yintang points with three strong applications each: Shizhe is found in the hollow above the elbow crease along the transverse elbow line, where the Taiyin Lung meridian enters, to relieve lung excess.[366p]

　　小儿瘈瘲，针阳谷二分，灸则三壮。阳谷在手外侧腕中锐骨下陷中，手太阳大肠所行为经火。　　小儿发癎瘈瘲，针昆仑三分，灸则三壮。昆仑在足外踝后跟骨上陷中，细脉动应手，足太阳膀胱脉所行为经火。或针瘈脉一分，灸三壮。瘈脉一名资脉，耳本后鸡足青络脉。或针前顶一分，灸则三壮，前顶在顖会后一寸半骨间陷中。　　小儿吐呕，泻痢无时，惊恐目濇，眵膏，针瘈脉一分，灸则三壮。瘈脉一名资脉，耳本后鸡足青络脉，刺出血如豆汁，不宜多出。　　小儿风癎，角弓反张，灸神阙三壮，禁针。神阙，一名气舍，当脐中。　　小儿呕吐，瘈瘲发癎，身热头痛，不得卧，聤耳肿及脓汁，灸颅息七壮，禁针。颅息，耳后间青络脉中。　　小儿张口摇头，身反，针金门一分，灸则三壮。[367p]

For children with convulsions, needle the Yanggu point for two minutes and moxibustion for three applications. Yanggu is located on the outer side of the wrist, in the hollow beneath the sharp bone, corresponding to the Hand Taiyang Large Intestine channel.

For children with tics and convulsions, needle the Kunlun point for three minutes and moxibustion for three applications. Kunlun is found behind the outer ankle at the hollow above the heel bone, where a fine pulse can be felt; it corresponds to the Foot Taiyang Bladder channel. Alternatively, needle the Zhi pulse for one minute and moxibustion for three applications. The Zhi pulse is also known as the Zi pulse, located at the back of the ear near the chicken-foot-like blue network. One may also needle the front fontanel for one minute and apply moxibustion for three applications; the front fontanel is found between the bones one and a half inches behind the vertex.

For children who vomit and have diarrhea intermittently, exhibit fright and eye irritation, or have sticky phlegm, needle the Zhi pulse for one minute and moxibustion for three applications. The Zhi pulse is known as the Zi pulse, located at the back of the ear near the chicken-foot-like blue network; needle until blood flows like bean juice, taking care not to draw too much.

For children with wind convulsions, where the body is arched backward, apply moxibustion to the Shenque point for three applications; do not needle. The Shenque, also known as the Qi Residence, is located at the center of the navel.

For children who vomit, exhibit convulsions, have body heat and headaches, cannot lie down, have ear swelling and pus, apply moxibustion to the Xu point at the back of the ear for seven applications; do not needle. The Xu point is found in the middle of the ear's back network.

For children who open their mouths, shake their heads, and arch their bodies, needle the Jinmen point for one minute and apply moxibustion for three applications.[367p]

金门一名梁关，在外踝下，申脉下一寸，足太阳郄，阳维别属。　　小儿瘈瘲，针长强三分，灸则五壮。长强一名气之阴郄，一名撅骨，在脊骶骨端，计三分，伏地取之乃得，足少阴少阳结会督脉，别走任脉。　　小儿睡中惊掣，灸足大指次指之端，去爪甲如韭叶许，各一壮。　　小儿身强角弓反张，灸鼻上入发际三分三壮，次灸大椎下节间三壮。　　小儿急惊风，灸前顶一穴三壮，取法在百会前一寸；若不愈，再灸两眉心及鼻下人中一穴，炷如麦大。　　小儿风癎治不瘥，灸耳上入发际一寸五分，嚼而取之。　　小儿睡中惊，目不合，灸屈肘横纹中上三分各一壮。癎病者，小儿恶疾也，呼吸之间，不及求师，致困者不少。谚云：世无良医，枉死者半。小儿诸癎病，如口秽吐清沫，灸巨阙穴三壮，在鸠尾下一寸陷中。[368p]

In Jinmen, there is a point named Liangguan, located one inch below the outer ankle and one inch below the Shen pulse, corresponding to the foot Taiyang. This point belongs to the Yangwei channel.

For children with epilepsy, use acupuncture at Changqiang point, three-tenths of an inch deep, and moxibustion should be performed five times. Changqiang, also known as Qi's Yinxi, is located at the end of the sacral bone, three-tenths of an inch deep; you can access it while lying down. This point connects the foot Shaoyin and Shaoyang, which further communicates with the Governing Vessel and diverges to the Conception Vessel.

When children are startled from sleep, perform moxibustion at the tips of the big toe and the second toe, removing the nail like a leaf of chives. Each should be treated five times.

For children with a strong body, who exhibit a bowing posture, moxibustion should be performed three-tenths of an inch above the nose, near the hairline, done five times, followed by five treatments on the lower segment of Dazhui.

For children with sudden fright, moxibustion should be applied at the front top point three times, located one inch before Baihui; if not cured, also moxibustion the center of the eyebrows and the Philtrum below the nose at one spot, each the size of a wheat grain.

For children suffering from persistent fright during sleep, where the eyes don't align, moxibustion should be done three-tenths of an inch above the crease in the elbow, each treated once.

Epilepsy is a serious disease in children; in moments of breathing difficulty, one often cannot seek help, leading to many fatalities. As the saying goes: "In this world, there are no good doctors; half of the dead have died in vain."

For various forms of childhood epilepsy, when the child has a foul mouth and foams at the mouth, perform moxibustion at the Jueque point, treated three times, located one inch below the tailbone.[368p]

　　王肯堂《证治准绳》曰：小儿癫癎，惊风目眩，灸神庭一穴七壮，在鼻柱直上入发际五分。　　小儿鸡癎善惊，及掣目摇头，灸少阴二壮，取法在掌后去腕半寸陷中。　　小儿惊癎者，先惊叫乃发也，灸顶上旋毛中三壮，及耳后青络脉，炷如小麦大。　　小儿惊癎，灸鬼禄一穴三壮，取法在上唇内中央弦上是穴。　　小儿食癎者，先寒热洒淅乃发也，灸鸠尾穴上五分三壮。　　小儿牛癎，目直视腹胀乃发也，灸鸠尾一穴三壮，取法胸蔽骨下五分陷中是穴。　　小儿马癎，张口摇头，身折反马鸣也，灸仆参穴各三壮，取法在足跟骨下白肉际陷中，拱足取之是穴。　　小儿羊癎，目瞪吐舌羊鸣也，灸第九椎下节间三五壮。　　按《灵枢经》云：暴挛，足不任身，取天柱。天柱穴，足太阳也。又云，癫癎瘈瘲，不知所苦，两蹺之下，男阳女阴。[369p]

Wang Kentang's "Principles of Diagnosis and Treatment" states: For children with epilepsy and symptoms of fright and dizziness, moxibustion should be applied to the Shenting acupoint seven times, located five fen straight up from the nasal bridge to the hairline. For children with chicken epilepsy, who often experience fright and have eye twitching or head shaking, moxibustion should be done on the Shaoyin acupoint two times, located half an inch from the wrist on the back of the hand. For children suffering from fright-induced epilepsy, which begins with a startling shout, moxibustion should be applied three times to the center of the crown and to the vein behind the ear, with each moxa stick being the size of a grain of wheat. For children with food-related epilepsy, which starts with chills and fever, moxibustion should be done three times five fen above the Jiuwei acupoint. For children with cow epilepsy, who have a fixed gaze and abdominal distension, moxibustion should be applied three times to the Jiuwei acupoint, located five fen beneath the chest bone at the midpoint. For children with horse epilepsy, who open their mouths and shake their heads or bend their bodies as if neighing, moxibustion should be administered three times to the Puxin acupoint, located in the depression under the heel bone at the edge of the white flesh, accessed by curving the foot. For children with sheep epilepsy, who have bulging eyes and stick out their tongues in a bleating manner, moxibustion should be applied three to five times at the interval beneath the ninth vertebra. According to the "Spiritual Pivot," it states: Extreme convulsions lead to an inability to stand; one should take action at Tianzhu. The Tianzhu acupoint corresponds to the foot's sun meridian. It also notes that for epilepsy, the specific affliction is unknown; moxibustion should be applied below the two arches — the male being yang and the female being yin.[369p]

洁古云：昼发灸阳蹺，夜发灸阴蹺，各二壮。阳蹺起于跟中，循内踝上行至咽喉，交贯冲脉照海穴也。　　李梴《医学入门》曰：小儿惊风，灸本神，临泣外一寸半。小儿惊癎，于侠豁上一寸半陷中，针三分，灸三壮。　　《身经通考》曰：小儿急惊，灸百会穴前一寸；若不瘥，灸两肩头及人中各三壮，艾小麦大。　　《医学纲目》曰；角弓反张，鼻上入发际三分灸三壮，大椎下节间灸三壮。　　《王日新小儿方》曰：小儿惊风，大叫一声就死者，名老鸦惊，以散麻缠住胁下及手心足心，以灯火爆之；用老鸦蒜晒干、车前子等分为末，水调，贴手心。仍以灯心焠手足心及肩膊、眉心、鼻心即醒也。　　《小儿惊风秘诀》曰：凡小儿惊风昏迷，搐搦窜视诸病，又头风胀痛，视头额太阳络脉盛处，以灯心蘸麻油点灯焠之。　　仰向后者，灯火焠其顖门、两眉际之上下。　　眼翻不下者，焠其脐之上下。[370p]

Jie Gu said: During the day, moxibustion is applied to the Yang qiao, and at night to the Yin qiao, each with two strong applications. The Yang qiao starts at the center of the heel and ascends along the inner ankle to the throat, connecting with the Chong meridian at the Zhuhai point. Li Zhan in "Introduction to Medicine" states: For children with convulsions, moxibustion is applied to the Ben Shen point one and a half inches from the lateral tear. For children with epilepsy, moxibustion is done one and a half inches above the Xia Huo point with three needles and three strong applications. The "Body Classics Comprehensive Examination" says: For sudden convulsions in children, moxibustion is applied one inch in front of the Baihui point; if it does not heal, three strong applications on each shoulder and the philtrum with a size of a small wheat grain. The "Medical Compendium" says: For a backward arched neck, apply moxibustion three strong applications three points above the hairline on the nose, and three strong applications between the lower segment of the Dazhui. The "Wang Rixin's Pediatric Formulas" states: For children who cry out and then suddenly die from convulsions, it is called "Old Crow Shock," using hemp rope to bind the sides and palms of the hands and feet, igniting them with fire; using dried Old Crow garlic and cheqianzi mixed into powder, adjusting with water and applying to the palms. Then, using the wick of the lamp to apply fire to the palms, shoulders, mid-brow, and center of the nose will awaken the child. The "Secret of Pediatric Convulsions" states: For all cases of convulsions in children with confusion, spasms, and viewing troubles, as well as headaches with fullness and pain, apply lamp wick dipped in sesame oil to the temples where the major vessels are prominent. For those who look up and do not lower their eyes, apply fire above and below the navel.[370p]

　　不省人事者，焠其手足心心之上下。　　手拳不开口往上者，焠其顶心、两手心。　　撮口出白沫者，焠其口上下、手足心。　　凡小儿惊风通身都乌者，名乌纱惊，急推向下，将黄土一碗捣末，入久醋一锺炒热，包定熨之，下引至足，刺破为妙。[371p]

For those who lose consciousness, apply heat to the upper and lower parts of their hands and feet. For a fist that cannot open and is directed upwards, apply heat to the crown of the head and the palms of both hands. If they are foaming at the mouth, apply heat to their mouth and the soles and palms. In the case of a child who has a sudden convulsion and their entire body turns black, this condition is called "black gauze fright." Quickly push down on them, grind a bowl of yellow earth into a fine powder, mix it with a cup of aged vinegar, heat it, and apply it while wrapped up, letting it pull down to the feet, and puncture it for best effect.[371p]

　　　　医案

　　钱氏《小儿直诀》曰：广亲宅七太尉方七岁，潮热数日欲愈，钱谓父二大王曰：七使潮热将安，八使预防惊搐。王怒曰：但使七使愈，勿言八使病。钱曰：八使过来日午间即无苦也。次日，午前果作搐，急召钱治之，三日而愈。盖预见其目直视而腮赤，必肝心俱热。更坐石杌子乃欲就冷，此热甚也。又肌肤素肥盛而本实，其脉急促，故发搐。克言午时者，自寅至午，皆心肝用事之时，治之乃泻心肝补肾，自安矣。
　　李司户孙百日发搐，日三五次，或作胎惊治之，不应，即用大青膏豆许并涂顖、浴体二法，三日而愈。盖婴儿血气未实，不能胜外邪而发搐，故用浴体法。凡搐频者，风在表易治，宜发散；搐稀者，风在脏难治，宜补脾。
　　朱监簿子五岁，夜半发热，晓则如故，用凉药解之，反多涎喜睡，大便青白，作渴引饮。师曰：此当健脾胃，则诸证退。遂用白朮散一两，水煎，恣饮二剂稍愈，三剂渴止涎消；又投阿胶散二服而安。[372p]

Medical Case

The book by Qian on pediatric diagnosis states: "In the residence of the Qian family, regarding the case of the seven-year-old Tawei Fang, who had been suffering from tidal fever for several days and wanted to recover, Qian told his father, the Great King, 'The seventh (method) will cure the tidal fever, but the eighth (method) is for preventing convulsions.' The king was angry, saying: 'Only let the seventh cure him; do not speak of the eighth causing sickness.' Qian replied: 'The eighth method will surely occur tomorrow at noon without suffering.' The next day, before noon, convulsions indeed appeared, leading to an urgent call for Qian to treat him, and he recovered in three days. He foresaw that the child’s eyes were straight and his cheeks were red, indicating that both the liver and heart were overheated. He then sat on a stone stool seeking coolness; this heat was excessive. Also, the skin was plump and firm, and the pulse was rapid, hence the convulsions emerged. He explained that noon refers to the time from the tiger (3 AM) to noon, when the heart and liver are most active; thus, treatment involved draining the heart and liver while tonifying the kidneys, leading to peace."

In another case, Li Sihu’s grandson experienced convulsions a hundred days after birth, occurring three to five times a day. Treatment was given for fetal fright but did not yield results. Therefore, he used large blue ointment and applied it to the forehead and utilized bathing methods, leading to recovery in three days. This was because the infant's blood and qi were not yet substantial enough to withstand external evils, resulting in convulsions, thus the necessity of the bathing method. Generally, for frequent convulsions, it is easy to treat if wind is on the surface, and dispersal is recommended; for rare convulsions, it is challenging if wind is internal, hence it is advised to tonify the spleen.

In the case of Zhu Jian's five-year-old son, who experienced fever at midnight, upon waking, he returned to his usual state. Cooling medicine was given to resolve it, but he ended up producing excessive saliva and enjoyed sleep, with stools being green and white, exhibiting thirst and a desire for drink. The physician said: "This should strengthen the spleen and stomach, allowing the symptoms to recede." Consequently, a dose of Bai Zhu San (Atractylodes powder) was prepared with one tael of water, and he was allowed to drink two doses. He improved slightly, and after three doses, his thirst ceased and saliva diminished; further doses of Ejiao San were given, and the child settled down.[372p]

　　徐氏子三岁病潮热，每日酉则发搐，身微热而目微斜露睛，四肢冷而喘，大便微黄，请钱与李同治。钱问李曰：病何搐也？李曰：有风。何身热微温？曰：四肢所作。何目斜睛露？曰：搐则目斜。何肢冷？曰：冷厥心内热。曰：何喘？曰：搐之甚也。曰：何以治之？曰：凉惊丸鼻中灌之，必搐止。钱又问曰：既谓风病，温壮搐引，目斜露睛，内热肢冷，及搐甚而喘，并以何药治之？李曰：皆此药也。钱曰：不然。搐者，心肝实也；身微热者，日西肺用事之时也。肺主身温，今且热者，肺虚也。目微斜露睛者，肝肺相乘胜也。四肢冷者，脾虚也。肺若虚甚，则脾母亦弱。木气乘脾，四肢即冷。治之当先补脾肺，用益黄散、阿胶散，得脾虚证退，然后治其心肝，泻青丸、导赤散。凉惊丸治之。九日愈。[373p]

The son of the Xu family, three years old, suffered from tidal fever. Every day at the hour of You (5-7 PM), he experienced convulsions, had a slight fever, and his eyes were slightly turned and showed the whites. His limbs were cold, and he wheezed, with his stool being slightly yellow. The family consulted Qian and Li for treatment. Qian asked Li, “What causes the convulsions?” Li replied, “There is wind.” “Why is there a slight fever?” asked Qian. Li said, “It is due to the condition of the limbs.” “Why are the eyes turned and the whites showing?” asked Qian. Li answered, “Convulsions cause the eyes to turn.” “Why are the limbs cold?” Qian inquired. Li responded, “It is cold contraction with internal heat.” “What about the wheezing?” asked Qian. Li said, “It is due to severe convulsions.” “How shall we treat it?” Qian asked. Li said, “Administer Liangjing pills through the nose; it will certainly stop the convulsions.”

Qian further questioned, “Since you say it is a wind illness, with warmth causing convulsions, eyes turned with whites showing, internal heat with cold limbs, and severe convulsions causing wheezing, what medicine will treat all of these?” Li replied, “It is all treated with this medicine.” Qian insisted, “That can’t be right. The convulsions indicate a strong heart and liver; the slight fever signifies the lung functioning at sunset. The lungs govern warmth; the current warmth indicates lung deficiency. The eyes slightly turned and the whites showing indicate a conflict between the liver and lungs. The cold limbs indicate spleen deficiency. If the lungs are very deficient, then the spleen is also weak. Wood energy overwhelms the spleen, causing the limbs to become cold. To treat it, we must first tonify the spleen and lungs using Yi Huang powder and Ejiao powder, which will reduce the spleen deficiency before addressing the heart and liver with Xie Qing pills and Dao Chi powder. The Liangjing pills will treat it.” After nine days, the child recovered.[373p]

　　王驸马子五岁，目直视而不欲食，或以为鬼祟，用符水喷之，反加发搐，此肝经实火之证也，用泻青丸而愈。
　　王氏子患吐泻，或用药下之，睡而露睛，瘈瘲身冷，此慢惊也，即用瓜蒌汤治之而目开身温。但二便不利，或用八正散；复冷不食，即用益黄散、使君子丸，温补脾胃，诸证悉愈。后又有不语，用地黄丸以补肾，半月而愈。
　　李寺丞子三岁发搐，自卯至巳，目右视，大叫哭。钱见曰：此逆也。男为阳，本发左视无声则顺，右视有声则逆。所以然者，左肝木也。右肺金也。逆则二脏相战，金木相击而有声也。治宜泻强补弱。假令女发搐，目左视，是肺来乘肝，肝不能任。故叫哭也。当泻其肺，后治其心，续治其肝。若病在秋【日西时同，】 肺兼旺位，当大泻其肺。若病在春 【早晨时同，】 此肝旺之时，尚不能胜肺，是肺强而肝火弱也，当补其肝肾，大泻其肺。若男发搐，目右视，是肝来胜肺而叫哭，当泻其肝心。[374p]

The prince's son, five years old, stared straight ahead and did not desire food. Some believed it was a ghostly disturbance and sprayed him with magical water, which only worsened his condition, leading to convulsions. This was a sign of excessive heat in the liver channel, and he was treated with Qingxian pills and recovered.

The son of the Wang family suffered from vomiting and diarrhea, and when medication was given, he slept with his eyes open, and his body felt cold, which indicated chronic fright. Using a bottle gourd soup treated him, and his eyes opened and his body warmed. However, his urination and defecation were not smooth; thus, Ba Zheng powder was administered. If he was still cold and refused food, he was treated with Yihuang powder and Shijunzi pills to warm and tonify the spleen and stomach, and all symptoms resolved. Later, he became mute, and Sheng Di Huang pills were used to tonify the kidneys, and he recovered in half a month.

The son of Li Siling, three years old, had convulsions from the hour of Yin to the hour of Si, looking to the right and crying aloud. Qian Jian said, "This is a reversal." As a boy represents yang, normally he would look to the left in silence, which signifies a smooth condition; looking to the right with a sound signifies a reversal. This is because the liver belongs to wood on the left and the lungs to metal on the right. A reversal indicates conflict between these organs, resulting in the sound. Treatment should aim to drain the strong and nourish the weak.

For example, if a girl has convulsions and looks to the left, it suggests the lungs are disturbing the liver, which cannot tolerate it, thus causing the crying. In this case, the lung should be drained, and then the heart and liver treated subsequently. If the disease arises in the fall (during a similar time in the west), when the lungs are in a dominant position, the lungs should be strongly drained. If the disease occurs in spring (during the same time in the morning), when the liver is dominant, it cannot subdue the lungs, meaning the lungs are strong and the liver fire weak. Therefore, the liver and kidneys should be nourished while draining the lungs. If a boy has convulsions and looks to the right, it indicates the liver is overpowering the lungs and causing the crying, so the liver and heart should be drained.[374p]

若病在春夏【早晨日中时同，】 肝心旺时，当大泻其肝。若病在秋冬 【日晡时同，】 此肺旺之时，尚不能胜肝，是肝强而肺极虚也，当补其肺，大泻其肝。所以言目反视者，乃肝主目也。凡搐则是风热相搏于内，风属肝，故外见于目也。今此病先泻其肺，以泻肺汤主之，二日不闷乱，知病退也。后用地黄丸补肾，三服后用泻青丸各二服以泻心肝，五日而愈。然此证男反女，故男易治于女也。假令女发搐，目左视，肺之胜肝，又病在秋，即肺旺肝不能任，故哭叫，当大泻其肺，然后治心续肝。所以言男目右视者，木反侮金，肝旺胜肺，当泻其肝。若更病在春夏，金气极衰，又当补其肺，慎勿泻也。[375p]

If the illness occurs in spring or summer, during the morning or midday when the liver and heart are strong, one should greatly purge the liver. If the illness occurs in autumn or winter, during the evening when the lungs are dominant, and cannot bear the strength of the liver, the liver is strong while the lungs are extremely deficient; thus, one should nourish the lungs and greatly purge the liver. Therefore, it is said that the eyes reflecting vision relate to the liver. In general, convulsions indicate internal conflict between wind and heat; since wind pertains to the liver, it manifests outwardly in the eyes. In this case, one should first purge the lungs using a lung-purging decoction. If after two days there is no agitation or confusion, it indicates the illness is receding. Afterwards, use Shudihuang pills to nourish the kidneys, and after three doses, utilize Xieqing pills, each two doses, to purge the heart and liver, and recovery will happen in five days. However, it is said that this condition is more common in males than in females, hence males are easier to treat than females. For example, if a female has convulsions and her eyes look to the left, the power of the lungs suppresses the liver, and if it occurs in autumn, when the lungs dominate and the liver cannot manage, it causes crying and shouting; thus, one should significantly purge the lungs first, then treat the heart and restore the liver. So it is said that if males have their eyes looking to the right, wood offends metal, the liver is strong against the lungs, and one should purge the liver. If the illness occurs again in spring or summer, when metal energy is extremely deficient, one should nourish the lungs, being careful not to purge.[375p]

　　窦汉卿《疮疡全书》曰：一小儿七岁，闻雷则昏倒不知人事以人参、归身、麦冬，少入五味，尽一斤后，闻雷自若。
　　张从政《儒门事亲》曰：李氏一小儿，病手足搐搦，以示戴人。戴人曰：心火胜也。勿持捉其手，当从搐搦。此由乳母保抱太极所致。乃令扫挣地以水洒之，干令复洒之，令极湿，俯卧儿于地上，良久挥身转侧，泥涴皆满，仍似水洗之，少顷而瘥矣。
　　李东垣曰：陈氏女八岁时得癎病，遇阴雨则作，遇惊亦作，口出涎沫，声如羊鸣。余视之曰：此胎受惊也，其病深痼。调治半年，病亦可安，仍须淡味以佐药力。与烧丹丸，继以四物汤入黄连，随时加减，半年而安。
　　丹溪心法曰：孙女因胎中受湿热，日午发搐，唇黑面青，每日作一次，未半周，难与药，且酿乳饮之，用白朮、陈皮、半夏、芍药、青皮各五分，人参、川芎、木通各三钱，黄连二钱，炙草一钱，分八服，姜五片，与乳母煎服。[376p]

In "The Complete Book on Sores and Ulcers" by Dou Hanqing, it is stated: A young boy, seven years old, would faint upon hearing thunder, losing awareness of his surroundings. Using ginseng, goji berries, and Ophiopogon, he was given a small amount mixed with five flavors, consuming a pound of it, and afterwards he was unaffected by thunder.

In "Confucianism and Caring for Parents" by Zhang Congzheng, it is mentioned: A young boy from the Li family had convulsions in his hands and feet, which he demonstrated to a person named Dai. Dai said: "It is due to excess heart fire. Do not hold his hands; you should let the convulsions continue." This was caused by the wetness from his nurse's holding while he was in the womb. He was advised to sweep and sprinkle water on the ground, ensuring it was very moist, then lay the child on the ground for a long time, allowing him to roll and turn, getting covered in mud as if washed in water. After a while, he was cured.

Li Dongyuan states: A girl from the Chen family, at eight years old, contracted convulsions. It would worsen in damp weather or if she was startled, producing drool and making sounds like a bleating sheep. Upon examination, I concluded that this was due to fright during pregnancy, and the ailment was deeply rooted. After six months of treatment, the condition improved, but she still required bland flavors to assist the medicine's efficacy. I provided her with Dan Pill, followed by Si Wu Decoction with added Coptis, adjusting as needed, and after half a year, she was stable.

Danchi's principles say: A granddaughter suffered from damp-heat during pregnancy, experiencing convulsions at noon, with dark lips and a pale face, having a seizure daily. After less than half a month without effective medication, she was given a concoction with milk made from 0.5 tael each of Atractylodes, dried tangerine peel, Pinellia, peony, and green tangerine peel, along with 0.3 tael each of ginseng and Chengqing, 0.2 tael of Coptis, 0.1 tael of honey-fried licorice, divided into eight doses, with five slices of ginger, to be prepared and consumed by the nurse.[376p]

　　罗天益《卫生宝鉴》曰：魏敬甫之子四岁，一长老摩顶授记，众僧念咒，因而大恐，遂惊搐，痰涎壅塞，目多白睛，项背强急，喉有痰声，一时许方省。后每见衣皂之人辄发，多服朱砂、龙脑镇坠之药。四十余日，前证仍在，又添行步动作神思如痴，命余治之。诊其脉沉弦而急。《黄帝针经》云：心脉满大，癎瘈筋挛；又肝脉小急，癎瘈筋挛。盖小儿血气未定，神气尚弱，因而惊恐，神无所依，又动于肝，肝主筋，故癎瘈筋挛。病久气弱，小儿易为虚实，多服镇坠凉定之药，复损其气，故行步动作如痴。《内经》云：暴挛癎眩，足不任身，取天柱穴者是也，天柱穴乃足太阳之脉所发阳癎附而行也。又云：癫癎瘈瘲，不知所苦，两蹺主之，男阳女阴。洁古老人云：昼发取阳蹺申脉，夜发取阴蹺照海，先各灸二七壮。阳蹺申脉穴在外踝下容爪甲白肉际陷中，阴蹺照海穴在足内踝下陷中是也。次与沉香天麻汤，服三剂而全愈。[377p]

Luo Tianyi's "Treasures of Health" states: Wei Jingfu's son was four years old, and an elder rubbed his head to give a prophecy. The gathered monks recited incantations, which caused the child to be greatly frightened, leading to spasms, phlegm blockage, excessive white in the eyes, and a tense neck and back, with a phlegm-like voice in the throat. After a while, he seemed better. However, he would become frightened upon seeing people in black clothing, and he frequently took medications with realgar and dragon's brain for calming. After more than forty days, the symptoms persisted, and he began to walk and act in a dazed manner, so I was ordered to treat him. I diagnosed his pulse as deep, wiry, and rapid. The "Huangdi Needle Classic" states: "A full heart pulse indicates epilepsy and convulsions," and "The liver pulse is small and rapid, indicating epilepsy and convulsions." This is because a child's blood and qi are not yet stable, and their spirit is still weak. Thus, fear and fright arise, causing disturbances in the liver, which governs the tendons, leading to convulsions. After a prolonged illness, the qi weakens; children are more prone to vacuity and repletion. Taking too many calming medications further weakens their qi, hence the dazed walking and actions. The "Inner Classic" states: "Violent spasms during epilepsy—when the feet cannot support the body, one should needle the Tianzhu point." The Tianzhu point is where the Yang channels of the foot emerge. It further states: "For convulsions and epilepsy that are unclear, the two yang feet are the main points, with male corresponding to yang and female to yin." The venerable Elder Jie Gu said: "For daytime seizures, needle the Yang qiao in the Shen pulse; for night seizures, needle the Yin qiao in the Zhaohai point. First, moxa both points for two seven times." The Yang qiao Shen pulse point lies in the depression below the outer ankle, at the junction of the white flesh beneath the toenail, while the Yin qiao Zhaohai point is located in the depression below the inner ankle. Following this, I used a formula of fragrant agarwood and Tianma, and after taking three doses, he was completely cured.[377p]

　　万氏《幼科发挥》曰：英山县大尹吴清溪子病惊风，诸医作风治之不效。急差人请余。余往见尹曰：非风也，乃因惊得之。风从肝治，惊从心治。不识病原，如何有效？乃取至圣保命丹治之，搐止矣。尹曰：名不虚传，果良医也。[378p]

Wang's "Exploration of Pediatric Science" states: In Yingshan County, the chief official Wu Qingxi suffered from convulsions, and various doctors attempted to treat it as a wind disorder, but to no effect. They urgently sent someone to request my help. When I went to see him, I said: "It is not wind; rather, it is caused by fright. Wind is treated through the liver, while fright is treated through the heart. If one does not recognize the root cause of the illness, how can treatment be effective?" I then administered the most revered life-preserving elixir, and the convulsions ceased. The official said: "The name is not in vain; you are indeed an excellent physician."[378p]

　　一小儿惊后成癎，余制一方：天水散一料，碾为细末，分作三剂：二两三钱，入真青黛五钱碾匀，名倩魂散，寅卯时煎竹叶汤调服一钱，以平肝火；一剂二两三钱，入珠砂水飞五钱，名安神散，巳午时煎灯草汤调服，以镇其神；一剂二两三钱，入真轻粉二钱研匀，名定魂散，申酉时煎淡姜汤服，以去其痰，旬日而安。
　　一小儿十岁，久得癎疾，余视两目浑白无睛光，语言蹇濇，举动痴迷，乃语其父曰：不可治矣。后请医治之，竟无成功。
　　本县汪前川儿惊病，一月之间尝发二三次。余曰：不治必成癎也。求治于余，乃立一方，用枳实、黄连、半夏、白茯苓、各等分折半，朱砂飞又折半，同前研末，神曲糊丸芡实大，朱砂为衣，每服一丸，用豮猪心一个批开，入药在内，线扎定，放瓦罐中，煮熟取出，猪心和药食之，以汤送下，后竟不发，名断癎丸。[379p]

A young child, after being startled, developed epilepsy. I formulated a prescription: First, take one measure of heavenly water powder and grind it into a fine powder, dividing it into three doses. The first dose comprises 2.3 liang, mixed with 0.5 liang of genuine indigo powder, named "Qinghun San" (Quelling Soul Powder), to be brewed with bamboo leaf soup at the Yin and Mao hours, taking 1 qian to calm the liver fire. The second dose, also 2.3 liang, mixed with 0.5 liang of mercury powder, is named "Anshen San" (Calming Spirit Powder), to be brewed with lamp grass soup at the Si and Wu hours, taken to steady the spirit. The third dose, again 2.3 liang, mixed with 0.2 liang of genuine light powder, is named "Dinghun San" (Settling Soul Powder), to be brewed with light ginger soup at the Shen and You hours, taken to expel phlegm. After ten days, the child became stable.

There was a ten-year-old child who had suffered from epilepsy for a long time. Upon examination, his eyes appeared murky and lacked brightness, he spoke with difficulty, and his actions were dull and distracted. I told his father: "It is not curable." Later, they sought medical treatment, but ultimately, there was no success.

In our county, there was a child from Wang Qianchuan suffering from shock illness, experiencing two to three episodes in one month. I stated: "If not treated, it will surely develop into epilepsy." They sought my treatment, so I established a prescription using equal parts of bitter orange, coptis, pinellia, and white poria, halved, along with the mercury powder, halved again, ground together as before, and then made into pills the size of Chinese water chestnuts, coated with mercury powder. Each dose consisted of one pill, inserted into a pig's heart that had been cut open, secured with string, placed in a clay pot, boiled until cooked, and then the pig's heart was consumed with the medicine, accompanied by soup. After this treatment, the child did not experience further episodes, and I named it "Duanqian Wan" (Breaking Epilepsy Pill).[379p]

　　旧县张月山长子病急惊风，十七日不醒，待请余到，舌色黑矣。余尝见父念《玉函经》：伤寒舌黑洗不红，药洗分明见吉凶。余问曰：用何药洗之？父曰：薄荷汤。乃依法急取薄荷汤洗之，舌变红色。余曰：可治也。用泻青丸二钱煎汤服之，一饮而尽，口燥渴已止也。其夜搐止热退而安。此子不遇余，几死也。
　　汪元津幼子七月间因伤食病疟，七日发搐。余见之，肝风虽甚，脾未至困，当泻其肝，后补其脾可也。乃以泻肝散三服而搐止。后用调元汤以补其脾，琥珀抱龙丸以平其肝。喜睡，二目不能开。余思喜睡者，非脾困也，乃神昏欠惺惺也。目属肝，两泡属脾，合目不开者，非亡魂也，乃神倦也。今儿目欲开欲合可知也。只用前方，又二日，令其家中平日相与嬉戏者，取其小鼓小钹之物，在房中床前唱舞以噪之，未半日，目开而平复也。凡十日而安。[380p]

In the old county, Zhang Yuanshan’s eldest son fell seriously ill with a sudden convulsion and did not awaken for seventeen days. When I was called, his tongue was black. I once saw my father recite the "Jade Casket Classic": "In cases of cold damage, if the tongue is black and does not turn red with treatment, the medicine will clearly reveal fortune or misfortune." I asked, "What medicine should be used to wash it?" My father replied, "Mint decoction." Following his advice, I urgently prepared the mint decoction to wash his tongue, and it turned red. I said, "He can be treated." I then prescribed the Xieqing Pill, two qian, brewed as a decoction for him to drink in one go, and his dry throat and thirst ceased. That night, the convulsion stopped, the fever retreated, and he rested peacefully. If this son had not encountered me, he would have nearly died.

Wang Yuanzhen’s youngest son fell ill in July due to eating improperly and contracted a fever, having convulsions for seven days. I observed that although the liver wind was severe, the spleen was not yet exhausted; thus, I needed to clear his liver and then replenish his spleen. I prescribed a liver-clearing powder in three doses, and the convulsions ceased. Later, I used a regulating herbal decoction to replenish his spleen and the Amber Baolong Pill to pacify his liver. He enjoyed sleep, but could not open his eyes. I thought that if he liked to sleep, it was not due to spleen exhaustion, but rather due to a dull spirit. The eyes are related to the liver, and the pupils to the spleen. If he could not open his eyes, it wasn’t that his soul was lost, but rather that his spirit was weary. Now, if he wished to open and close his eyes, it was evident. I used the previous formula again, and after two days, I instructed his family, who usually played with him, to bring small drums and cymbals into his room and sing and dance before his bed to create some noise. Within half a day, his eyes opened, and he gradually recovered. In total, he was stable after ten days.[380p]

　　一女子五个月内发搐，余以泻青丸投之，三四服搐不止，转甚。余思痰壅气郁，乃发搐也。丸散颇粗，与痰粘滞于咽喉之间，致气不通而搐愈甚也。用竹叶煎作汤，取绵纸滤去其渣滓，澄清服之，搐止而安。其父叹曰：医之贵于变通也，如是夫！
　　有儿脾胃素弱，一日病泻，以理中丸服之，泻未止，口内生疮。乃谓前药性热助火，复以冷药投之，身微热，睡则扬睛。余见之曰：此发慢惊风也。令郎脾胃本虚，泻则益虚，口中生疮者，脾虚热也，误服冷药，则中气益损，昏睡不乳，虚损之极也，当急作调元汤倍加人参服之，调理半月而愈。[381p]

A woman experienced convulsions for five months. I administered Qing Wan pills, but after three or four doses, her convulsions did not stop and became worse. I suspected that phlegm and stagnant qi were causing her convulsions. The pills were somewhat coarse and had become stuck in her throat with the phlegm, leading to blocked qi and exacerbating her condition. I then prepared a soup from bamboo leaves, filtered it through cotton paper to remove the dregs, and gave her the clarified liquid to drink. Her convulsions ceased and she felt at peace. Her father sighed, saying: "The value of a physician lies in their ability to adapt; indeed, it is so!"

There was a boy whose spleen and stomach were inherently weak. One day, he suffered from diarrhea and was given Li Zhong Wan. However, the diarrhea did not stop, and sores arose in his mouth. I assumed that the previous medicine had a warming property that exacerbated the fire, so I prescribed a cooling remedy. He had slight fever and, when asleep, his eyes were wide open. I observed and said: "This is the onset of subtle convulsions." The boy's spleen and stomach were originally weak, and the diarrhea further weakened him. The sores in his mouth indicated that the spleen was deficient and hot. The mistaken use of the cooling remedy caused further harm to his vital energy, leading to lethargy and an inability to nurse, resulting in extreme deficiency. I recommended an urgent treatment using Tiao Yuan Soup with twice the amount of ginseng, and after half a month of regulating his condition, he recovered.[381p]

　　胡凤崖有子痘疮后伤食疳，肌瘦发穗，有医童一册见之曰：不是疳证，乃血虚也。其家惑之。始则生一病如癎非癎，昼则安静，夜则梦寐，抱其乳母叫云：我怕我怕，如人捕之状。询其病原，此儿性不吃药，一册来喂药，必将针火以恐吓之，而得斯疾也。盖胃为戊土，肾为癸水，合而化为火。肾主恐，恐则伤肾。此因脾胃虚弱，不能生肺，肾无化原，亦从而虚也。肾藏志，背虚则神志不宁而生惊恐。寤则神栖于心，寐则神栖于肾，脾志往来出入之门户也。必以补脾为主，安神次之。补脾。肥儿丸；安神，钱氏安神丸。调理半年而安。
　　一小儿七月，发搐无时，昏睡不醒，不哭不乳，招之灸之不痛，(口畜)之鼻不嚏，灌药不入。余曰：此真搐也，不可治矣。本县大尹吴子生四月，病惊风，搐过则昏睡不乳，发搐则醒，眼邪视，右手搐搦，请余。余曰：此真搐，不可治。辞而退。[382p]

In Hu Fengya, a child suffered from smallpox, leading to malnutrition and emaciation. A medical apprentice observed that it was not a symptom of malnutrition but rather blood deficiency. The family was confused. Initially, the child experienced a condition resembling epilepsy but was not actually epilepsy; during the day, he was calm, and at night, he had nightmares, clinging to his wet nurse, crying out, "I’m scared, I’m scared," as if someone were trying to catch him. Inquiring about the cause of the illness, it was found that the child did not take medicine well; any attempt to administer it would involve frightening him with needles or fire, contributing to his condition. This was because the stomach represented the earth element, while the kidneys represented the water element; when combined, they transformed into fire. The kidneys govern fear, and fear harms the kidneys. This was due to the weakness of the spleen and stomach, which could not nourish the lungs, leading to a deficiency in the kidneys. The kidneys house willpower, and if they are deficient, the spirit cannot be settled, resulting in anxiety and fear. When awake, the spirit resides in the heart; when asleep, it resides in the kidneys, with the spleen acting as the gateway for the will. Thus, the primary treatment should be to nourish the spleen, with calming the spirit as a secondary measure. To nourish the spleen, use Fei Er Wan; to calm the spirit, use Qian's Anshen Wan. After six months of treatment, the child was at peace.

A seven-month-old child experienced convulsions at all times, was in a stupor unresponsive to wakefulness, did not cry or nurse, did not respond to calling or moxibustion, did not react to inhaling substances, and was unable to take medicine. I said: "This is true convulsion; it cannot be treated." In our county, the magistrate Wu Zisheng, after four months, had a child with shock caused by convulsions, who was left in a stupor and unable to nurse. He would become aware when convulsing, with his eyes deviating, and his right hand twitching. He consulted me. I said: "This is true convulsion; it cannot be treated." I took my leave.[382p]

　　一儿发搐痰壅，有医用白饼子下之不退，凡三下，病益深，合目昏睡，不哭不乳，喉中气鸣，上气喘促，大便时下。余曰：五脏气绝，病不可治，转下之过也。彼医曰：白饼子，钱氏下痰神方也。余曰：尽信书，不如无书。钱氏小儿皆出于门人附会之事也。盖人之有痰，犹木之有津。时令大热，草木流津，痰自热生，此明验也。痰犹水也，附气自行，过颡在山，岂水之性哉？乃搏激使之也。今痰随火上，不如降火而反下之，损其胃气，胃气既败，五脏俱损。故目不开者肝绝也，昏睡不乳者脾绝也，啼声不出者心绝也，喘促痰向者肺绝也，便溺遗失者肾绝也。果不可治而死。
　　邑中有儒医，治病有奇方，惟性太执，不知变通。时有小儿发搐，余谓急惊之证，当用凉泻，导赤散、泻青丸是也。彼谓惊风者，肝火郁遏而成也。火郁则发之，小续命汤是也。人不能决，两从之。余所治者，一日而安。彼治者死。悔不信吾言，无及矣。[383p]

A child had convulsions and phlegm blockage, and a doctor used white pills to treat it without success. After three doses, the child's condition worsened; the child lay with closed eyes, in a deep sleep, neither crying nor breastfeeding, with a wheezing sound in the throat, gasping for breath, and laxative stools. I said: "The organs are failing; the condition is incurable. The excessive treatment has backfired." The doctor replied: "The white pills are a miraculous remedy from the Qian family for phlegm." I said: "To fully trust books is no better than having no books at all. The Qian family's pediatric techniques stem from the teachings of their disciples. Just as wood has moisture, humans have phlegm. In hot weather, plants exude moisture, which generates phlegm naturally—this is an evident truth. Phlegm is like water; it moves with the air and flows downward when it encounters an obstruction. It is not the nature of water to be stagnant. Forcing it can only exacerbate the issue. Now that phlegm rises with the fire, it is better to reduce the heat and let it descend, rather than damaging the stomach's vital energy. If the stomach's energy fails, the five organs will suffer as well. Therefore, when the eyes cannot open, it indicates liver failure; when the child is in a deep sleep and cannot breastfeed, it indicates spleen failure; when there is no crying, it indicates heart failure; when wheezing and phlegm are present, it indicates lung failure; and when there are issues with urination, it indicates kidney failure. Ultimately, it’s beyond healing and leads to death.

In the town, there was a Confucian doctor who treated ailments with remarkable remedies but was overly rigid and unaware of the need for flexibility. Once, a child had convulsions, and I thought it was a case of sudden fright, so I suggested a cooling purge, using Daochi powder and Xieqing pills. He argued that the convulsions were due to accumulated liver fire. When fire accumulates, it triggers convulsions, and he recommended a little life-preserving soup. People could not decide; they followed both approaches. My treatment resulted in safety within a day, while his led to death. Regret for not believing my words was now too late to remedy.[383p]

　　一小儿发搐，先取善推法推之，止向后发，病益危甚。余曰：推法者，乃针灸按摩之遗意也。经曰：无刺大虚人。推掐之法，壮实者可用之。如怯弱者，其气不行，推则有汗，反伤元气也。其家不信余言。余曰：不死必成癎疾。半月后果死。
　　癸亥二月，英山县大尹前县吴某一子发搐，彼医以二陈汤、姜汁、竹沥治之，不退。吴初来任，过罗，与余有识，乃差人请余。比往，视其外候，三关青气，两颊赤色，目常直视，指如燃物。曰：此得之外感，未与发散，热入于里。钱氏曰：肝有热则目直视，得心热则发搐。又曰：两颊赤而目直视，必作惊风。小儿肝常有余，又乘木旺之时，当与泻肝，若二陈汤陈皮、半夏、生姜之辛，皆助肝之物。经曰：以辛补之。所以无效。乃用泻青丸以泻肝木之有余，导赤散以泻心之火，一服而搐即止。余见其胎禀素怯，脾胃且弱，恐后作搐，便成癎疾，又作琥珀丸与之，常服而安。[384p]

A child experienced convulsions. Initially, the method of pushing was used, but it only worsened the situation. I stated that the pushing technique is derived from the principles of acupuncture and massage. The classic says: "Do not stab a person of great deficiency." The technique of pushing and pinching can only be applied to those who are strong and healthy. In the case of weak individuals, their energy does not circulate; pushing them can lead to sweating and ultimately harm their vital energy. The family did not believe my words. I warned them that if they did not take heed, the child would surely develop epilepsy. Two weeks later, he sadly passed away.

In the second month of the gui-hai year, a child of a certain Wu from Ying County experienced convulsions. Local doctors treated him with Erchen Decoction, ginger juice, and bamboo juice, but there was no improvement. Wu, who had just assumed his position, knew me from a previous encounter, so he sent someone to call me. Upon my arrival, I observed the child: his three places of vital energy were bluish, his cheeks were red, and his eyes had a fixed gaze; his fingers were curled as if in a fire. I concluded that his condition was caused by an external factor that had yet to be released, with heat embedded inside. A physician named Qian observed that heat in the liver causes fixed gaze; heat in the heart leads to convulsions. He also said that red cheeks coupled with a fixed gaze indicated impending wind-styled fits. The child’s liver was constantly in excess, and combined with the time of wood dominance, we needed to purge the liver. The ingredients of Erchen Decoction—aged tangerine peel, pinellia, and ginger—are all items that support the liver. The classics say: "Supplement with acrid," hence the inefficacy. I then prescribed Qingxie Pills to purge the excess from the liver wood, and Daohong Powder to clear the fire from the heart. After just one dose, the convulsions stopped.

Noticing his innate constitution was weak and his spleen and stomach were also frail, I feared he would later develop convulsions and finally become epileptic. So, I prepared Amber Pills for him to take regularly, which calmed him.[384p]

　　蕲水沙坂徐淑道一子患惊风，先取医张姓者治之，数日不效。请余往，痰喘正急，惊搐频发。余先治其痰，次治其搐，以次而定。惟身热犹炽。张姓者欲用解毒汤、竹叶汤、小柴胡汤，余皆不可，谓之曰：小儿肝常有余，脾常不足。病发于肝，风木本旺，脾土受伤，此乃虚热，勿用寒凉，致损中气也。乃用四君子汤加炙黄芪、炒黑干姜，一服而安。[385p]

In Qishui, on the sandy slope, Xu Shudao's child was afflicted by convulsions. He first consulted a physician of the Zhang surname, but after several days, there was no improvement. He requested my help; the child was in severe distress with phlegm and wheezing, and frequent convulsions. I first treated the phlegm, then addressed the convulsions, gradually stabilizing the situation. However, the child still had a strong fever. The Zhang physician wanted to use a detoxifying decoction, a bamboo leaf decoction, and a minor Bupleurum decoction, all of which I opposed, saying: "A child's liver is often excessive, while the spleen is usually deficient. The illness arises from the liver, where wind and wood are essentially vigorous, and the spleen and earth are injured. This is indeed false heat; do not use cold and cool treatments, as they will harm the central qi." Thus, I prescribed the Four Gunners Decoction, adding roasted astragalus and fried black ginger; after one dose, the child was at peace.[385p]

　　一小儿年五岁，梦中惊哭，抱其母叫怕，此因被惊吓得之。余制一方，用人参、麦门冬、茯神、黄连、酸枣仁、柏子仁、炙甘草、朱砂各等分，一半水煎，一半入地黄加炙甘草为末，山药粉糊丸黍米大，每服二十五丸，灯草煎汤下，未尽剂而安。
　　余初习医，治一儿二岁发搐而死，但面色未脱，手足未冷，乃气结痰壅而闷绝，非真死也。取艾作小炷，灸两手中冲穴，火方及肉而醒，大哭，遂用家传治惊方，以雄黄解毒丸十五丸利其痰，凉惊丸二十五丸去其热，合之，煎薄荷汤送下。须臾利下黄涎，搐止矣。
　　一儿周岁发热而搐，以泻青丸投之不效，乃问其发搐之状。其母曰：搐过后只好睡，醒时则戏作猫儿声，见人则笑。余曰：医要识证，药要对证。以导赤散服之，一剂而安。其父问是何故？余曰：心脏属火，其声为笑。火生于寅属虎，猫者虎之类也，猫声而笑，知非肝病，乃火病也。故以导赤散泻其心火而安。[386p]

A five-year-old child, startled from a dream, cried out in fear while holding onto his mother. This was due to being frightened. I prepared a remedy using equal parts of ginseng, Ophiopogon, Poria, Coptis, sour jujube seed, biota seed, roasted licorice, and realgar. I brewed half in water and mixed the other half with prepared Rehmannia, ground with roasted licorice into a powder, then made pills the size of millet grains. Each dose consisted of twenty-five pills taken with a broth made from lampwick, and before the full dose was finished, he was calm.

When I first practiced medicine, I treated a two-year-old boy who experienced convulsions and died. However, his complexion had not changed, and his hands and feet were still warm. He was not truly dead but suffered from a trapped qi and phlegm obstruction, leading to suffocation. I took mugwort and made small moxibustion sticks, applying them to the Zhongchong acupoints of both hands. When the fire reached the flesh, the boy woke up with a loud cry. A one-year-old had a fever accompanied by convulsions. After administering Qingpian pills without effect, I inquired about the nature of his convulsions. His mother replied, "After the convulsion, he only wants to sleep, and when he wakes, he plays and makes cat sounds, laughing when he sees others." I said, "A physician must distinguish signs, and medicines must match those signs." I gave him Daochi Powder, and after one dose, he was calm. His father asked why this was so. I explained, "The heart is associated with fire, and its sound is laughter. Fire is generated in the Yin hour, associated with the tiger, and the cat is a related creature. Therefore, making cat sounds and laughing indicates it is not a liver issue but rather a heart condition. Hence, I used Daochi Powder to drain the heart's fire and restore calm."[386p]

　　一儿发搐，因有推法暂退，一月后，至期复发，又推之，或一月一发，或一月再发。余曰：病成癎矣。推法者，乃发表之意，痰聚在心不得出也。幸初成癎者尚可治，若久则为终身痼疾，不可治也。因立方用黄连五钱，朱砂二钱五分，飞白甘遂三分，胆星一钱为末，粟米糊丸，獖猪心血杵匀，丸芡实大，每服一丸，灯草煎汤化下，夜服三，日服一，遂安。
　　王纶《明医杂着》曰：一小儿三岁，因惊抽搐，发热痰盛，久用抱龙丸等药，以清风痰，反致面色或赤或青。余谓始因肝有实邪，故宜用前药。今面色青赤，乃肝经虚热而传心不足之象也。先用六味地黄丸以滋养肝肾，佐以六君子汤少加柴胡、升麻以调补脾胃，诸证顿退而痊。[387p]

A child experienced convulsions, and as a result of the method of pushing, there was a temporary retreat. A month later, on schedule, the convulsions recurred. Sometimes it would happen once a month, or even twice in a month. I said: the illness has developed into epilepsy. Wang Lun in "Miscellaneous Writings of Ming Physicians" states: A three-year-old child experienced convulsions due to fright, accompanied by fever and excessive phlegm. 　　奚氏女六岁，忽然发惊，目动咬牙，或睡中惊搐，痰涎壅盛，或用化痰袪风等药益甚。余曰：面青而见前证，乃属肝木克制脾土，不能摄涎而上涌也。当滋肾水，生肝血，则风自息而痰自消矣。遂用六味丸而愈。

　　一小儿两目动札，手足发搐，数服天麻防风丸之类，以袪风化痰，前证不愈，其痰益甚。得饮食，诸证稍愈。视其准头及左颊色青黄。余曰：脾主涎，此肝木制脾土，不能统摄其涎，非痰盛也。遂用六君子汤加升麻、柴胡、钓藤二剂，饮食渐进，诸证渐愈。又用补中益气而安。

　　一小儿病后遇惊即痰盛，咬牙抽搐，摇头作泻，却服脑、麝、朱砂等剂，以致慢惊而卒。

A young child, after falling ill, would experience a surge of phlegm upon being startled, grinding his teeth and having convulsions, shaking his head as if having diarrhea. After taking ingredients like brain, musk, and vermilion, he developed chronic fright and eventually passed away.

　　姚仪部子每停食则身发赤晕，此饮食内停不消，郁热发外，用清中解郁汤而愈。后患摇头咬牙，痰盛发搐，吐出酸味，伺其吐尽，翌日，少以七味白朮散调理脾胃，遂不复患。

　　一小儿忽腰背反张，目上视，面青赤。面青属肝主风，赤属心主火，此风火相搏，用柴胡栀子散倍加钓藤钩顿安；而痰如旧，又用抱龙丸而愈。

　　王肯堂《证治准绳》曰：东都王氏子吐泻，诸医用药下之，至虚变慢惊，其候昏睡露睛，手足瘈瘲而身冷。钱曰：此慢惊也。与瓜蒌汤，其子胃气实，即开目而身温。王疑其子不大小便，令诸医以药利之，医留八正散等数服，不利而身复冷。令钱氏利小便，钱曰：不当利。小便利之，必身冷。一二日，果身冷矣。因抱出，钱曰：不能食而胃中虚，若利大小便，则脾胃俱虚，当身冷而闭目即死。今幸胎气实而难衰也。钱氏用益黄散、使君子丸四服，令微能饮食，至日午果能饮食。所以然者，谓利大小便，脾胃虚寒，当补脾不可别攻也。后又不语，诸医作失音治之。钱曰：既失音，何开目而能饮食？又牙不紧而口不噤也？诸医不能晓，以地黄补肾。钱曰：此因凉药，利小便，致脾肾俱虚，今脾已实，肾尚虚，故补肾必安。治之半月而能言，一月而痊。[412p]

Wang Kentang in "Principles of Diagnosis and Treatment" states: In the Eastern Capital, the son of the Wang family experienced diarrhea. Various doctors treated him with purgatives until he became weak, showing symptoms of a lingering fright, such as drowsiness with exposed eyes, coldness in his limbs, and shivering. Qian noted that this was a lingering fright and prescribed Guo Luo Decoction. If the son had strong stomach qi, he would regain consciousness and warmth. Wang doubted that his son had no bowel movements and ordered the doctors to use medications to induce them. The doctors administered Ba Zheng Powder several times, but it was ineffective and his body became cold again. Wang then instructed Qian to help with urination, but Qian advised against it, saying: "Inducing urination would lead to coldness in the body." After one or two days, the body did indeed become cold. They then carried him out, and Qian remarked: "He cannot eat and has a weak stomach. If we induce bowel movements, both the spleen and stomach will be exhausted, leading to body coldness and closing of the eyes, which could be fatal. Fortunately, the fetal energy is strong and resilient." Qian used Yi Huang Powder and Shi Jun Zi Pills for four doses, allowing him to drink and eat a little by noon. The reasoning behind this was that inducing bowel movements while the spleen and stomach were weak and cold could lead to further problems; therefore, the spleen should be strengthened rather than attacked separately. Later, he also became mute, and the doctors attempted to treat his lost voice. Qian suggested that since he was mute, how could he open his eyes and eat? Moreover, his teeth were not tightly closed and his mouth was not locked. The doctors were baffled and recommended using Rehmannia to nourish the kidneys. Qian countered that this was due to cooling medications that induced urination, resulting in weakness of both the spleen and kidneys. Now that the spleen was strong but the kidneys were still weak, it was essential to nourish the kidneys gently. After half a month of treatment, he could speak, and within a month, he was healed.[412p]

　　少时闻友人孙彭山云：尝见姻家一小儿，患惊搐，延专科治之，诸证悉退，而摇头不止。后一老医至，于常服药中，加入紫河车，即时愈。按紫河车，草名，《神农本经》名蚤休，唐本名金线重楼，钱氏方名白甘遂，主治惊癎摇头弄舌。乃本经正文，古人谓遵白字疗病多效，不虚也。
[413p]

In my youth, I heard my friend Sun Pengshan say: he once saw a young child from his in-laws who suffered from seizures. They sought specialized treatment, and all symptoms subsided, yet he continued to shake his head uncontrollably. Later, an older doctor arrived and added purple river car to the regular medication, and the child was instantly cured. According to the "Shennong Bencao," purple river car, also known as "Zao Xiu," is noted in Tang texts as "Jin Xian Chong Lou," and referred to as "Bai Gan Sui" in the Qian family's prescriptions, mainly treating seizures, head shaking, and tongue antics. Thus, the main text of the classics indicates that ancient practitioners believed following the writings closely was highly effective, and it is not false.[413p]
